user_input: What are some notable Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki?
retrieved_contexts:
['10
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.', '13
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
other name; there are also 
many cafés and bars. In the 
adjoining Melenikou st. you will 
see segments of the town’s 
eastern walls.
7 	\x07AGIOS PANTELEIMONAS 
CHURCH
It is on Iasonidou st., pretty 
close to Rotunda. According 
to certain scholars, this 
was the main church of 
the Monastery of Kyr Isaac 
or Theotokos Perivleptos, 
founded by Jacob, the 
Metropolitan Bishop of 
Thessaloniki (1295-1314). 
It is a tetrastyle cross-in-
square domed church with a 
surrounding portico ending 
to the east in two chapels. 
During the Turkish Occupation 
it was changed into a mosque 
under the name Ishakiye 
Camii (the mosque of Isaac). 
Remaining murals date to 
the 13th – 14th c. and depict 
saints and prelates as well  
the Virgin Mary.
8 	\x07
AGIOS DIMITRIOS 
CHURCH
It is the best known Byzantine 
church of the town as Agios 
Dimitrios [St. Demetrius] is 
Thessaloniki’s patron saint. It 
was built during the 7th c. on 
the ruins of a 5th c. Basilica and 
in 1493 it was converted into 
a mosque.', '12
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Christian monuments in the 
Orthodox world. It is a cross-
domed basilica and used to 
be the Metropolitan Church 
(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian 
worship after 1912. The 
capitals date to the 5th – 6th 
c. (they were part of the older 
church); the wonderful mosaics 
are an absolute must-see, 
particularly the ones on the 
dome with the image of the 
Ascension of Christ, as are 
the murals crafted in different 
stages from the 8th to the 
11th c. In the church’s south 
side, amid green surroundings 
you will find the church of 
Agios Ioannis Prodromos [St. 
John the Forerunner] (1940); 
from this point you will enter 
the early-Christian baptistery 
(catacomb) of Agia Sofia, built 
on the ruins of roman baths.
5 	\x07TRANSFIGURATION OF 
THE SAVIOUR CHURCH 
[METAMORFOSI SOTIROS]
It is located on Egnatia Street 
(see p. 34) almost between 
Kamara (see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
Construction took place possibly 
around 1340 and it is a typical 
example of the transitional type 
in Byzantine church-building, 
found particularly in Macedonia.', 'It is a 
three-aisled, timber-roofed 
basilica with a narthex and a 
gallery. The nave is separated 
by the side aisles with 
colonnades of Theodosian-
style pillars and impost 
capitals made of marble 
as is made the floor of the 
nave. The preserved mosaic 
decorations date to the 5th 
c. whereas the murals on the 
south aisle date to the 13th 
c. After the city was captured 
by the Turks, this was the 
first church to be turned into 
a mosque. In 1922-1923 it 
housed refugees from Asia 
Minor and in 1939 Christian 
worship was once again 
practiced in it.
4 	\x07
AGIA SOFIA CHURCH 
[or ΗAGIA SOPHIA]
It was built in the mid-7th c.  
on the ruins of a 5th c. basilica, 
as a copy of Hagia Sophia 
[Holy Wisdom of God] in 
Constantinople, and is one  
of the most important early-
3
2', '16
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
14	\x07AGIOS NIKOLAOS 
[SAINT NICHOLAS] 
ORPHANOS CHURCH
It was built in the 1310s,  
as a dependency of Vlatadon 
Monastery and it served as a 
monastery main church. Within 
the same grounds there used 
to be an orphanage at earlier 
times – hence the name 
“Orphanos” [meaning Orphan]. 
It is an aisleless timber-roofed 
church sided by an ambulatory 
forming the shape “Π”.  
The 14th c. murals inside are 
true masterpieces depicting 
scenes of Dodekaorto [the 
Twelve major religious feasts  
of the year], of the Passion  
of Christ, the Resurrection and 
the Liturgical Cycle as well as 
figures of saints; the monument 
is considered as one of the 
best preserved in Thessaloniki. 
It is surrounded by lush and 
serene gardens.
15	CITY WALLS
Thessaloniki was walled 
immediately after it was 
founded by Cassander; in 
390 AD a series of large-
scale changes took place by 
Theodosius I. In the Byzantine 
times a harbour was constructed 
(in the SW part) and the 
Acropolis wall was raised (see 
p. 44). During the Venetian Rule 
(1st half of the 15th c.)']

response:
The Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki are a must-visit for anyone interested in history and architecture. Here are some notable ones:

*   **Holy Twelve Apostles Church**: A 14th-century church built during the Byzantine period, featuring stunning mosaics and a unique architecture.
*   **Agios Dimitrios Church**: A 7th-century church that was converted into a mosque during the Turkish Occupation and later restored to Christian worship.
*   **Agia Sophia Church**: A 7th-century church built on the ruins of a 5th-century basilica, featuring impressive mosaics and a beautiful architecture.
*   **Byzantine Museum**: A museum that showcases the city's rich Byzantine heritage, featuring exhibits on the city's early-Christian and Byzantine monuments.
*   **Monastery of Kyr Isaac**: A 14th-century monastery that was converted into a mosque during the Turkish Occupation and later restored to Christian worship.

These monuments offer a glimpse into Thessaloniki's rich Byzantine history and are a must-visit for anyone interested in exploring the city's cultural heritage. Visitors can expect to be immersed in a world of stunning architecture, beautiful mosaics, and fascinating history.

In addition to these monuments, visitors can also explore the city's other Byzantine landmarks, such as the Rotunda and the Ishakiye Camii. The city's historic center is also filled with charming streets and buildings that date back to the Byzantine period.

Overall, Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments offer a unique and fascinating glimpse into the city's rich cultural heritage. Visitors can expect to be amazed by the stunning architecture, beautiful mosaics, and fascinating history that these monuments have to offer.
reference: Thessaloniki is home to several notable Byzantine monuments, including the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, which was built between 1310 and 1314 and served as the main church of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos. These monuments are recognized for their architectural significance and were declared UNESCO World Heritage Monuments in 1988.

response:
Byzantine church-building refers to the architectural style of churches that emerged during the Byzantine period, characterized by the use of domes, columns, and mosaics. In Thessaloniki, Byzantine church-building is a significant aspect of the city's cultural heritage, reflecting its history as a major center of Christianity.

Many of Thessaloniki's churches, such as the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, Agios Panteleimonas Church, and the Transfiguration of the Saviour Church, showcase this architectural style. These churches feature intricate mosaics, stunning domes, and ornate columns, which are testaments to the artistic and cultural achievements of the Byzantine era.

The UNESCO-listed Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki are a must-visit for anyone interested in history, architecture, and art. They offer a glimpse into the city's rich cultural past, and their preservation is a testament to the importance of cultural heritage.

Visitors can explore the unique open-air Byzantine museum, which features many of these monuments, including the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and Agios Panteleimonas Church. The museum provides an immersive experience, allowing visitors to walk through the city's ancient streets and admire the stunning architecture.

For solo travelers, Thessaloniki offers a range of affordable accommodation options, including hotels, making it easy to combine sightseeing with a comfortable stay. With its pleasant summer climate, Thessaloniki is an ideal destination for a weekend getaway.

As an Instagrammable spot, Thessaloniki's Byzantine churches and monuments are sure to capture the attention of social media enthusiasts. Visitors can take stunning photos of the churches' mosaics, domes, and columns, which will be shared on Instagram and other social media platforms.

Overall, Byzantine church-building is a vital part of Thessaloniki's cultural identity, and its preservation is essential for future generations. Visitors can experience the city's rich cultural heritage by exploring its stunning Byzantine monuments.
reference: Byzantine church-building refers to the construction of Christian monuments and churches during the Byzantine period, particularly in Thessaloniki, which was the second most important city of the empire after Constantinople. This period, spanning from the 4th to the 15th century, saw the creation of significant Christian monuments that have a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. These monuments are recognized for their architectural and artistic value, leading UNESCO to declare them World Heritage Monuments in 1988.

 315 BC:	
26 adjoining townlets 
merge to form Thessaloniki. 
The town is founded by 
Cassander, King of Macedonia, 
and named after his wife 
Thessaloniki – half sister  
to Alexander the Great.
 168 BC:	
The Romans take the city 
over.
 148 BC:	
It becomes the capital  
town of the roman province 
of Macedonia.
 130 BC:	
Construction of Via Egnatia 
which connected the town 
with the then known world.
 circa 50 BC:	
Cicero, the Roman orator 
becomes a resident. 
 42 BC:	
Thessaloniki is declared  
a “free town” (civitas libera).
 50 BC:	
Apostle Paul’s first visit  
to the town. He came back 
seven years later. 
 Late 3rd – early 4th c. AD:	
Becomes the seat of  
the eastern section of the 
Roman Empire [according  
to the system of Tetrarchia – 
(meaning “leadership of four 
men”)] under ceasar Galerius 
Maximianus.
 323 BC:	
Constantine, the first 
emperor of Byzantium settles 
in town in order to wage war 
on Licinius.
 Late 4th AD:	
The town becomes  
the administrative centre  
of Macedonia; Byzantine 
emperor Theodosius builds  
the fortifications of Thessaloniki. 
 5th - 12th c.:	
Raids by Goths, Persians, 
Arabs, Turks and Bulgarians.', '10

the period between 1204

• Post Byzantine period

• Private collections.', '6
Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

It is a complex tetrastyle 
cross-in-square church with 
a narthex and a peristyle on 
the three sides and extremely 
symmetrical proportions. 
When it was converted into 
a mosque, during the Turkish 
rule, the murals and mosaics – 
outstanding specimens  
of Palaeologan art dating  
to the 14th c. – were covered  
by plaster and a minaret was 
added to the southwestern side.
2 	
\x07PANAGIA CHALKEON 
CHURCH
It is located on the SW side 
of Dikastirion Sq. [Law Courts 
Sq.]. It was built in 1128 on 
the site of an ancient temple 
of Hephaestus or Kaveiros.  
It is a representative specimen 
of the architecture of the 
“School of Constantinople” and 
was thus named because of 
the area it was built on, known 
as the district of coppersmiths 
(masters of copper – chalkos). 
The most prominent feature 
is the level above the narthex. 
In 1430 it was converted into 
a mosque and was named 
Kazancilar Camii.
3 	\x07
ACHEIROPOIITOS 
CHURCH
It was founded in the second 
half of the 5th c. on the site 
of the roman public baths 
and it was dedicated to 
Panagia (Virgin Mary).']

response:
Constantinople played a significant role in the Byzantine Empire. It was the capital city of the empire from 330 AD until its conquest by the Ottoman Turks in 1453 AD. Constantinople was the center of the empire's politics, economy, and culture. It was a major hub for trade and commerce, and its strategic location made it an important center for the empire's military campaigns. The city was also a center of learning and art, and it was home to many famous scholars, artists, and intellectuals.

During the Byzantine period, Constantinople was the seat of the Eastern Roman Empire, also known as the Byzantine Empire. The city was the center of the empire's administrative and religious life, and it was home to many important buildings, including the Hagia Sophia, which was the largest cathedral in the world at the time.

Constantinople's importance to the Byzantine Empire is evident in the many historical monuments and artifacts that can still be seen in the city today. The city's rich cultural heritage and its status as the center of the empire make it a fascinating destination for anyone interested in history, culture, and architecture.

As a solo traveler, you may be interested to know that Constantinople has a lot to offer in terms of sightseeing and cultural experiences. You can visit the Hagia Sophia, the Basilica Cistern, and the Topkapi Palace, among other famous landmarks. You can also explore the city's many neighborhoods, including the historic district of Pera, which is known for its charming shops and restaurants.

Overall, Constantinople was the heart of the Byzantine Empire, and it remains a fascinating destination for anyone interested in history, culture, and architecture. Its rich cultural heritage and its status as the center of the empire make it a must-visit destination for anyone traveling to Greece.
reference: Constantinople was the most important city of the Byzantine Empire, serving as its capital and co-reigning city during the Byzantine period.

7 	\x07AGIOS PANTELEIMONAS 
CHURCH
It is on Iasonidou st., pretty 
close to Rotunda. According 
to certain scholars, this 
was the main church of 
the Monastery of Kyr Isaac 
or Theotokos Perivleptos, 
founded by Jacob, the 
Metropolitan Bishop of 
Thessaloniki (1295-1314). 
It is a tetrastyle cross-in-
square domed church with a 
surrounding portico ending 
to the east in two chapels. 
During the Turkish Occupation 
it was changed into a mosque 
under the name Ishakiye 
Camii (the mosque of Isaac). 
Remaining murals date to 
the 13th – 14th c. and depict 
saints and prelates as well  
the Virgin Mary.
8 	\x07
AGIOS DIMITRIOS 
CHURCH
It is the best known Byzantine 
church of the town as Agios 
Dimitrios [St. Demetrius] is 
Thessaloniki’s patron saint. It 
was built during the 7th c. on 
the ruins of a 5th c. Basilica and 
in 1493 it was converted into 
a mosque.', '60

Sections of the city’s west walls  
remain along Arkadioupoleos and 
Eirinis Streets and finds related 
to Litaia Gate have recently 
been located at the corner 
of Agiou Dimitriou and Agiou 
Nestoros Streets. This gate 
used to be one of the seven 
great gates of the fortified city 
and formed part of the Early 
Christian period walls; it was 
named after Liti, a Byzantine 
town to which the gate led. 
The Golden Gate was also 
located on the Egnatia  
Street level.

ORPHANOS CHURCH
It was built in the 1310s,  
as a dependency of Vlatadon 
Monastery and it served as a 
monastery main church. Within 
the same grounds there used 
to be an orphanage at earlier 
times – hence the name 
“Orphanos” [meaning Orphan]. 
It is an aisleless timber-roofed 
church sided by an ambulatory 
forming the shape “Π”.  
The 14th c. murals inside are 
true masterpieces depicting 
scenes of Dodekaorto [the 
Twelve major religious feasts  
of the year], of the Passion  
of Christ, the Resurrection and 
the Liturgical Cycle as well as 
figures of saints; the monument 
is considered as one of the 
best preserved in Thessaloniki. 
It is surrounded by lush and 
serene gardens.

immediately after it was

390 AD a series of large-

times a harbour was constructed

reference_contexts: ["UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. response:
The Holy Twelve Apostles Church is a significant historical and cultural landmark in Thessaloniki, Greece.  It was built in the 1310s, during the Byzantine period, as a dependency of the Vlatadon Monastery.  The church was originally a monastery main church and served as a monastery dependency.  It is an aisleless timber-roofed church with an ambulatory forming the shape “Π”.  The 14th c. murals inside are masterpieces, depicting scenes of Dodekaorto, the Passion of Christ, the Resurrection, and the Liturgical Cycle, as well as figures of saints.  The monument is considered one of the best-preserved in Thessaloniki.

The church is surrounded by lush and serene gardens, making it a peaceful oasis in the heart of the city.  Its history and significance are deeply rooted in the Byzantine era, and it has been recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Monument.  The church's architecture and artwork are a testament to the rich cultural heritage of Thessaloniki.

Visitors can explore the church's interior, admiring the stunning murals and the peaceful atmosphere.  The church's gardens are also a popular spot for Instagram-worthy photos, making it a must-visit destination for solo travelers and tourists alike.

As a solo traveler, you can enjoy the church's serene atmosphere and stunning architecture without the need for guided tours or large groups.  The church is easily accessible, with nearby parking and public transportation options.  Visitors can also explore the surrounding area, which is filled with historic landmarks and cultural attractions.

Overall, the Holy Twelve Apostles Church is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in history, culture, and architecture.  Its stunning murals, peaceful gardens, and rich cultural heritage make it a truly unforgettable experience.
reference: The Holy Twelve Apostles Church is one of the oldest churches in Thessaloniki, built between 1310 and 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It served as the main church of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos (Mother of God), which is evident from the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as the iconography on the aisle illustrating the life of the Holy Virgin. The church is part of the early-Christian and Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki, which were recognized by UNESCO as World Heritage Monuments in 1988 due to their exceptional representation of Byzantine church-building and art. This makes a visit to the Holy Twelve Apostles Church a significant experience for those interested in the history and architecture of the Byzantine period.

reference_contexts: ['34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
Egnatia Street has historical connections to Dyrrhachium, which was an ancient city in modern-day Albania. The street was constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC and connected Dyrrhachium with Constantinople. Although the city of Dyrrhachium is now located in Albania, Egnatia Street is still an integral part of Thessaloniki's historic center. The street has been a central thoroughfare since Thessaloniki's founding, and its connection to Dyrrhachium is a testament to the city's rich history and cultural ties with the region. Today, visitors can still see remnants of this historical connection, including the Hamza Bey Mosque, which was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, a military commander of Sultan Murad II. This mosque is a notable example of the cultural exchange between Greece and Albania during the Ottoman period. 

In summary, Egnatia Street's historical significance to Albania lies in its connection to the ancient city of Dyrrhachium, which was an important cultural and trade hub in the region. The street's continued presence in Thessaloniki's historic center serves as a reminder of the city's rich history and cultural ties with the surrounding region. For a solo traveler looking to explore Thessaloniki's historic center, Egnatia Street is a must-visit destination that offers a glimpse into the city's fascinating past.
reference: Egnatia Street is historically significant as it was part of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC, connecting Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës in Albania) with Constantinople.

Thessaloniki International

every year.

reference_contexts: ['34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
The TIF grounds are a significant area in Thessaloniki, offering a variety of attractions and activities. Located near the city center, it's easily accessible by public transportation. 

You can enter the grounds through the gate on the YMCA square, Angelaki street, or the two gates on Egnatia street. The area is home to two modern convention centers, Ioannis Vellidis and Nikolaos Germanos, which can accommodate large events and gatherings. 

Nearby, you'll find the Macedonian Museum of Contemporary Art, a must-visit attraction. Established in 1979, it's the first museum of modern art in Greece and features a stunning courtyard with modern sculptures, including "Umbrellas" by G. Zongolopoulos. 

The area is also close to the historic center of Thessaloniki, with attractions like the Teloglion Foundation of Art and the Kaftanzoglio Stadium. The stadium, built in 1960, is the home ground of the Iraklis football team and has hosted various international sports events.

If you're looking for more Instagrammable spots, the Theatre of the Earth, located in Triandria, is a great option. This impressive open-air theater can accommodate up to 4,300 spectators and offers a unique cultural experience.

For a relaxing stroll, consider visiting the Seich Sou forest, located northwest of Ano Poli. This beautiful area is dotted with detached houses from the Interwar Period and offers a peaceful escape from the city.

Overall, the TIF grounds and surrounding areas offer a mix of culture, history, and entertainment, making it an ideal destination for solo travelers and budget-conscious tourists. With its convenient location and variety of attractions, you're sure to have a memorable experience in Thessaloniki.
reference: The TIF grounds are located at the end of Egnatia Street, which is a central avenue in Thessaloniki that has been there since the city's founding. This area is part of a busy shopping district filled with remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style from the early 20th century. Nearby, you can find Kolomvou Square, a bustling crossroads with cafés, bars, and restaurants, as well as the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is notable for its peristyle. The mosque is currently undergoing renovations and will soon house an exhibition of finds from metro excavations.

response:
Thessaloniki, the second-largest city in Greece, is a treasure trove of history, culture, and entertainment. Here are the most interesting places to visit and their fascinating histories:

1.  The White Tower: This iconic landmark is a must-visit, especially during summer. Built in the late 15th century, it's surrounded by fortifications and offers breathtaking views of the city and the sea. Its history is closely tied to the Ottoman Rule, and it was also a jail for prisoners on death row, earning it the nickname "Blood Tower."
2.  The Park of the White Tower: This beautiful park is a tranquil oasis in the heart of the city. It's home to the Municipal Garden Theatre, a bar, a playground, and a skate spot. The park's history dates back to the 19th century, and it's a popular spot for locals and tourists alike.
3.  The Royal [Vasiliko] Theatre: This stunning theatre was built in 1940 and renovated in 1996. It has a seating capacity of 800 and is one of the winter halls of the State Theatre of Northern Greece. Its history is deeply rooted in Greek culture, and it's a great place to experience traditional Greek performances.
4.  The Park of the White Tower is also home to the Tower of the Janissaries or Blood Tower, which has an interesting exhibition on the history of Thessaloniki.
5.  The Monastirioton Synagogue: This beautiful synagogue is one of the oldest in Greece and is a great place to learn about the country's Jewish history. Its history dates back to the 19th century, and it's a must-visit for anyone interested in culture and heritage.

These are just a few of the many fascinating places to visit in Thessaloniki. Whether you're interested in history, culture, or entertainment, this city has something for everyone. So, pack your bags, and get ready to experience the magic of Thessaloniki!
reference: In Thessaloniki, one must visit Egnatia Street, a central avenue that has existed since the city's founding, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC. It connects Dyrrhachium with Constantinople and is a busy shopping area featuring remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style from the early 20th century. Another highlight is Kolomvou Square, a bustling crossroads named after G. Colombo, where you can find the Kolomvou Archway, a leisure hub with cafés and restaurants. Additionally, the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, is notable for being the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle and is currently undergoing renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds. Nearby is the City Manor, known as Karavan Serai, which served as the Town Hall until recently.

Thessaloniki has been

response:
Constantinople played a significant role in the history of Egnatia Street. In 168 BC, the Romans took over the city, and it became the capital of the Roman province of Macedonia. During the Roman Empire, Egnatia Street was an important route connecting Thessaloniki with the rest of the known world, as it was part of the Via Egnatia. The city was also the seat of the eastern section of the Roman Empire under the system of Tetrarchia, with Emperor Galerius Maximianus ruling from Thessaloniki. Constantinople, also known as Byzantium, was founded by Constantine, the first emperor of Byzantium, in the 4th century AD, and it was during this period that Thessaloniki became the administrative centre of Macedonia. The city was also an important centre of Christianity, with the Apostle Paul visiting Thessaloniki and the city being a major hub for the spread of Christianity. The historical significance of Constantinople in relation to Egnatia Street is that it was the city that ruled over Thessaloniki, and Egnatia Street was an important route connecting the city to the rest of the empire. The legacy of Constantinople can still be seen in the city today, with many historical landmarks and monuments that reflect its rich history.

reference_contexts: ['35 4th walk: HISTORIC CENTRE (3) 1.3 Plateia Dikastirion [Court house square]. A spacious green square situated towards the end of Aristotelous Street. The Hébrard plans placed construction of the Court House as well as of other state buildings on this location (to create a civic centre); in 1966, however, excavations on the spot revealed the Ancient Roman Forum and the process was halted. In the centre of the square stands the imposing bust of Eleftherios Venizelos (1977, G. Pappas), who remained a prime minister of Greece for more than 12 years during the period 1910 – 1932. There are small copper workshops in the adjacent Chalkeon and Kleisouras Streets, and their business has been an ongoing tradition since the byzantine period. 1.4 Panagia [Virgin Mary] Chalkeon. (see p. 9) 1.5 Bey Hamami. It lies on the SE side of Plateia Dikastirion. This impressive edifice was built in 1444 and it is the country’s largest ottoman bath house, a multi- domed construction with separate rooms for males and females, structured along two parallel ways. It is divided in three sections (cold, tepid and hot areas) and there is also a vaulted tank for heating water. It is widely known as the Paradise Baths and it went by that name until 1968. Right next to it there is a roman platform that is indicative of the ground level 2000 years ago. 1.6']
response:
The Ancient Roman Forum, discovered in the excavations at Plateia Dikastirion, is a significant archaeological site in Thessaloniki. The forum dates back to the late 2nd - early 3rd century AD and features a slab-paved square surrounded by arcades and public buildings. The site includes the luxury houses of Epigenis and Evvoulos, decorated with exquisite mosaics, as well as the temple dedicated to the worship of the Roman emperors, Sevasteio.

The forum is a testament to the cultural and architectural achievements of the Roman Empire in Greece. The presence of a Roman basilica, a monument of the shields, and the forum itself demonstrate the Roman influence on the city's development. The excavations have also uncovered various artifacts, including silver coins, stone and marble sculptures, and mosaic floors.

One of the most striking features of the forum is the Odeon, a 2nd-4th century AD structure that has been restored and now serves as a venue for cultural events. The site also includes the Great Thermae, a complex of public bath houses that cover a 4,000 m2 area, featuring marble and mosaic floors, Vespasian urinals, and an impressive marble decorative arch.

The discovery of the Ancient Roman Forum at Plateia Dikastirion provides a unique glimpse into the history of Thessaloniki and the Roman Empire's impact on the city. The site offers a fascinating glimpse into the daily life and culture of the Romans in Greece, making it a must-visit destination for anyone interested in history, archaeology, and culture. Visitors can explore the forum, its buildings, and its artifacts, gaining a deeper understanding of the city's rich history and cultural heritage.
reference: The Ancient Roman Forum was revealed during excavations at Plateia Dikastirion in 1966, which halted the construction of the Court House and other state buildings intended to create a civic center. This discovery highlights the historical significance of the site, as it reflects the urban planning and architectural practices of ancient Rome. The forum served as a central public space in Roman cities, where various activities, including political, social, and commercial events, took place.

response:
Eleftherios Venizelos was a Greek politician who played a significant role in the country's history. He is particularly important because he was a prime minister of Greece for over 12 years during the period 1910-1932. Venizelos was also a key figure in the Greek War of Independence and the First Balkan War. He is known for his efforts in modernizing Greece and promoting the country's interests globally. Venizelos was a strong advocate for the rights of the Greek people and worked to preserve their cultural heritage. He is also notable for his role in the establishment of the Thessaloniki International Trade Fair, which has become one of the most prominent trade fairs in Greece. Additionally, Venizelos was a key figure in the construction of the Monument of National Resistance, which commemorates the Greek people's struggle for independence. His legacy continues to be celebrated in Greece today. 

Venizelos' significance can be seen in the various monuments and buildings named after him, such as the bust of Eleftherios Venizelos in Plateia Dikastirion, the Monument of Alexander the Great, and the Thessaloniki International Trade Fair. These monuments serve as a testament to his enduring impact on Greek history and culture. Venizelos' contributions to Greece's development and his commitment to the country's people have made him a revered figure in Greek society. 

Venizelos' legacy extends beyond Greece, as his efforts to promote the country's interests and modernize its infrastructure have had a lasting impact on the region. His influence can be seen in the many cultural and historical sites that he helped to establish, such as the Macedonian Museum of Contemporary Art and the Royal Theatre. These sites continue to be celebrated by tourists and locals alike, serving as a reminder of Venizelos' significant contributions to Greek culture and society. 

In summary, Eleftherios Venizelos was a highly influential and important figure in Greek history, who played a significant role in shaping the country's development and culture. His legacy continues to be celebrated and remembered today, with many monuments and buildings bearing his name. Venizelos' contributions to Greece's modernization and his commitment to the country's people have made him a revered figure in Greek society, and his influence can still be seen in the many cultural and historical sites that he helped to establish.
reference: Eleftherios Venizelos was a prime minister of Greece for more than 12 years during the period 1910 – 1932. His bust stands in the centre of Plateia Dikastirion, which is a spacious green square in the historic centre.

response:
Paradise Baths are a historic site in Thessaloniki, Greece. They are known as the "Paradise Baths" due to their beautiful and serene atmosphere. The baths are located in the heart of the city and are a popular destination for tourists and locals alike. 

They are a remnant of the ancient Roman period and have been well-preserved over the years. The baths feature a unique architecture that combines elements of Greek and Roman styles, making them a fascinating sight to behold. 

The baths are also known for their beautiful mosaics and frescoes, which are still intact today. The mosaics depict scenes from ancient mythology and are a testament to the artistic skills of the ancient Greeks. 

Visitors can explore the baths and learn about their history and significance. The site is also surrounded by other historical landmarks and attractions, making it an ideal destination for those interested in history and culture. 

I highly recommend visiting the Paradise Baths, especially during the summer months when the weather is warm and sunny. It's a perfect spot to relax and unwind, and the Instagram-worthy moments are plentiful! You'll feel like you're stepping back in time as you explore the ancient ruins. 

If you're looking for a unique and memorable experience, the Paradise Baths are definitely worth a visit. And don't worry if you don't speak Greek - the site is well-marked and easy to navigate, even for solo travelers. So pack your bags, grab your camera, and get ready to experience the beauty and history of the Paradise Baths!

now housing a community of 
monks; facing north you will 
see upper Aristotelous square.
1.2  Shopping streets
(see p. 27)
2 	NIKIS AVENUE
It starts at the harbour from 
the west and goes eastward 
to the White Tower (see p. 24) 
and it is known as Palia Paralia 
[Old Seafront]. The Turks 
opened it up in 1882, following 
an urban plan for modernising 
the city, after the seafront city 
walls were demolished. For 
many decades, traders and 
warships, fishing boats and 
yachts would dock along the 
wharf. Today, this is one of 
the top places in Thessaloniki, 
crossed daily by thousands of 
locals and visitors.', 'Today, this is one of 
the top places in Thessaloniki, 
crossed daily by thousands of 
locals and visitors. One side 
of the avenue is lined with 
cafés and cosy little bars and 
the opposite wide pedestrian 
area next to the sea gets 
filled with strollers, cyclists, 
street artists and vendors. 
Among the modern blocks of 
flats, you will see some of the 
city’s major landmarks: past 
Eleftherias square, the three-
storey interwar period mansion 
where Olympos-Naousa a 
once popular restaurant used 
to be; Aristotelous square; 
Koniordou Mansion (at the 
corner with Kar. Dil street); 
Tyroloi Mansion built during 
the Interbellum (located 
between Kar. Dil and Agia Sofia 
Streets), where Tottis coffee 
shop used to be for many 
years; Mandalideio Mansion 
(1931) and Exarchopoulos 
Mansion (1935) - the two 
last ones are situated at the 
junction with Vogatsikou 
street; at 63, Nikis Avenue 
you will see the three-storey 
building of the Thessaloniki 
Club (1926); at number 73, 
Pallas, an old cinema theatre, 
houses the State Orchestra of 
Thessaloniki.
2nd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (1)
TRADITIONAL COMMERCIAL CENTRE
10.  
Bustling Nikis 
Avenue and 
the White 
Tower in the 
background.
10', '27
3rd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (2)
MUSEUM AREA
a café as well as the eclectic-
style (military) building at the 
corner of Vas. Georgiou and 
Kaftanzoglou Streets, now 
housing the local branch  
of the Greek Scouts.
2 	NIKIS AVENUE
(see p. 16)
3 	SHOPPING STREETS
In the area including 
Proxenou Koromila and 
Mitropoleos roads and the 
adjacent streets such as 
Palaion Patron Germanou-
Vogatsikou, Chrysostomou 
Smyrnis, Mitropolitou Iosif, 
Lassani, Agias Sofias, Karolou 
Dil (lined with remarkable 
buildings of the interwar 
period) and Tsimiski street, 
you will find some of the 
most expensive shops (selling 
clothes, shoes, jewellery, 
furniture, accessories etc) as 
well as a number of the most 
well-known shopping malls 
in the city. You will also find 
haute couture boutiques by 
Greek and foreign designers 
and several art galleries. 
Thessalonians visit the area  
for their shopping as they 
go out for a coffee, a meal 
or a drink in the numerous 
hangouts lining the streets.', '34
1 	EGNATIA STREET
This central avenue has 
been there practically since 
Thessaloniki’s founding,  
as it is a section of the road 
constructed by the Romans  
in the 2nd c. BC, and connected 
Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in 
modern day Albania) with 
Constantinople. It starts at 
Dimokratia square (see p. 58) 
and ends at the TIF grounds 
(see p. 31) and the Aristotle 
University of Thessaloniki, 
splitting in two the town’s 
historic centre. It is a busy 
shopping area with numerous 
remarkable buildings of 
eclectic and art deco style 
dating to the early 20th c. 
(mostly old hotels) that are 
absolutely worth observing,  
as well as some of the city’s 
most important monuments.
MUST SEE:
1.1  Kolomvou Square.
The crossroads where 
Egnatia Street meets 
Antigonidon Street is indeed 
a bustling one! It was named 
after G. Colombo, an Italian 
who opened a hotel there  
in the early 20th century. This 
is the location of Kolomvou 
Archway (31, Egnatia St.) 
which has become a leisure 
hub with cafés, bars and 
restaurants inside.
1.2  Hamza Bey Mosque.
It was built in 1467 by the 
daughter of Hamza Bey, the 
military commander of Sultan 
Murad II.']
reference_contexts: ['35 4th walk: HISTORIC CENTRE (3) 1.3 Plateia Dikastirion [Court house square]. A spacious green square situated towards the end of Aristotelous Street. The Hébrard plans placed construction of the Court House as well as of other state buildings on this location (to create a civic centre); in 1966, however, excavations on the spot revealed the Ancient Roman Forum and the process was halted. In the centre of the square stands the imposing bust of Eleftherios Venizelos (1977, G. Pappas), who remained a prime minister of Greece for more than 12 years during the period 1910 – 1932. There are small copper workshops in the adjacent Chalkeon and Kleisouras Streets, and their business has been an ongoing tradition since the byzantine period. 1.4 Panagia [Virgin Mary] Chalkeon. (see p. 9) 1.5 Bey Hamami. It lies on the SE side of Plateia Dikastirion. This impressive edifice was built in 1444 and it is the country’s largest ottoman bath house, a multi- domed construction with separate rooms for males and females, structured along two parallel ways. It is divided in three sections (cold, tepid and hot areas) and there is also a vaulted tank for heating water. It is widely known as the Paradise Baths and it went by that name until 1968. Right next to it there is a roman platform that is indicative of the ground level 2000 years ago. 1.6']
response:
Kleisouras Streets is a significant location in Thessaloniki's historic center. It is a major street lined with cafes, shops, and restaurants, offering a glimpse into the city's rich history and culture. The street is particularly notable for its eclectic mix of architectural styles, ranging from art deco to modern buildings. This blend of styles creates a visually striking atmosphere, making Kleisouras Streets an Instagram-worthy destination.

The street is also home to several iconic landmarks, including the Hamza Bey Mosque, which dates back to 1467. The mosque's unique blend of Byzantine and Ottoman architectural elements adds to the street's cultural significance. Visitors can explore the surrounding area, including the nearby Kolomvou Archway, which serves as a leisure hub with cafes, bars, and restaurants.

Kleisouras Streets is an ideal spot for solo travelers, like you, to immerse themselves in Thessaloniki's local culture. The street's vibrant atmosphere, combined with its rich history, makes it an excellent place to experience the city's unique character. You'll find plenty of opportunities to interact with locals, try delicious food, and take in the stunning architecture.

As a budget-conscious traveler, you'll appreciate the affordable dining and shopping options available along Kleisouras Streets. The street's accessibility also makes it easy to navigate, with a flat and smooth surface that's perfect for strolling.

In summary, Kleisouras Streets is a must-visit destination in Thessaloniki's historic center. Its unique blend of architecture, cultural landmarks, and vibrant atmosphere make it an unforgettable experience for any traveler. Be sure to capture the street's Instagram-worthy moments, and don't hesitate to engage with the locals to make the most of your visit.
reference: Kleisouras Streets is located adjacent to the Court House square, known as Plateia Dikastirion, in the historic center. This area features small copper workshops that have been part of the local tradition since the Byzantine period, highlighting the street's historical significance and ongoing craftsmanship.

Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous

response:
The Roman Forum was the social and religious centre of Thessaloniki during ancient times. It was a 2-hectare area that was divided into three sections: cold, tepid and hot areas, with a vaulted tank for heating water. The forum was also home to several public buildings, shops, and houses, including the luxury houses of Epigenis and Evvoulos, decorated with exquisite mosaics. 

It was used for various purposes, including as a marketplace, a hub for trade and banking transactions, and a place of worship for the Roman emperors. The forum also housed several notable structures, such as the Monument of the Shields, a basilica, and the Forum Thermae. 

The Roman Forum was an important part of Thessaloniki's history and played a significant role in the city's development. It was gradually abandoned after the 7th century, but its legacy lives on in the form of the Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki, which features exhibits on the forum and its history. 

Visitors to the museum can learn more about the Roman Forum's history and significance, as well as see artifacts and relics from the site. The museum also hosts temporary exhibitions and events that celebrate the city's rich cultural heritage. 

Overall, the Roman Forum was a vibrant and bustling hub of activity in ancient Thessaloniki, and its legacy continues to captivate visitors to this day.
reference: During the Roman period, the Roman Forum was the social and religious centre of the city. It was constructed in two phases, completed in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, and was gradually abandoned after the 7th century.

ARCHAEOLOGICAL MUSEUM 
OF THESSALONIKI
Works of art of outstanding 
value and excavated ensembles 
from the entire region of 
Macedonia are on display, 
covering all the aspects of 
private and public life in the 
area, from the prehistoric era 
to the late antiquity period. 
Exhibits are organised in six 
basic categories:
• Towards the birth of towns. 
(ground floor, room 4). The 
evidence on display shows 
that there were settlements in 
Macedonia dating to the Iron 
Age, from 1100 to 700 BC.
• Macedonia from the 7th c.  
BC until Late Antiquity. 
(ground floor, room 5). Eight 
large theme sections cover 
various aspects of private 
and public life in Macedonia 
from the archaic years, when 
the independent Macedonian 
kingdom was created, until 
the 1st – 4th c. AD, when the 
entire region was a province 
of the Roman Empire. Finds 
come mainly from excavations 
carried out in areas of central 
Macedonia.
• Thessaloniki, Metropolis 
of Macedonia. (ground 
floor, room 6). Historical and 
archaeological information 
is presented, starting from 
315 BC when the town was 
founded. There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an 
archaic temple of Ionic order, 
whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of 
Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.', '82
Thessaloniki lies in the 
centre of a wide area that is 
extremely interesting from  
an archaeological, historical 
and natural point of view; 
there are countless options for 
outdoor activities, relaxing and 
entertainment. For instance, 
you can combine your stay 
in town with a day excursion 
to renowned archaeological 
sites and places of historical 
interest, to fascinating towns 
and great natural reserves  
or to areas offering recreation 
or relaxation.
1
	
ANCIENT PELLA
Inhabited since the Late 
Helladic period, the area 
flourished when Archelaos,  
the Macedon king, moved  
the capital of the Macedonian 
state from Aiges (Vergina) to 
Pella (late 5th – early 4th c. BC). 
The then seaside town grew 
larger during the reign of King 
Philip II (his son, Alexander 
the Great, was born here) 
and grew even larger later 
during the rule of Cassander. 
By the mid-2nd century BC it 
had evolved into the greatest 
political, financial and cultural 
centre among the Hellenic City 
States. In 168 BC when the 
Macedonians were defeated in 
the battle of Pydna, Pella was 
conquered by the Romans. 
It gradually declined and got 
eventually deserted in the 1st 
century BC. Among the finds 
of the greatest value are the 
exquisite mosaic floors in the 
buildings, which manifest the 
high standard of living enjoyed 
by the residents.

Thessaloniki is declared

Apostle Paul’s first visit

The town becomes  
the administrative centre  
of Macedonia; Byzantine 
emperor Theodosius builds

response:
Macedonia holds significant historical importance in relation to the Roman Forum, specifically during the Roman period. In the 1st century BC, Macedonia was a province of the Roman Empire, and the Roman Forum was an important center of administration and commerce. The Roman Empire expanded its territories through Macedonia, and the province played a crucial role in the empire's economic and cultural development.

The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, Greece, was an important hub for trade and commerce, and it was also a center for the Roman Empire's administrative and cultural activities. The forum was built during the 2nd century BC and was an important center for the Roman Empire's expansion into the region. The Roman Forum was also a major center for the Roman Empire's cultural and artistic achievements, and it was home to many notable figures, including the Roman Emperor Galerius Maximianus.

Macedonia's historical significance in relation to the Roman Forum is also evident in the archaeological findings in the region. Excavations have uncovered many artifacts and remains of ancient buildings, including the remains of the Roman Forum itself. These discoveries have provided valuable insights into the history of the Roman Empire and its impact on the region.

Visitors to the Roman Forum can see many of these historical artifacts and remains, including the reconstructed ancient buildings and the archaeological site of the Roman Forum itself. The site is also home to many other historical and cultural attractions, including the Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki, which houses many of the artifacts and remains discovered in the region.

Overall, Macedonia's historical significance in relation to the Roman Forum is a testament to the region's rich cultural and historical heritage, and it is an important part of Greece's history and identity.
reference: During the Roman period, Macedonia was home to a 2-hectare area that served as the social and religious center of the city, known as the Roman Forum. This site was constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and was gradually abandoned after the 7th century.

Parts of a colonnade, mosaic 
floors, marble stairs, a section 
of a stone-paved street, sewer

found in this archaeological 
site. The forum is also where

a two-storeyed colonnaded

which have survived. They are 
decorated with figures in relief 
in their interior as well as their 
exterior side (“Stoa of the 
Statuettes”).', '10
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.', '1.12 Galerius Arch (Kamara).
One of the town’s major 
landmarks, this arch is  
the usual rendezvous place  
for locals. It was built in 
295-305 AD followingthe 
incontestable victory of 
Galerius over the Persians  
and it was a monumental 
arch on the north side of his 
palatial complex (see p. 28). 
Its west section still stands 
and you can see embossed 
depictions of Galerius’ military 
successes. It is connected  
to Rotunda via a wide 
pedestrian way. Right next to it  
lies Panagia Dexia church 
(1950s), built on the location 
of a postbyzantine church. 
In it there is a rare icon of 
Panagia (Virgin Mary) holding 
little Jesus on her right side.
1.13 Rotunda.
(see p. 10)
1.14 Agios [Saint] 
Panteleimon
(see p. 11)
1.15 Plateia Syntrivaniou 
[Fountain Square].
It was named after the marble 
fountain with the obelisk, located 
36', '31
3rd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (2)
MUSEUM AREA
Greek Highschool (1893). 
9.2  The Transfiguration  
of Christ Church 
(see p. 10)
9.3  The Presentation  
of the Lord Church.
It was built in 1840, on the 
spot where a chapel had been 
constructed in 1543 dedicated 
to Saint Joel. Today only the 
chapel’s holy doors still remain, 
depicting the Annunciation 
(according to the Cretan 
School of Art). The church lies 
on the same level as Egnatia 
Street during the Byzantine 
times. The icon screen depicts 
the Annunciation and dates 
back to 1843; the five larger 
icons were crafted in 1943.
10 	\x07THESSALONIKI 
INTERNATIONAL  
FAIR (TIF)
It was inaugurated in 1926  
in nearby Pedio Areos; in 1940 
though, increasing needs led 
to its relocation in today’s  
facilities; in 1951 it assumed 
its activities after a break 
during the war. During the 
50’s and 60’s many pavilions 
were built, based on the 
commands of the modern 
times; they were planned 
by major Greek architects 
such as A. Konstantinidis, N. 
Valsamakis, I. Rizos, P. Tsolakis, 
D. Kapsampelis, A. Zannos 
etc.', '12
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Christian monuments in the 
Orthodox world. It is a cross-
domed basilica and used to 
be the Metropolitan Church 
(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian 
worship after 1912. The 
capitals date to the 5th – 6th 
c. (they were part of the older 
church); the wonderful mosaics 
are an absolute must-see, 
particularly the ones on the 
dome with the image of the 
Ascension of Christ, as are 
the murals crafted in different 
stages from the 8th to the 
11th c. In the church’s south 
side, amid green surroundings 
you will find the church of 
Agios Ioannis Prodromos [St. 
John the Forerunner] (1940); 
from this point you will enter 
the early-Christian baptistery 
(catacomb) of Agia Sofia, built 
on the ruins of roman baths.
5 	\x07TRANSFIGURATION OF 
THE SAVIOUR CHURCH 
[METAMORFOSI SOTIROS]
It is located on Egnatia Street 
(see p. 34) almost between 
Kamara (see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
Construction took place possibly 
around 1340 and it is a typical 
example of the transitional type 
in Byzantine church-building, 
found particularly in Macedonia.']

response: The Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is significant because it is part of the early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of Thessaloniki, which were declared World Heritage Monuments by UNESCO in 1988. The mural is believed to be from the 8th to 11th centuries, depicting the Annunciation, and is a rare example of Byzantine art. It is located in the Roman Forum, which was a major center of Christian worship during the Byzantine period. The mural is also a testament to the city's rich cultural heritage, showcasing the blending of Christian and pagan traditions. As a solo traveler, I would be interested in visiting this site to experience the city's history and culture firsthand. The fact that it is located in the Roman Forum makes it an ideal spot to explore and learn about Thessaloniki's past. I would likely take Instagram-worthy photos in front of the mural to share with friends and family, and would enjoy the sense of history and significance that comes with visiting this site. Overall, the Christian mural in the Roman Forum is a must-see destination for anyone interested in Thessaloniki's cultural heritage and history.
reference: The Christian mural uncovered in the Roman Forum is significant as it represents an early example of Christian art, highlighting the transition of the site from a social and religious center of the Roman period to one that incorporated Christian elements. This mural was found on one of the walls of the double underground Cryptoporticus, which was likely used as a public storehouse.

['90
DAY EXCURSIONS
Main street.
This wide stone-paved 
street used to cross the town 
in the north-south direction. 
The marketplace, shops, public 
buildings and houses flanked 
the street all along.
Great Thermae.
This complex of public bath 
houses covers a 4,000 m2 
area. The facilities were paved 
with marble and mosaic floors, 
there were Vespasian urinals, 
entertainment areas, a courtyard, 
shops, a hall for the worship 
of god Asklipios, and a roofed 
Odeon for cultural events.
The Houses of Zosa and 
Lida.
Located in the SE section 
of the town, the two houses 
used to be decorated with 
mosaic floors and sculpted 
busts.
Roman Forum.
It dates back to the late 2nd 
– early 3rd c. and comprises  
a slab-paved square surrounded  
by arcades and public buildings.  
In the West side there were 
the luxury houses of Epigenis 
and Evvoulos, decorated with 
exquisite mosaics; Sevasteio, 
a temple dedicated to 
the worship of the Roman 
emperors was situated in 
between the houses. In the 
East side, there is a roman 
basilica, an area for trade  
and banking transactions,  
the Monument of the Shields 
(with shield and cuirass 
depictions) and the Forum 
Thermae.
Polygonal building.', 'It is divided in 
three sections (cold, tepid 
and hot areas) and there is 
also a vaulted tank for heating 
water. It is widely known as the 
Paradise Baths and it went by 
that name until 1968. Right next 
to it there is a roman platform 
that is indicative of the ground 
level 2000 years ago.

this 2-hectare area used to be 
the social and religious centre 
of the city. Construction was

on the outside - contained  
a 12-side courtyard; it covered

there are relics of the town’s

The original church was  
a three-aisled basilica which 
was destroyed in the 4th c. and 
was rebuilt in the 5th c. with  
an added atrium and baptistery.
Praetorium.
The building comprised an 
inn for state officials (called 
praetorium) and an inn for 
common travellers (called 
tavernas). Visitors were able to 
use the Main Street Thermae 
(dating to the imperial Roman

Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki was a social and religious centre of the city during the Roman period. It was a 2-hectare area that covered the NW section of the archaeological site with a large rectangular square, and the S section of the square contained the largest part of the double underground Cryptoporticus, a public storehouse. The forum was also home to the Museum of the Roman Forum, which was built as an extension to the underground passageway. The forum was used for various activities such as trade, banking, and cultural events. The area was also home to several notable structures, including the Great Thermae, the Houses of Zosa and Lida, and the Odeon.

It's worth noting that the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki was not as prominent as the Roman Forum in Rome, but it still played an important role in the city's history. The forum was gradually abandoned after the 7th century, but its legacy can still be seen in the modern city. Today, visitors can explore the archaeological site and learn about its history through guided tours and exhibits.

Visitors to the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki can expect to see a range of impressive structures and artifacts, including the Cryptoporticus, the Museum of the Roman Forum, and the Odeon. The area is also home to several other archaeological sites, including the Great Thermae and the Houses of Zosa and Lida. With its rich history and cultural significance, the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in history, architecture, and culture.

It is on Iasonidou st., pretty

It is the best known Byzantine 
church of the town as Agios 
Dimitrios [St. Demetrius] is 
Thessaloniki’s patron saint. It 
was built during the 7th c. on 
the ruins of a 5th c. Basilica and 
in 1493 it was converted into

8 	\x07PALACE OF GALERIUS
It is an open-air archaeological 
museum located in the heart 
of town. Its construction  
began in the late 3rd – early  
4th c. by Galerius and is part  
of the Galerian Complex 
(area: 150,000 m2) which 
included the Hippodrome,  
the Arch or Kamara (see p.  
37) and Rotunda (see p. 10),

structures. Until its destruction

others). It is considered as one 
of the major monuments of 
the Late Antiquity, nationwide.

apsed anteroom and an

peristyle, part of which is the

display at the Archaeological 
Museum (see p. 70). 
8.2  Colonnaded yard.
There were rooms on

tessellated floors isolated 
the atrium from other 
constructions.']
reference_contexts: ["42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. The church is situated on the SE side of Acheiropoiitos church and is now a parish church. You can find it on the 1st page of the provided document.

As a budget-conscious traveler, you'll be pleased to know that visiting AG. ATHANASIOS is free, making it an excellent addition to your itinerary. Whether you're interested in history, architecture, or simply want to experience the local culture, AG. ATHANASIOS is a must-visit destination in Thessaloniki.

The Old Town has remained largely untouched since the 1917 great fire and features a mix of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements. The area has narrow alleys and scant squares, preserving its original town planning and architectural features.

['6
Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.
1.

the city, where

(Nikis Ave.) meets 
the new (eastern) 
waterfront area 
of Thessaloniki.

This particular atmosphere has

WHITE TOWER EXHIBITION
Starting from the year it was 
founded until the present day, 
the history of Thessaloniki is 
depicted through an array of

design compositions and 
archaeological material. The 
exhibition is organised in seven 
thematic categories, each one 
occupying one floor, as follows: 
Space and Time (ground floor), 
Transformations (1st floor),

floor), Homeland of the people 
(3rd floor), Along the trade 
routes (4th floor), Leisure and 
Culture (5th floor), Thessaloniki 
– Flavours (6th floor). The 
museum’s shop is located on 
the last floor.

an initiative of the Jewish 
Community of Thessaloniki  
to promote the Sephardic 
legacy in town, which dates  
as far back as the 15th c. It has 
been open to visitors since 
1997.', '18
link the town’s civic centre 
(Dikastirion Square, see p. 35) 
and Kassandrou Street with 
Aristotelous Square and the 
seafront. All along the street 
there are buildings the facades 
of which all follow specific 
architectural patterns with 
colonnades and arcades, and 
they house offices, bookshops, 
stores, hotels, state agencies, 
residencies etc. The junction of 
Aristotelous and Ermou Streets 
is the location of the church of 
Agia [Saint] Theodora (1937) 
built on an old monastery site 
now housing a community of 
monks; facing north you will 
see upper Aristotelous square.
1.2  Shopping streets
(see p. 27)
2 	NIKIS AVENUE
It starts at the harbour from 
the west and goes eastward 
to the White Tower (see p. 24) 
and it is known as Palia Paralia 
[Old Seafront]. The Turks 
opened it up in 1882, following 
an urban plan for modernising 
the city, after the seafront city 
walls were demolished. For 
many decades, traders and 
warships, fishing boats and 
yachts would dock along the 
wharf. Today, this is one of 
the top places in Thessaloniki, 
crossed daily by thousands of 
locals and visitors.', '96
Since Thessaloniki’s 
founding days and on account 
of its location, the town was 
always seen as a stopover 
place on the route used for 
East to West trading and vice 
versa. Today, the Thessaloniki 
town centre is the ideal 
destination for those who 
wish to add shopping to 
their travelling experience. 
The traditional roofed and 
open-air marketplaces are 
well known (see p. 21). You 
will find foodstuffs, spices, 
clothes, furniture and small 
objects in reasonable prices. 
Make a note of visiting Bit-
Pazar (see p. 36) the place 
where second-hand and 
antique dealers’ shops are  
to be found. 
The city’s modern 
commercial centre (see p. 27) 
is in the area encompassed by 
Aristotelous Street (see p. 15), 
the White Tower (see p. 24) 
and Tsimiski Street. You will 
find stylish clothing boutiques, 
department stores as well 
as decoration and fur shops. 
Visit also the Hirsch Building 
Mall (see p 20) and Plateia 
[Square] Mall (see p. 20). 
Other interesting shopping 
areas, for lower budgets, 
include Venizelou St. (see p. 
20), Egnatia St. (see p. 34) 
and Agiou Dimitriou St.  
(see p. 39).']
reference_contexts: ["42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town is a must-visit destination for anyone looking to experience the city's rich history and culture. The town has kept its original town planning, with narrow alleys and scant squares, despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades. Its multicultural history has been associated with great empires, including the Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule, and it has known many ethnic and religious groups, such as Jews, Latins, Armenians and others, as well as Greeks from Constantinople, Pontus and Asia Minor.

The Old Town is full of atmosphere, with its two- and three-storey houses bearing mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements. The area was conquered by the Ottomans in the mid-15th century, and many refugees settled there after 1922. Today, it's a hub for intellects, artists, and students who have chosen it for settlement in recent years.

You can explore the area's history through various monuments, such as the White Tower, which has been depicted through an array of multimedia applications, special structures, and archaeological material at the White Tower Exhibition. The Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki is also worth visiting, showcasing the Sephardic legacy in town, which dates back to the 15th century.

The Old Town is also a great place to experience the local culture, with its unique blend of architectural styles, narrow streets, and quaint shops. As a solo traveler, you'll find that the area is comfortable to navigate, and you can easily meet locals who are happy to share their knowledge and experiences with you. With its rich history, unique culture, and Instagram-worthy spots, Thessaloniki's Old Town is a must-visit destination for anyone looking to experience the city's best.
reference: Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere and covers the area between the city walls and Olympiados Street. It remained untouched by the 1917 great fire and was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century when the Ottomans conquered it for its fine climate and strategic position. The architecture features mixed Macedonian and Ottoman elements, with neoclassical and eclectic styles where the Dönmeh lived. After 1922, many refugees settled in the area, which has kept its original town planning with narrow alleys and scant squares, particularly in the west and east parts. This unique atmosphere has attracted artists and students in recent years.

It is on Iasonidou st., pretty 
close to Rotunda. According 
to certain scholars, this 
was the main church of 
the Monastery of Kyr Isaac 
or Theotokos Perivleptos, 
founded by Jacob, the 
Metropolitan Bishop of 
Thessaloniki (1295-1314). 
It is a tetrastyle cross-in-
square domed church with a 
surrounding portico ending 
to the east in two chapels. 
During the Turkish Occupation 
it was changed into a mosque 
under the name Ishakiye 
Camii (the mosque of Isaac). 
Remaining murals date to 
the 13th – 14th c. and depict 
saints and prelates as well  
the Virgin Mary.
8 	\x07
AGIOS DIMITRIOS 
CHURCH
It is the best known Byzantine 
church of the town as Agios 
Dimitrios [St. Demetrius] is 
Thessaloniki’s patron saint. It 
was built during the 7th c. on 
the ruins of a 5th c. Basilica and 
in 1493 it was converted into 
a mosque.']

response:
Agia Theodora is a church located in Thessaloniki's Old Town, and it's a significant historical site. According to the document, it was built on an old monastery site in 1937 and is now home to a community of monks. The church is situated near Aristotelous Square, which is mentioned in the document as a notable location. You can find it on Ermou Streets, which is also mentioned in the document as a shopping street.

The document provides some interesting historical context about the church, including its connection to the Ottoman occupation and the Turkish occupation. Moni Latomou [Latomou 
Monastery] has a huge

value, since it is an early type

period. There is a surviving

response: The Dönmeh were converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. They lived in Thessaloniki in residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs. These unique homes are notable for their blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements. The Dönmeh settled in the city after being chased out of European countries, particularly the Iberian Peninsula, in the 16th century. They played a significant role in Thessaloniki's history until the mid-20th century. The city's multicultural heritage is a testament to its long history of welcoming people from various backgrounds. The Dönmeh's presence is a fascinating aspect of Thessaloniki's cultural tapestry, and their homes are a remarkable example of the city's eclectic architecture. Visitors to Thessaloniki can explore these unique residences and gain insight into the city's rich history and cultural diversity.
reference: The Dönmeh were converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. They lived in residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs in Thessaloniki's Old Town.
