other name; there are also 
many cafés and bars. In the 
adjoining Melenikou st. you will 
see segments of the town’s 
eastern walls.
7 	\x07AGIOS PANTELEIMONAS 
CHURCH
It is on Iasonidou st., pretty 
close to Rotunda. According 
to certain scholars, this 
was the main church of 
the Monastery of Kyr Isaac 
or Theotokos Perivleptos, 
founded by Jacob, the 
Metropolitan Bishop of 
Thessaloniki (1295-1314). 
It is a tetrastyle cross-in-
square domed church with a 
surrounding portico ending 
to the east in two chapels. 
During the Turkish Occupation 
it was changed into a mosque 
under the name Ishakiye 
Camii (the mosque of Isaac). 
Remaining murals date to 
the 13th – 14th c. and depict 
saints and prelates as well  
the Virgin Mary.
8 	\x07
AGIOS DIMITRIOS 
CHURCH
It is the best known Byzantine 
church of the town as Agios 
Dimitrios [St. Demetrius] is 
Thessaloniki’s patron saint. It 
was built during the 7th c. on 
the ruins of a 5th c. Basilica and 
in 1493 it was converted into 
a mosque.', '77
MUSEUMS
collection includes works of art 
by leading Greek Artists; the 
Byzantine and Postbyzantine 
Icons collection is related to 
the school of Thessaloniki 
and spans 5 centuries (14th 
-19th c.); and a collection of 
360 pieces of art on Greek 
Engraving. Retrospective 
exhibitions of Greek and 
foreign artists are frequently 
arranged in collaboration with 
art foundations in Greece and 
abroad.
GALLERY OF THE 
SOCIETY FOR 
MACEDONIAN STUDIES
It is housed on the top floor 
of the Theatre Building of 
the S.M.S. and it is the first 
visual arts museum in the city. 
It encompasses 300 pieces 
of art (painting, sculpture 
and engraving) by famous 
Greek and foreign artists, 
mostly from northern Greece, 
who represent the major art 
movements of the 20th c.
CULTURAL CENTRE OF 
THESSALONIKI (NATIONAL 
BANK OF GREECE 
CULTURAL FOUNDATION)
It opened to the public in 
1989 and has, ever since,  
been organising major painting,  
sculpture, photography and 
architecture exhibitions in 
collaboration with other local 
educational and cultural 
agencies. Events related to  
the history of the city and  
the greater area also take  
place there. The collection 
includes approx. 250 pieces  
on painting, sculpture, pottery,  
mosaics, murals and 
engraving.', 'There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an 
archaic temple of Ionic order, 
whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of 
Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.
• The gold of Macedon. 
(ground floor, room 7). It 
includes exhibits of exceptional 
craftsmanship (e.x. diadems, 
crowns, rings, bracelets, 
earrings) removed mostly from 
cemeteries of the archaic and 
classical times; there is also  
a step by step depiction of the 
processing of noble metals. 
The museum owns a very large 
collection of gold crowns; 
particularly worthy of notice 
are also two singular items, the 
crater [type of vase-like vessel] 
and the papyrus of Derveni  
(4th c. BC).
• Field-House-Garden-
Grave. (in the museum’s 
MUSEUMS
79 & 80. 
The 
Archaeological 
Museum of

showcases 
unique 
finds from 
Macedonia, 
dating from 
prehistoric 
times to late 
antiquity.
81.  
The Museum 
of Byzantine 
Culture is 
considered to 
be one of the

museums

response:
The UNESCO World Heritage site of Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki represents the cultural heritage of the Byzantine Empire, specifically the early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town. These monuments showcase the unique blend of Christian and Byzantine art and architecture that was characteristic of the Byzantine Empire. The site includes notable buildings such as the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, the Byzantine museum, and the Rotunda, which demonstrate the city's rich cultural heritage.

The Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki date back to the 4th-15th centuries and are considered to be excellent specimens of Byzantine church-building and art. The site also reflects the city's multicultural history, having been influenced by various ethnic and religious groups, including Greeks from Constantinople, Pontus, and Asia Minor. The monuments have been recognized by UNESCO as World Heritage Monuments, acknowledging their significance in the cultural and artistic heritage of the Byzantine Empire.

Visitors to the site can expect to see a range of architectural styles, including the use of domes, cross-in-square domes, and tetrastyle cross-in-square domes. The site also features notable mosaics, frescoes, and icons that showcase the artistic and cultural achievements of the Byzantine Empire. The monuments are not only significant cultural heritage sites but also provide a unique glimpse into the history and culture of the Byzantine Empire.

Overall, the UNESCO World Heritage site of Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring the cultural heritage of the Byzantine Empire. The site offers a unique and enriching experience for visitors, providing a glimpse into the artistic, cultural, and historical achievements of the Byzantine Empire.
reference: The UNESCO World Heritage site of Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki represents a significant aspect of cultural heritage, showcasing early-Christian and Byzantine monuments that were constructed during the Byzantine period (4th – 15th century). These monuments reflect the city's historical importance as a center of Christianity and its architectural achievements, influencing the entire Byzantine world.

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\nMUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street, also known as the Old Railway Station, has a rich history dating back to 1894 when it was built near the harbour. The station was constructed in the neoclassical style and played a significant role in connecting Thessaloniki with other major cities in Greece, including Skopje, Belgrade, Monastir, and Constantinople (modern-day Istanbul). 

During World War II, the station was used as a cargo train station, and it was here that the German occupation forces mustered approximately 50,000 Jewish residents from March to August 1943, sending them by train to concentration camps. This tragic event serves as a somber reminder of the city's history and the importance of preserving its cultural heritage. 

Today, the Old Railway Station is no longer exclusively used for passenger traffic, but it remains an important transportation hub in Thessaloniki. It is still used for cargo trains and serves as a terminus for buses, including the Macedonia Intercity Bus Station, which offers services to regional areas and nearby islands such as Corfu and Crete. 

In terms of its significance to transportation in Thessaloniki, the Old Railway Station plays a crucial role in connecting the city to the rest of Greece and beyond. Its proximity to the harbour and the city centre makes it an ideal location for commuters and tourists alike. The station's history and architecture are a testament to the city's strategic importance as a major port and transportation hub. 

Visitors to the Old Railway Station can take a stroll along the adjacent Old Station Street, lined with cafes, bars, and restaurants, offering a glimpse into the city's vibrant commercial and social scene. Overall, the Old Railway Station is an essential part of Thessaloniki's transportation infrastructure and a poignant reminder of the city's complex history.
reference: The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street, which was later renamed Egnatia Street, began construction in 1939 and became fully operational in 1951. It plays a significant role in transportation in Thessaloniki, serving as a key hub for travelers and connecting various modes of transport. Additionally, the old steam engine located in front of the station highlights the historical significance of railway transportation in the city.

reference_contexts:
['<1-hop>

34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:', '<2-hop>

MUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
Egnatia Street has significant historical importance in Thessaloniki, dating back to the 2nd century BC when it was part of the Roman road connecting Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës, Albania) with Constantinople. Over time, it has evolved to become a central avenue in the city, with a busy shopping area and numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style.

Egnatia Street is connected to the Railway Station through Monastiriou Street, which is renamed at some point to Egnatia Street. The Railway Station was constructed in 1939 and became fully operational in 1951, with construction beginning in 1939 and it officially opened in 1951. The Railway Station is located near Dimokratias Square, where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street, and is also close to the University Campus of the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki.

The connection between Egnatia Street and the Railway Station is a result of the city's historical development. During the Interwar Period, a large part of the Railway Station was removed to make Egnatia Street wider, and it was restored to its original shape in 1977. Today, the Railway Station remains a significant landmark in Thessaloniki, and its proximity to Egnatia Street and Dimokratias Square makes it an important hub for transportation and tourism.

Visitors to Thessaloniki can explore the Railway Station and its connection to Egnatia Street, which offers a glimpse into the city's rich history and development. The area is also known for its historic sites, such as the Railway Station itself, and its proximity to other significant landmarks, such as the University Campus and the historic centre of the city. Overall, Egnatia Street is an essential part of Thessaloniki's historical significance, and its connection to the Railway Station is a testament to the city's growth and development over time.
reference: Egnatia Street is a central avenue in Thessaloniki that has been present since the city's founding, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC to connect Dyrrhachium with Constantinople. It is a bustling shopping area featuring important monuments and eclectic architecture. The Railway Station, located on Monastiriou Street, was renamed Egnatia Street at some point. Construction of the station began in 1939, and it became fully operational in 1951, highlighting the historical evolution of the area as a transportation hub.

to make Egnatia Street wider; 
it was restored to its original 
shape in 1977.

Campus in Greece (covering 
a 50 hectare area) to have 
been built following complete 
architectural plans. It was 
planned to be constructed 
on the location of the old 
Jewish cemetery (see p. 61), 
according to the Hébrard 
committee plan; construction 
finally began in 1938, yet the 
works were interrupted during 
the war and resumed in the 
1950s. Since then, several 
buildings were erected on 
these grounds by leading Greek 
architects following mostly the 
Modernist design, such as the 
main Administration Buildings 
as well as those built for the 
Schools of Chemistry, Law, 
Theology and Education and 
the two buildings of the Main 
Library; all the above form  
a major ensemble of modern 
architecture. Today there 
are over 100,000 enrolled 
students (the biggest campus 
in Greece) who add verve  
and youthfulness to the city.', '28

icons, church heritage items

This beautiful square, adorned 
with greenery, has been 
shaped after the 1890 fire  
and encompasses the grounds 
of Agia Sofia church (see p. 9) 
and sections of Ermou Street 
(up to Kar. Dil Street) as well 
as Agias Sofias Street (up to 
Egnatia Street). Agias Sofias 
St. is pedestrianised up to 
Tsimiski Street. Halfway the 
street there is a monument 
in memory of the Genocide of

several buildings around it 
are also very interesting, such

(the Red House) located at

Sofias streets, and the 1924 
Chatzidimitriou Building (at the

Streets meet). The square is 
also the location where Pavlou 
Mela and Iktinou (pedestrian

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\n34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
Egnatia Street is a central avenue in Thessaloniki, Greece, with a rich history dating back to the Roman era. It's a must-visit destination for any traveler, especially those interested in history and culture. 

As you walk down Egnatia Street, you'll find several important places that are worth exploring. First, there's the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. This historic mosque is a great example of Ottoman architecture and is definitely worth a visit.

Next, you'll find the Kolomvou Archway, located at the crossroads of Egnatia Street and Antigonidon Street. This archway is a great spot to take Instagram-worthy photos and is surrounded by cafes, bars, and restaurants.

Egnatia Street is also home to the Church of Mikri Panagia, also known as the Panagouda Church, which was built in 1818 and is a great example of neoclassical architecture. The church is located near the historic neoclassical building of the 28, which is now a museum.

As you continue down Egnatia Street, you'll find the historic centre of Thessaloniki, with its beautiful greenery and picturesque streets. This area is perfect for taking a leisurely stroll and enjoying the city's atmosphere.

Finally, Egnatia Street is also home to the University Campus of Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, which is a great example of modern architecture and is definitely worth a visit.

Overall, Egnatia Street is a must-visit destination in Thessaloniki, with its rich history, cultural significance, and stunning architecture. Whether you're interested in history, culture, or architecture, Egnatia Street has something for everyone.
reference: Egnatia Street is a central avenue in Thessaloniki that has been present since the city's founding, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC. It connects Dyrrhachium with Constantinople and is a busy shopping area featuring remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style from the early 20th century. Important places along Egnatia Street include Kolomvou Square, known for its bustling atmosphere and leisure spots, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is notable for its unique peristyle and ongoing renovation works.

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\nMUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street is a significant historical landmark in Thessaloniki, Greece, with a construction timeline that reflects the city's development in transportation. Construction began in 1939, and it became fully operational in 1951. This indicates that the railway station played a crucial role in connecting Thessaloniki with the rest of Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul during the mid-20th century.

Historically, the railway station was built in the neoclassical style, near the harbour, and was inaugurated in 1962. Its exterior side combines modern and classical elements with wings added on the sides, making it a notable architectural feature in the city. The station's primary function was to serve as a transportation hub, connecting Thessaloniki with other major cities in Greece and beyond.

The railway station's construction timeline is closely tied to the development of transportation in Thessaloniki. The city's growth and expansion during the 20th century led to an increased need for efficient transportation links. The railway station was designed to meet this demand, providing a vital connection between Thessaloniki and other major cities in the region.

Today, the railway station is exclusively used as a cargo train station, but its historical significance remains. It is a testament to Thessaloniki's rich history and its role as a major transportation hub. Visitors can still appreciate the station's neoclassical architecture and its significance in the city's development.

In summary, the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street is a historical landmark that played a crucial role in Thessaloniki's transportation development during the mid-20th century. Its construction timeline reflects the city's growth and expansion, and its neoclassical architecture remains an important part of Thessaloniki's cultural heritage.
reference: The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street, which was renamed Egnatia Street, holds historical significance as a key transportation hub in Thessaloniki. Construction of the station began in 1939, and it became fully operational in 1951, marking an important development in the city's transportation infrastructure. The station's establishment coincided with a period of modernization in Thessaloniki, enhancing connectivity and facilitating travel, which was crucial for the city's growth and development.

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\nMUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street, also known as the Old Railway Station, has a rich history dating back to 1939 when its construction began. It officially became operational in 1951 and served as a key transportation hub connecting Thessaloniki to other major cities in Greece, including Skopje, Belgrade, Monastir, and Constantinople (modern-day Istanbul). 

During World War II, the station played a significant role in the German occupation's efforts to deport approximately 50,000 Jewish residents from Thessaloniki to concentration camps between March and August 1943. Today, the station is primarily used as a cargo train station, a stark contrast to its former purpose as a major transportation hub.

The Old Railway Station is strategically located on Monastiriou Street, which is renamed Egnatia Street at some point. The station's proximity to the city centre and its connection to other parts of the city make it an essential stop for locals and tourists alike. Visitors can explore the station's historic architecture, learn about its past, and experience the city's rich history.

In terms of transportation in Thessaloniki, the Old Railway Station is a vital link between the city and other major cities in Greece. While it may not be as prominent as it once was, the station remains an important part of the city's transportation infrastructure, providing a convenient and accessible route for locals and visitors to travel throughout the region.

As a solo traveler, you'll find the Old Railway Station to be a fascinating and Instagram-worthy spot, offering a glimpse into Thessaloniki's rich history and cultural heritage. With its well-preserved architecture and poignant reminders of the past, the station is an unmissable destination for anyone interested in exploring the city's history and culture.
reference: The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street, which was renamed Egnatia Street, began construction in 1939 and became fully operational in 1951. It plays a significant role in transportation in Thessaloniki, serving as a key hub for travelers and connecting various modes of transport. Additionally, the old steam engine located in front of the station highlights its historical significance in the development of railway transportation in the region.

the two buildings of the Main 
Library; all the above form  
a major ensemble of modern 
architecture. Today there 
are over 100,000 enrolled 
students (the biggest campus 
in Greece) who add verve  
and youthfulness to the city.', '9 	THREE CHURCHES

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\n34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
Egnatia Street is a historically significant thoroughfare in Thessaloniki that dates back to the 2nd century BC, when it was part of the Roman road connecting Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës) to Constantinople. The street has been a central avenue in the city since its founding and has been a hub for shopping, commerce, and entertainment for centuries.

Along Egnatia Street, you can find several notable landmarks, including the Kolomvou Archway, which has become a leisure hub with cafes, bars, and restaurants inside. The Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, is also located on the street and is a significant historical site. The street is lined with impressive buildings of eclectic and art deco style, dating back to the early 20th century, including the Longos Building, also known as the Red House.

Egnatia Street is also significant due to its role in the city's Byzantine tradition and its connection to European interwar period motifs. The street is pedestrianized, making it a convenient and enjoyable area to explore. Visitors can stroll along the street, taking in the sights and sounds, and stopping at one of the many cafes or restaurants to rest and refuel.

For Instagrammable spots, Egnatia Street offers a unique and visually appealing backdrop, with its impressive architecture and historic significance. Visitors can capture photos of the street's landmarks, cafes, and restaurants, making for a great social media post.

In summary, Egnatia Street is a must-visit destination in Thessaloniki, offering a unique blend of history, culture, and entertainment. Its significance as a central avenue in the city, combined with its impressive landmarks and Instagrammable spots, make it a must-see destination for any traveler.
reference: Egnatia Street is historically significant as it has been a central avenue since the founding of Thessaloniki, originating from a Roman road constructed in the 2nd century BC that connected Dyrrhachium with Constantinople. Along this busy shopping area, notable landmarks include Kolomvou Square, which features the Kolomvou Archway, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, known for its unique peristyle and current renovation for an exhibition of archaeological finds.

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Kalamaria is a must-visit area for anyone looking to experience the authentic Thessaloniki. The area is known for its vibrant nightlife, offering a wide range of clubs and venues that cater to various tastes. You can enjoy the local marine sports club facilities, open-air cinemas, and marinas with amenities like power, water, and telephone services. For those seeking a more leisurely experience, there are plenty of cafes, restaurants, and shops along the main street, pedestrian-friendly and lined with local culture.

One of the best ways to experience Kalamaria is by visiting its central square, which houses the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ. You can also explore the nearby Aretsou-Krini beach and its facilities, including the marine sports club. Kalamaria is also a great place to explore the local markets, such as the Kapani (Vlali Marketplace) and Modiano Marketplace, offering a taste of traditional Greek culture.

Kalamaria is closely tied to the overall experience of visiting Thessaloniki, as it offers a unique blend of modern and traditional experiences. The area is easily accessible from the city center, making it an ideal place to explore on foot or by public transportation. Whether you're looking for a lively nightlife or a more relaxed atmosphere, Kalamaria has something for everyone.

When it comes to Instagrammable spots, Kalamaria is a treasure trove of photo opportunities. From the stunning views of the seafront to the vibrant nightlife, there's no shortage of unique and memorable moments to capture. And, as a solo traveler, you'll find that Kalamaria is a great place to meet locals, with plenty of opportunities to strike up conversations and make new friends.

In short, Kalamaria is an absolute must-visit when in Thessaloniki. Its unique blend of modern and traditional experiences, combined with its vibrant atmosphere and Instagrammable spots, make it the perfect place to explore and experience the authentic Thessaloniki.
reference: In Kalamaria, popular attractions include the seafront areas of Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a lively spot year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, which is pedestrian-only, offers shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located. This vibrant atmosphere in Kalamaria contributes to the overall experience of visiting Thessaloniki, as it provides a mix of leisure, dining, and cultural exploration, enhancing the travel experience in the region.

response:
The railway station is located on Monastiriou Street, which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street. Construction began in 1939, and it became fully operational in 1951. The station is primarily used for domestic and international timetables, with information available on the station's website. The station's history is closely tied to transportation in the area, as it was designed to connect Thessaloniki with the rest of Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul. Today, it serves as a cargo train station, but its legacy as a major transportation hub remains. The station's proximity to the city centre and its connections to regional areas make it an important transportation hub in the region. 

It's worth noting that the station has been used for various purposes throughout its history, including as a meeting point for the German occupation forces during World War II. In 1997, the station was renovated to celebrate Thessaloniki's designation as the European Capital of Culture, and it continues to be an important landmark in the city's transportation network. 

If you're looking for a unique and historic spot to explore, the railway station is definitely worth a visit. You can learn more about its history and significance through the station's website or by speaking with local authorities. The station's location on Egnatia Street makes it easily accessible from the city centre, and its proximity to other major transportation hubs, such as the port and bus stations, make it a convenient starting point for exploring the city.
reference: The railway station, located on Monastiriou Street, which was later renamed Egnatia Street, is a significant landmark. Construction of the station began in 1939, and it became fully operational in 1951. It is an important hub for transportation in the area, with historical significance highlighted by the old steam engine that stands in front of Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\nMUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
The railway station in Thessaloniki is a significant landmark and a hub for transportation in the area. Built in 1939 and fully operational by 1951, it replaced an older railway station that dated back to 1894. The new station was designed in the neoclassical style and features a striking exterior.

The station's history is closely tied to the city's development and growth. During World War II, the railway station played a crucial role in the German occupation's efforts to relocate Jewish residents. Approximately 50,000 people were transported from Thessaloniki to concentration camps via the station between March and August 1943.

Today, the railway station serves as a cargo train station, although it still holds historical significance. Visitors can explore the station's architecture and learn about its past. The station is also an important transportation hub, connecting Thessaloniki with other major cities in Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul.

For those traveling by bus, there is an intercity bus service available, operated by K.T.E.L. Buses depart from the Macedonia Intercity Bus Station, located about 5 km west of the city center. This service provides access to regional areas and major cities, including the islands of Corfu, Zante, and Crete.

Taxis are also readily available, with taximeters that calculate fares based on the distance traveled. The radio taxi service, «Taxiway», offers convenience and reliability.

Overall, the railway station in Thessaloniki is an essential part of the city's transportation network, offering a range of options for visitors to explore the area. Its history and significance make it a must-visit destination for those interested in learning about the city's past.
reference: The railway station, located on Monastiriou Street, which was later renamed Egnatia Street, is a significant landmark in Thessaloniki. Construction of the station began in 1939, and it became fully operational in 1951. It features an old steam engine in front, symbolizing its historical importance in transportation. The station serves as a crucial hub for travelers, connecting various regions and facilitating the movement of people and goods.

response:
The Railway Station in Thessaloniki is a historical landmark with significant importance in the city's history. Built in 1939, it began to take shape in 1951 and officially became fully operational that year. The station played a crucial role in connecting Thessaloniki with the rest of Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul, and it was also the bus terminus for most of the city areas. 

The station holds a poignant memory, as it was the location where the German occupation forces mustered about 50,000 Jewish residents in 1943, in order to send them to concentration camps. This dark period in history serves as a somber reminder of the city's complex past. 

Today, the Railway Station stands as a testament to Thessaloniki's rich history and its role in connecting the city to the wider world. Its neoclassical architecture and historical significance make it a must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring the city's cultural heritage. 

As a solo traveler, you'll likely be drawn to the station's unique character and its ability to evoke a sense of history and nostalgia. The station's proximity to other attractions, such as the Old Railway Station and the nearby streets, makes it an ideal starting point for your weekend getaway. 

Whether you're interested in history, architecture, or simply want to experience the city's vibrant atmosphere, the Railway Station in Thessaloniki is a must-visit destination. Its Instagram-worthy architecture and historical significance make it a perfect spot for capturing memorable moments on social media. 

In short, the Railway Station in Thessaloniki is a historical gem that offers a glimpse into the city's complex past and its role in connecting the world. As a solo traveler, you'll find it an engaging and memorable experience that will leave you with a deeper appreciation for the city's history and culture.
reference: The Railway Station in Thessaloniki, located on Monastiriou Street (later renamed Egnatia Street), began construction in 1939 and became fully operational in 1951. It is a must-see landmark, notable for its historical significance and the old steam engine that fronts the station.

The area west of Aristotelous 
street and south of Egnatia 
Street encompasses the 
town’s traditional market; it 
is dotted with small shops, 
malls and arcades, most of 
which date back to the time 
of the Turkish Occupation. 
Today, in these much visited 
marketplaces, you can find all 
kinds of products – food and 
spices, fabrics, jewellery, small 
boutiques and also tavernas, 
ouzo restaurants and coffee 
shops.
MUST SEE:
7.1  Modiano Market.
It was built in 1922 by 
engineer E. Modiano, and it is 
known as Modiano Market. It 
is a glass-roofed rectangular 
edifice containing 140 food 
shops inside its three arcades.']
reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\nMUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street in Thessaloniki has a significant historical importance, dating back to 1939 when its construction began. It officially became operational in 1951 and was designed to connect Thessaloniki with the rest of Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul. The station played a crucial role in the city's transportation development, serving as a major hub for both domestic and international routes. 

The station's significance extends beyond its functional role, as it was also the site of a tragic event during World War II. In 1943, the German occupation forces used the station as a muster point to transport approximately 50,000 Jewish residents to concentration camps. This dark period in history serves as a poignant reminder of the city's complex past and the importance of preserving its cultural heritage.

Today, the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street is a testament to Thessaloniki's rich history and its significance in the city's transportation network. Although it is now exclusively used as a cargo train station, it remains an important landmark and a symbol of the city's connection to the wider world. Visitors to the city can explore the station's architecture and learn about its history, gaining a deeper understanding of Thessaloniki's role in the region's transportation infrastructure.

As a solo traveler, you can easily reach the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street by using the city's public transportation system or by walking from nearby areas. The station is also easily accessible, with clear signage and directions available to help you navigate the area. With its rich history and cultural significance, the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street is an unmissable experience for anyone visiting Thessaloniki.
reference: The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street, which was later renamed Egnatia Street, holds historical significance as its construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951. This station is a key part of Thessaloniki's transportation development, symbolizing the city's connectivity and progress in the mid-20th century. Additionally, the presence of the old steam engine in front of the station highlights the historical evolution of transportation in the area.

response:
The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street is historically significant because it was built in 1939 and became fully operational in 1951. It was constructed in the neoclassical style and served as a major transportation hub, connecting Thessaloniki to the rest of Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul. The station played a crucial role in the city's development, particularly during World War II, when it was used to ship Jewish residents to concentration camps. The station's history is also marked by its use as a cargo train station today, which has preserved its original function and architectural style. 

Visitors can appreciate the station's significance by exploring its exterior, which features neoclassical elements, and learning about its role in the city's history. The station's proximity to other historical sites, such as the Vardariou Tower and the Old Railway Station, makes it an excellent starting point for exploring Thessaloniki's rich cultural heritage. Overall, the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in Thessaloniki's history and architecture. 

As a solo traveler, you can easily get to the station by walking from Dimokratias Square, which is just a short distance away. The station's location in the city centre also makes it easily accessible by public transportation. Visitors can take a guided tour or explore the station on their own, taking in the sights and sounds of this historic landmark. 

Whether you're an Instagram enthusiast or simply looking to immerse yourself in Thessaloniki's history, the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street is a must-visit destination that is sure to leave a lasting impression.

Additionally, it features the old steam engine fronting the station, which adds to its historical charm.

user_input: What cultural heritage significance do the UNESCO World Heritage Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki hold, and how does their history relate to the early Christian period?
retrieved_contexts:
['10
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.', '12
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Christian monuments in the 
Orthodox world. It is a cross-
domed basilica and used to 
be the Metropolitan Church 
(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian 
worship after 1912. The 
capitals date to the 5th – 6th 
c. (they were part of the older 
church); the wonderful mosaics 
are an absolute must-see, 
particularly the ones on the 
dome with the image of the 
Ascension of Christ, as are 
the murals crafted in different 
stages from the 8th to the 
11th c. In the church’s south 
side, amid green surroundings 
you will find the church of 
Agios Ioannis Prodromos [St. 
John the Forerunner] (1940); 
from this point you will enter 
the early-Christian baptistery 
(catacomb) of Agia Sofia, built 
on the ruins of roman baths.
5 	\x07TRANSFIGURATION OF 
THE SAVIOUR CHURCH 
[METAMORFOSI SOTIROS]
It is located on Egnatia Street 
(see p. 34) almost between 
Kamara (see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
Construction took place possibly 
around 1340 and it is a typical 
example of the transitional type 
in Byzantine church-building, 
found particularly in Macedonia.', '6
Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.
1. 
The White Tower 
area is one of the 
busiest parts of 
the city, where 
the old seafront 
(Nikis Ave.) meets 
the new (eastern) 
waterfront area 
of Thessaloniki.
DION – VERGINA – ANCIENT PELLA
PETRALONA CAVE – LAKES AREA
THESSALONIKI', '13
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
other name; there are also 
many cafés and bars. In the 
adjoining Melenikou st. you will 
see segments of the town’s 
eastern walls.
7 	\x07AGIOS PANTELEIMONAS 
CHURCH
It is on Iasonidou st., pretty 
close to Rotunda. According 
to certain scholars, this 
was the main church of 
the Monastery of Kyr Isaac 
or Theotokos Perivleptos, 
founded by Jacob, the 
Metropolitan Bishop of 
Thessaloniki (1295-1314). 
It is a tetrastyle cross-in-
square domed church with a 
surrounding portico ending 
to the east in two chapels. 
During the Turkish Occupation 
it was changed into a mosque 
under the name Ishakiye 
Camii (the mosque of Isaac). 
Remaining murals date to 
the 13th – 14th c. and depict 
saints and prelates as well  
the Virgin Mary.
8 	\x07
AGIOS DIMITRIOS 
CHURCH
It is the best known Byzantine 
church of the town as Agios 
Dimitrios [St. Demetrius] is 
Thessaloniki’s patron saint. It 
was built during the 7th c. on 
the ruins of a 5th c. Basilica and 
in 1493 it was converted into 
a mosque.', '16
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
14	\x07AGIOS NIKOLAOS 
[SAINT NICHOLAS] 
ORPHANOS CHURCH
It was built in the 1310s,  
as a dependency of Vlatadon 
Monastery and it served as a 
monastery main church. Within 
the same grounds there used 
to be an orphanage at earlier 
times – hence the name 
“Orphanos” [meaning Orphan]. 
It is an aisleless timber-roofed 
church sided by an ambulatory 
forming the shape “Π”.  
The 14th c. murals inside are 
true masterpieces depicting 
scenes of Dodekaorto [the 
Twelve major religious feasts  
of the year], of the Passion  
of Christ, the Resurrection and 
the Liturgical Cycle as well as 
figures of saints; the monument 
is considered as one of the 
best preserved in Thessaloniki. 
It is surrounded by lush and 
serene gardens.
15	CITY WALLS
Thessaloniki was walled 
immediately after it was 
founded by Cassander; in 
390 AD a series of large-
scale changes took place by 
Theodosius I. In the Byzantine 
times a harbour was constructed 
(in the SW part) and the 
Acropolis wall was raised (see 
p. 44). During the Venetian Rule 
(1st half of the 15th c.)']

response:
The UNESCO World Heritage Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki hold significant cultural heritage value, showcasing the city's rich history and its importance as a hub of early Christianity. The monuments date back to the 4th-15th centuries and feature a mix of Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman architectural styles, reflecting the city's multicultural history.

The Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki are particularly significant due to their association with the Apostle Paul, who is said to have preached in the city. The monuments also demonstrate the city's status as a co-reigning city with Constantinople during the Byzantine period. The UNESCO World Heritage designation recognizes the monuments' importance in the Byzantine world and their influence on the entire Christian world.

The early Christian period is deeply intertwined with the Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki. The monuments feature early-Christian and Byzantine monuments, including the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, which dates back to the 13th century and features a unique cross-in-square domed church design. The church is a testament to the city's Christian heritage and its importance as a center of early Christianity.

Other notable monuments include the Agios Pantheleimonas Church, the Rotunda, and the Agios Nikolaos Orphanos Church, which feature impressive murals and architectural designs that reflect the city's Byzantine heritage. The monuments also demonstrate the city's multicultural history, with influences from Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman architectural styles.

Overall, the UNESCO World Heritage Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki hold significant cultural heritage value, offering a glimpse into the city's rich history and its importance as a hub of early Christianity. The monuments are a must-visit for anyone interested in history, architecture, and culture, and they provide a unique perspective on the early Christian period and its significance in the Byzantine world.
reference: The UNESCO World Heritage Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki are significant as they represent some of the earliest examples of Christian architecture and art, constructed during the Byzantine period when Thessaloniki was a major city of the empire. These monuments, built between the 4th and 15th centuries, reflect a diachronic typology that has had a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. Their historical importance is underscored by the fact that Thessaloniki was one of the first towns to embrace Christianity, as introduced by the Apostle Paul, making these monuments not only architectural treasures but also vital components of the cultural heritage that narrates the city's early Christian history.

['<1-hop>

34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:', '<2-hop>

MUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
Egnatia Street is a central avenue with a rich history, dating back to the 2nd century BC when it was part of the Roman road network connecting Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern-day Albania) with Constantinople. The street has been a significant transportation hub and commercial center in Thessaloniki since its founding. 

The connection between Egnatia Street and the Railway Station is deeply rooted in the city's history. The Railway Station, built in 1939 and completed in 1951, is situated on Egnatia Street, which was renamed from Monastiriou Street at some point. The station's construction was interrupted during World War II, but it became fully operational in the 1950s. Today, the Railway Station is a major landmark and a significant transportation hub in Thessaloniki.

The intersection of Egnatia Street and the Railway Station is also notable for the Kolomvou Archway, a leisure hub with cafes, bars, and restaurants. This area is bustling and offers a glimpse into the city's vibrant culture. 

Historically, the area has played a crucial role in the city's development, with the Railway Station serving as a major gateway to the city and connecting Thessaloniki to the rest of Greece and Europe. The street's connection to the station has facilitated the growth of the city's commercial and cultural centers.

Visitors to Thessaloniki can explore the Railway Station and its surroundings, taking in the city's rich history and cultural heritage. The area is also a great spot for Instagram-worthy moments, with the station's modern architecture and the street's historic charm providing a unique backdrop for photos. Overall, Egnatia Street and the Railway Station offer a fascinating glimpse into Thessaloniki's history and culture, making them must-visit attractions for anyone exploring the city.
reference: Egnatia Street is a central avenue in Thessaloniki that has been in existence since the city's founding, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC. It served as a vital connection between Dyrrhachium and Constantinople. The street is notable for its eclectic and art deco buildings, as well as important monuments. The Railway Station, located on Monastiriou Street, was renamed Egnatia Street at some point. Construction of the station began in 1939, and it became fully operational in 1951. This connection highlights the historical importance of Egnatia Street as a major thoroughfare in Thessaloniki's urban landscape.

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\nMUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
The railway station in Thessaloniki is a significant transportation hub that connects the city to the rest of Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul. The station has a long history, with construction beginning in 1939 and becoming fully operational in 1951. It was officially opened in 1951. Initially, it was used for both domestic and international passenger trains. Today, it is primarily used for cargo trains. The station was also the location of the German occupation forces' muster of approximately 50,000 Jewish residents in 1943, who were sent to concentration camps.

The railway station is situated on Monastiriou Street, which is renamed at some point to Egnatia Street. The station is a key transportation link between the city centre and the surrounding suburbs. It serves as a terminus for buses and taxis, connecting Thessaloniki with regional areas and the islands of Corfu, Zante, and Crete. The station is also an important stop for intercity buses, with services to major cities like Skopje and Belgrade.

The station has undergone renovations and expansions over the years, with modern facilities and infrastructure. The current building is a neoclassical structure, reflecting the city's architectural heritage. The station's exterior side combines modern and classical elements, with wings added on the sides.

Visitors to the station can find information on domestic and international timetables, as well as details on intercity bus services. The station is also a good starting point for exploring the city's historic sites and landmarks, including the nearby Old Railway Station and the nearby Stavros Port Station.

In summary, the railway station in Thessaloniki is a vital transportation hub that has played a significant role in the city's history and development. It continues to serve as a key connection point for locals and tourists alike, with easy access to the surrounding suburbs and regional areas.
reference: The railway station, located on Monastiriou Street, which was later renamed Egnatia Street, is a significant landmark. Construction of the station began in 1939, and it became fully operational in 1951. It is an important hub for transportation in the area, with the old steam engine in front of the station serving as a historical reminder of the railway's past in Thessaloniki.

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\n34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
Egnatia Street is a significant historical landmark in Thessaloniki, dating back to the 2nd century BC when it was part of the Roman road connecting Dyrrhachium (Durrës, Albania) with Constantinople. The street has been a central avenue in the city since its founding, and its current layout is a result of the Hébrard plan, which included the creation of a historic center and pedestrianized zones.

Along Egnatia Street, you can find several notable landmarks, including the Kolomvou Archway, the Hamza Bey Mosque, and the historic buildings such as the Electra Palace hotel and the Olympion building. The street is also home to the TIF grounds, the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, and the Red House (Longos Building). These landmarks showcase the city's rich history, architecture, and cultural heritage.

The street's significance extends beyond its historical value, as it has played a crucial role in the city's development and growth. In the 20th century, Egnatia Street underwent significant changes, including the removal of a large part of the historic structure to make the street wider, and its restoration in 1977.

Visitors to Egnatia Street can expect to experience a mix of modern and historic architecture, as well as a blend of European and Byzantine influences. The street is also a hub for shopping, dining, and entertainment, with numerous cafes, bars, and restaurants along its length.

For Instagrammable spots, Egnatia Street is a must-visit, with its unique blend of old and new architecture, picturesque alleys, and vibrant street life. Visitors can also expect to encounter friendly locals, many of whom speak English, making it easy to interact with the community and learn about the city's history and culture.

Overall, Egnatia Street is a must-visit destination in Thessaloniki, offering a unique blend of history, culture, and entertainment that is sure to delight visitors of all ages.
reference: Egnatia Street is historically significant as it has been a central avenue since Thessaloniki’s founding, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC to connect Dyrrhachium with Constantinople. Along this busy shopping area, notable landmarks include Kolomvou Square, which features the Kolomvou Archway, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467. The mosque is unique as it is the only one in Greece with a peristyle and has undergone renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds.

response:
The Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki have been recognized as UNESCO World Heritage status, marking their significance in the cultural heritage of the Byzantine period. This status acknowledges the unique and exceptional value of these monuments, which are considered to be excellent specimens of Byzantine church-building and art. 

These monuments are a testament to the rich cultural legacy of the Byzantine Empire, showcasing its distinctive architectural and artistic styles. The UNESCO World Heritage designation underscores the importance of preserving these historical sites for future generations. 

The Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki are a reflection of the city's long history, having been an important center of Christianity and Byzantine rule. The city's multicultural heritage is evident in the various ethnic and religious groups that have shaped its development, including Greeks from Constantinople, Pontus, and Asia Minor. 

The monuments feature a range of architectural styles, including the iconic Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I in the 14th century. The museum of Byzantine culture, established in 1989, houses an impressive collection of artifacts and exhibits, providing insight into the Byzantine Empire's art, architecture, and culture. 

The UNESCO World Heritage status of the Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki is a celebration of the city's cultural heritage and a testament to its enduring legacy. Visitors can experience the unique charm of these monuments firsthand, offering a glimpse into the Byzantine period's rich cultural tapestry. 

As a solo traveler, you can explore these monuments on your own, taking in the stunning architecture and historical significance. With its rich cultural heritage, Thessaloniki is an ideal destination for anyone interested in history, architecture, and culture. Whether you're an art lover or a history buff, the Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki are sure to leave a lasting impression.
reference: The UNESCO World Heritage status of the Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki signifies their outstanding universal value and importance in representing the cultural heritage of the Byzantine period. These monuments, constructed between the 4th and 15th centuries, showcase a diachronic typology of Christian architecture and art that had a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The early-Christian and Byzantine monuments, such as the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, are considered excellent specimens of Byzantine church-building, reflecting the rich cultural heritage and historical significance of Thessaloniki as a major city during the Byzantine Empire.

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\nMUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
The Railway Station in Thessaloniki has a rich history dating back to 1939, when its construction began. It was officially opened in 1951, becoming fully operational shortly after. The station was built in the neoclassical style and played a significant role in connecting Thessaloniki with the rest of Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul. It was also an important hub for trade and commerce, with cargo trains operating from the station. One of the most notable events in the station's history is the period during World War II, when the German occupation forces used the station to muster and transport approximately 50,000 Jewish residents to concentration camps. Today, the Railway Station remains a significant landmark in Thessaloniki, and its history serves as a poignant reminder of the city's complex past. Visitors can still see the station's impressive architecture and learn more about its fascinating history through guided tours. 

It's worth noting that the station is now primarily used as a cargo train station, and it has been renovated and restored to its original grandeur. The station's exterior side combines modern and classical elements, making it a visually striking and Instagram-worthy spot. Visitors can also explore the nearby Old Station Street, which features a mix of old and new buildings, adding to the station's charm. Overall, the Railway Station in Thessaloniki is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in history, architecture, and culture.
reference: The Railway Station in Thessaloniki, located on Monastiriou Street (which was renamed Egnatia Street), began construction in 1939 and became fully operational in 1951. Additionally, it features the Old steam engine fronting the station, which adds to its historical significance.

BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
Egnatia Street is a historically significant street in Thessaloniki, Greece, dating back to the 2nd century BC when it was constructed by the Romans to connect Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern-day Albania) with Constantinople. Over the centuries, the street has been shaped by various cultures, including the Byzantine and European influences of the Interwar Period.

Notable landmarks along Egnatia Street include the Kolomvou Archway, Hamza Bey Mosque, and the iconic Electra Palace hotel, which was built by the GNTO architects in the late 1960s. The street is also home to the monumental style of architecture, with buildings like the Olympion and the Red House (Longos Building) showcasing a blend of Byzantine and European influences.

Egnatia Street is a bustling shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings, many of which date back to the early 20th century. The street's historic centre is also where you'll find the TIF grounds and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, which is the first University Campus in Greece to have been built following complete architectural plans.

Visitors can explore the street's rich history by visiting these landmarks, which offer a glimpse into Thessaloniki's fascinating past. The street's vibrant atmosphere and eclectic mix of architecture make it an Instagram-worthy destination, perfect for solo travelers and photography enthusiasts.

As a budget-conscious traveler, you can find affordable accommodations and dining options along Egnatia Street, making it an ideal destination for a weekend getaway. With its comfortable layout and accessibility, Egnatia Street is an excellent choice for solo travelers seeking familiar experiences and a dose of local culture.
reference: Egnatia Street is historically significant as it has been a central avenue since the founding of Thessaloniki, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC to connect Dyrrhachium with Constantinople. Along this busy shopping area, notable landmarks include Kolomvou Square, which features the Kolomvou Archway, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467. The mosque is unique as it is the only one in Greece with a peristyle and has undergone renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds.

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\nMUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street in Thessaloniki is a historical landmark with a significant connection to the city's transportation development. Construction began in 1939, and it became fully operational in 1951. The station was officially inaugurated in 1962, marking a major milestone in Thessaloniki's transportation infrastructure. Its exterior side combines modern and classical elements, and it connects the city to the rest of Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul.

Historically, the Railway Station played a crucial role in the city's transportation network, connecting Thessaloniki with Skopje, Belgrade, Monastir, and Constantinople (modern-day Istanbul). Today, the station is primarily used as a cargo train station, but it remains an important landmark in the city's history.

The station's significance extends beyond its functional role, as it has been the site of significant events in the city's past. For example, during World War II, the German occupation forces mustered about 50,000 Jewish residents at the station, preparing to send them to concentration camps. This dark chapter in the city's history serves as a poignant reminder of the importance of preserving historical sites and promoting tolerance and understanding.

In terms of transportation development, the Railway Station has played a key role in shaping the city's connectivity to the wider region. The station's construction and inauguration marked a significant turning point in Thessaloniki's transportation infrastructure, paving the way for the development of the city's transportation network.

Overall, the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street is a significant historical landmark that holds a special place in Thessaloniki's history and transportation development. Its legacy serves as a reminder of the city's complex past and its importance as a hub for transportation and connectivity in the region.
reference: The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street, which was later renamed Egnatia Street, holds historical significance as its construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951. This station is a key part of Thessaloniki's transportation development, symbolizing the city's connectivity and progress in the mid-20th century. Additionally, the presence of the old steam engine in front of the station highlights the historical evolution of transportation in the area.

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\n34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
Egnatia Street holds significant historical importance in Thessaloniki, dating back to the 2nd century BC when it was constructed by the Romans as a major thoroughfare connecting Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës, Albania) with Constantinople. Over the centuries, the street has played a vital role in the city's development, serving as a hub for commerce, culture, and entertainment.

Along Egnatia Street, you'll find numerous notable landmarks, including the Kolomvou Archway, a leisure hub with cafes, bars, and restaurants; the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II; and the iconic Electra Palace hotel, constructed in the late 1960s and designed by GNTO architects. The street is also home to the historic Aristotelous Street, which has been pedestrianized and features several notable buildings, including the Olympion hotel, designed by J. Moshé.

As you stroll along Egnatia Street, you'll notice a mix of eclectic and art deco architecture, reflecting the city's rich cultural heritage. The street is lined with shops, cafes, and restaurants, offering a glimpse into Thessaloniki's vibrant atmosphere. Be sure to stop by the 1925 Longos Building, also known as the Red House, located at the corner of Ermou and Agias Sofias streets, and the 1924 Chatzidimitriou Building, situated at the point where Ermou and Kar. Dil Streets meet.

Egnatia Street is an excellent starting point for your exploration of Thessaloniki, offering a unique blend of history, culture, and entertainment. With its picturesque atmosphere and Instagram-worthy landmarks, this street is sure to leave a lasting impression on your solo travels. As you wander along Egnatia Street, take in the sights, sounds, and flavors of this incredible city, and don't hesitate to interact with the friendly locals who will make your experience truly unforgettable.
reference: Egnatia Street is historically significant as it has been a central avenue since the founding of Thessaloniki, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC. It connected Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës, Albania) with Constantinople. Along this busy shopping area, notable landmarks include Kolomvou Square, which features the Kolomvou Archway, a leisure hub with cafés and restaurants, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is unique for its peristyle and currently undergoing renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds.

1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.', '6
Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

Starting from the year it was
