reference_contexts: ["<1-hop>\n\nUNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. response:
The UNESCO World Heritage sites in Thessaloniki that reflect its cultural heritage, particularly during the Byzantine period, are the Byzantine Monuments. These monuments date back to the Byzantine period and showcase the city's rich cultural heritage, including early-Christian and Byzantine churches, such as the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Agios Panateleimonas Church. The Byzantine Monuments are a testament to Thessaloniki's significant role in the Byzantine Empire and its importance as a center of Christianity during that time.

Another notable UNESCO World Heritage site is the White Tower, which is a six-storey round tower built in the late 15th century. Although not exclusively a Byzantine site, it has been influenced by Byzantine architecture and has played a significant role in the city's cultural heritage. The White Tower has been surrounded by fortifications until the early 20th century and has been the subject of various exhibitions, including the White Tower Exhibition, which showcases the history of Thessaloniki from its founding to the present day.

These UNESCO World Heritage sites are a must-visit for anyone interested in Thessaloniki's cultural heritage, particularly during the Byzantine period. They offer a glimpse into the city's rich history and its significance as a center of Christianity during that time. Visitors can explore these monuments and learn about their significance, making for a memorable and enriching experience.

In addition to these UNESCO World Heritage sites, Thessaloniki has a wealth of other historical and cultural attractions to explore, including the Archaeological Museum and the Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki. These museums offer a deeper understanding of the city's history and culture, and are definitely worth a visit. Overall, Thessaloniki's UNESCO World Heritage sites are a treasure trove of cultural and historical significance, reflecting the city's rich heritage and its importance in the Byzantine Empire.
reference: Thessaloniki is home to several UNESCO World Heritage sites that reflect its rich cultural heritage, particularly from the Byzantine period. The city was one of the first to embrace Christianity, and during the Byzantine era, it became the second most important city of the empire after Constantinople. Notable monuments include the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built between 1310 and 1314, which served as the main church of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos. These early-Christian and Byzantine monuments are considered excellent specimens of Byzantine church-building and art, leading to their designation as World Heritage Monuments by UNESCO in 1988.

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\nMUST SEE: 2.1 Railway Station. It is on Monastiriou Street which is renamed at some point Egnatia Street (see p. 34). Construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951, but it was officially 66. Vardariou Tower (Top Hane). 67. Old steam engine fronting Thessaloniki’s Railway Station.']
response:
The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street in Thessaloniki has significant historical importance as it was built in 1939 and became fully operational in 1951. This station played a crucial role in connecting Thessaloniki with the rest of Greece, the Balkans, and Istanbul. It was also the terminus for many buses, including the iconic Macedonian Intercity Bus Service, which connects the city to regional areas and the islands of Corfu, Zante, and Crete. The station's neoclassical architecture and modern wings make it an impressive landmark in the city.

Historically, the Railway Station was an important transportation hub, especially during the German occupation of World War II. In 1943, the station was used to muster around 50,000 Jewish residents, who were then sent to concentration camps by train. This dark period in history serves as a poignant reminder of the city's complex past.

Today, the Railway Station remains a vital transportation infrastructure in Thessaloniki, serving as a key point for domestic and international travel. Its location on Monastiriou Street makes it easily accessible for visitors, who can also explore the surrounding area, including the nearby Stavros Port Station and the bustling Giannitson Street.

As a solo traveler seeking familiar experiences, you'll appreciate the Railway Station's blend of history and modernity. The station's exterior side combines modern and classical elements, making it an Instagram-worthy spot. You can easily take a taxi or bus from the station to explore the city, and its proximity to other attractions, such as the city centre and the waterfront, makes it an ideal starting point for your weekend getaway.

Overall, the Railway Station on Monastiriou Street is a must-visit destination in Thessaloniki, offering a glimpse into the city's rich history and transportation infrastructure. Its significance extends beyond its functional role, as it represents the city's connection to its past, present, and future.
reference: The Railway Station on Monastiriou Street, which was renamed Egnatia Street, holds historical significance as its construction began in 1939 and it became fully operational in 1951. This station is a key part of Thessaloniki's transportation infrastructure, symbolizing the city's connectivity and development in the mid-20th century. Additionally, it features an old steam engine in front, which adds to its historical charm and reflects the evolution of transportation in the region.

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\n34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
Egnatia Street is a historical and culturally significant street in Thessaloniki, Greece, with roots dating back to the 2nd century BC when it was part of the Roman Empire's road connecting Dyrrhachium (Durrës, Albania) and Constantinople. The street has been a central avenue in the city since its founding and has played a significant role in the city's development. Today, it is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style, dating back to the early 20th century.

Along Egnatia Street, notable sites can be found in the historic centre, including:

*   Kolomvou Square, a bustling crossroads with cafes, bars, and restaurants.
*   Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, a military commander of Sultan Murad II.
*   The monumental style of architecture is showcased in the buildings' facades, colonnades, arcades, and porticos, combining elements from the city's Byzantine tradition with European interwar period motifs.
*   The square is also home to the seat of the Thessaloniki Film Festival and the 1925 Longos Building (the Red House).
*   The historic centre is also marked by the Church of Mikri Panagia, also known as the Panagouda Church, and the Monastery of Panagia Gorgoepikoos.

Visitors can experience the city's rich history and culture by exploring these sites and taking in the vibrant atmosphere of Egnatia Street. The street's eclectic mix of old and new, combined with its stunning architecture, makes it an Instagram-worthy destination. With its central location and abundance of cafes, bars, and restaurants, Egnatia Street is the perfect place for a leisurely weekend getaway. As a solo traveler, you can easily meet locals and soak up the city's atmosphere, making it an ideal destination for your first-time visit to Thessaloniki.
reference: Egnatia Street is historically significant as it has been a central avenue since the founding of Thessaloniki, being part of the Roman road constructed in the 2nd century BC that connected Dyrrhachium with Constantinople. This street splits the town’s historic centre and is a busy shopping area featuring remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style from the early 20th century. Notable sites along Egnatia Street include Kolomvou Square, a bustling crossroads with cafés and restaurants, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle. The mosque is currently undergoing renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds.

reference_contexts: ['<1-hop>\n\n34 1 EGNATIA STREET This central avenue has been there practically since Thessaloniki’s founding, as it is a section of the road constructed by the Romans in the 2nd c. BC, and connected Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in modern day Albania) with Constantinople. It starts at Dimokratia square (see p. 58) and ends at the TIF grounds (see p. 31) and the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, splitting in two the town’s historic centre. It is a busy shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style dating to the early 20th c. (mostly old hotels) that are absolutely worth observing, as well as some of the city’s most important monuments. MUST SEE: 1.1 Kolomvou Square. The crossroads where Egnatia Street meets Antigonidon Street is indeed a bustling one! It was named after G. Colombo, an Italian who opened a hotel there in the early 20th century. This is the location of Kolomvou Archway (31, Egnatia St.) which has become a leisure hub with cafés, bars and restaurants inside. 1.2 Hamza Bey Mosque. It was built in 1467 by the daughter of Hamza Bey, the military commander of Sultan Murad II. It is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle (a colonnaded yard). For many decades it housed a cinema named Alkazar. Currently there are renovation works under way. Once they are finished, it will house an exhibition of finds unearthed during the metro excavations. Right behind it you will see the City Manor which housed the Town Hall until recently. It is known at Karavan Serai as there used to be an ottoman inn here. (early 16th c.). 4th walk:']
response:
Egnatia Street in Thessaloniki is a central avenue with a rich history dating back to the 2nd century BC, when it was constructed by the Romans as a section of the road connecting Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës, Albania) with Constantinople. Over time, it has been shaped by various cultures, including the Byzantine and European influences of the Interwar Period.

Some must-see places along Egnatia Street include:

* The Panagouda Church (also known as the Church of Mikri Panagia), a historic church built in 1818 that was once the location of the Monastery of Panagia Gorgoepikoos.
* The Longos Building (also known as the Red House), a 1925 building that is now a hotel and is a great spot for Instagram-worthy photos.
* The Agias Sofia Square, a beautiful square adorned with greenery that features the iconic Agia Sofia church and several interesting buildings, including the 1924 Chatzidimitriou Building.
* The Aristotelous Street, a pedestrianized historic boulevard that ends in Egnatia Street and is lined with interesting buildings and cafes.
* The Thessaloniki Film Festival venue, located in the Olympion building, which is a great spot to catch a film or take in the views.

Egnatia Street is a bustling shopping area with numerous remarkable buildings of eclectic and art deco style, dating back to the early 20th century. It is a must-visit destination for anyone looking to experience the history and culture of Thessaloniki. As a solo traveler, you'll appreciate the opportunity to explore the street on your own and take in the sights and sounds of the city. With its rich history and stunning architecture, Egnatia Street is a truly unforgettable experience.
reference: Egnatia Street is a central avenue in Thessaloniki that has been present since the city's founding, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC. It connected Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës in Albania) with Constantinople. The street starts at Dimokratia Square and ends at the TIF grounds and Aristotle University, dividing the historic center of the town. Along Egnatia Street, there are several must-see places, including Kolomvou Square, which is a bustling crossroads named after G. Colombo, an Italian hotelier. Another notable site is the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is unique for its peristyle and has undergone renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds.

response:
Egnatia Street is a historically significant avenue in Thessaloniki, dating back to the Roman era, when it was a major road connecting Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës, Albania) with Constantinople. The street has been a central hub for the city since its founding and has been a busy shopping area with eclectic and art deco-style buildings since the early 20th century. 

Along Egnatia Street, notable landmarks include the Kolomvou Square, where the street meets Antigonidon Street, featuring a bustling crossroads with cafes, bars, and restaurants inside the Kolomvou Archway; the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467; and the Egnatia Street shops and buildings, showcasing the city's Byzantine tradition and European interwar period motifs. 

As you walk down Egnatia Street, you will pass by the historic centre of Thessaloniki, including the Agia Sofia church, the Red House, and the 1925 Longos Building, which is now the seat of the Thessaloniki Film Festival. The street also passes by the Church of Mikri Panagia, the Panagouda Church, and the Monastery of Panagia Gorgoepikoos, which are all worth visiting.

Egnatia Street is also significant for its connection to the city's west walls, Byzantine and Ottoman monuments, and archaeological sites, including the temple of Aphrodite. The street has undergone significant changes over the centuries, but its historical significance remains.

In terms of Instagrammable spots, Egnatia Street is a photographer's paradise, with its eclectic mix of old and new buildings, cafes, and shops. It is also a great place to experience the local culture and meet locals, with many restaurants and cafes offering traditional Greek cuisine and hospitality. With its rich history, cultural landmarks, and vibrant atmosphere, Egnatia Street is a must-visit destination for any solo traveler looking to experience the best of Thessaloniki.
reference: Egnatia Street is historically significant as it has been a central avenue since the founding of Thessaloniki, originally constructed by the Romans in the 2nd century BC. It connected Dyrrhachium (modern-day Durrës, Albania) with Constantinople. Along this busy shopping area, notable landmarks include Kolomvou Square, which features the Kolomvou Archway, a leisure hub with cafés and restaurants, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is the only mosque in Greece with a peristyle. The mosque is currently undergoing renovations to house an exhibition of archaeological finds from metro excavations.

SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
2.4  Aretsou – Krini.
These two most popular 
areas of Kalamaria stretch 
along the seafront. The 
facilities of the local marine 
sports club are here, next to 
Aretsou-Krini beach; there is 
also an open air cinema and a 
marina (the only one in town) 
with a 242-berth capacity 
(there are power, water and 
telephone services). The 
waterfront N. Plastira Street  
is lined with café-bars and 
fish tavernas which get filled 
to capacity all year round.
2.5  Komninon Street.
The longest part of the 
town’s main street is for 
pedestrian use only and you 
will find shops, cafés, small 
bars and restaurants along 
the way. This is also where 
you will find the area’s central 
square where the Town 
Hall and the church of the 
Transfiguration of Christ are. 
From the direction of the 
seafront, you can reach the 
area via I. Passalidis Street. 
How to get there. Bus 
lines 5 and 5A leave from 
Eleftherias square. Get off at 
Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.', '105

BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach 
(Kalamaria, see p. 64) and 
the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see 
p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, 
Angelochori (see p. 68) and the 
beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). 
A bit farther away, you can try the 
beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea 
Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). 
At a 60 – 90 min. distance from 
the city you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).
MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS
Lagkadas Spa: 
Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.', '66
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km

or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', '(see p.

Modern shopping areas

['<1-hop>

65 SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS 2.4 Aretsou – Krini. These two most popular areas of Kalamaria stretch along the seafront. The facilities of the local marine sports club are here, next to Aretsou-Krini beach; there is also an open air cinema and a marina (the only one in town) with a 242-berth capacity (there are power, water and telephone services). The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas which get filled to capacity all year round. 2.5 Komninon Street. The longest part of the town’s main street is for pedestrian use only and you will find shops, cafés, small bars and restaurants along the way. This is also where you will find the area’s central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are. From the direction of the seafront, you can reach the area via I. Passalidis Street. How to get there. Bus lines 5 and 5A leave from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. 3', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. response:
Kalamaria is a popular suburb of Thessaloniki, offering a mix of amenities and attractions. The main attractions in Kalamaria include:
- The Thessaloniki Marina, a large marina with 242 berths, offering amenities such as power, water, and telephone services.
- Aretsou-Krini beach, a popular spot for swimming and relaxation.
- The waterfront N. Plastira Street, lined with café-bars and fish tavernas.
- The town's central square, featuring the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ.
- The suburb's shopping centers, including the Mediterranean Cosmos Mall and the Apollonia Politeia Mall.
- The Little Palace, a historic building that served as the country residence of the Greek royal family.

In comparison, Panorama is a more rural and mountainous suburb, located on the slopes of Mt Chortiatis. The main attractions in Panorama include:
- The Vlatadon Monastery, a historic monastery that played a significant role in the city's water supply.
- The mountain refuge, located at an elevation of 1,201 meters.
- The 32 charted paths for hiking and mountain biking.
- The scenic views of the city and its environs.

While both suburbs offer unique attractions and experiences, Kalamaria is more geared towards tourists and offers a wider range of amenities and activities. Panorama, on the other hand, is more suited to nature lovers and those seeking a peaceful retreat.

In terms of accessibility, Kalamaria is well-connected to the city center via bus lines, while Panorama is more difficult to reach, requiring a longer journey. However, Panorama's scenic views and natural beauty make it a worthwhile destination for those seeking a more relaxed pace.

Overall, both suburbs offer a unique experience, and visitors should consider their interests and preferences when choosing between Kalamaria and Panorama.
reference: In Kalamaria, the main attractions include the seafront areas of Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a lively spot year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, which is pedestrian-only, hosts shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located. In contrast, Panorama, situated 12 km south of Thessaloniki, offers a panoramic view of the city and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. It is known for its natural attractions like Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café, and a path leading to an artificial lake with scenic spots along the way.

user_input: What are the key attractions and features of Kalamaria, and how does it compare to the suburb of Panorama in Thessaloniki?

These two most popular

2.5  Komninon Street.
The longest part of the 
town’s main street is for 
pedestrian use only and you 
will find shops, cafés, small 
bars and restaurants along

square where the Town

From the direction of the

House] (Little Palace).
Situated on cape Mikro 
Emvolo or Karampournaki, 
Little Palace was built in the 
1950’s and used to be the 
country residence of the greek 
royal family; today the minister 
of Macedonia-Thrace and 
the President of the Hellenic 
Republic stay here when 
visiting the city. The ground 
floor includes the lounges,  
a dance hall and an atrium;  
the first floor includes two 
suites and secondary rooms. 
It is surrounded by a garden 
and it affords an amazing 
view of the city as well as Mts 
Chortiatis and Olympus.
2.3  Kodra former military 
camp.
Building works are under way 
to change it into a park. The 
Municipality of Kalamaria often 
hosts cultural events and visual 
art exhibitions there. On-site 
excavations brought to light a 
settlement dating to the archaic 
and classical times (9th – 5th 
c. BC), which some scientists 
believe it is identified as the

115', '66
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', '64

with a cemetery dating to the

An impressive Macedonian 
tomb was also unearthed in 
Agios Athanasios area.
How to get there. Bus 
lines 40, 40A and 40K leave 
for Kalochori from the Railway

on the national road and turn 
towards Kalochori.
2 	KALAMARIA
This is practically an eastward 
‘extension’ of Thessaloniki and 
the city’s best known suburb, 
stretching along the waterfront, 
with many green spaces and 
a self-contained shopping 
centre. The first inhabitants are 
recorded in the early 20th c. and 
during the 1920’s significant 
numbers of Greek refugee 
populations settled here and 
built their small houses. They 
came from Caucasus, Minor 
Asia and Pontus [modern- 
day northeast Turkey]. Today,  
despite the rising building trend  
in the area, several refugee 
houses remain, still keeping  
a flavour of times goneby.

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. response:
Kalamaria is a popular suburb in Thessaloniki that offers a mix of amenities, attractions, and natural features. The suburb is known for its waterfront, with many cafes, restaurants, and shops lining the area. The Aretsou-Krini beach is a major attraction, as well as the open-air cinema and marina. Kalamaria is also home to the Little Palace (Kyverneio), a historic building that was once the residence of the Greek royal family. The suburb has a range of accommodation options, including hotels, and is easily accessible by public transportation.

In comparison, Panorama is a suburb located on Mt. Chortiatis, offering stunning views of the city and its surroundings. The mountain is covered in forests, and there are many hiking and biking trails available. The Panorama area also offers a fine view of the city, making it an ideal spot for sightseeing. However, Panorama is more of a natural retreat, with fewer amenities and attractions compared to Kalamaria.

While Kalamaria is a bustling and vibrant area, Panorama is more serene and peaceful. Kalamaria's waterfront and shops offer a range of activities and experiences, whereas Panorama's natural beauty is its main draw. However, both suburbs offer unique experiences and are worth visiting during your stay in Thessaloniki.

If you're looking for a mix of culture, amenities, and natural beauty, Kalamaria might be the better choice. But if you prefer a more relaxed and peaceful atmosphere, Panorama could be the way to go. Ultimately, both suburbs have their own charm and are worth exploring during your visit to Thessaloniki.
reference: Kalamaria is known for its popular areas along the seafront, particularly Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a vibrant spot year-round. In contrast, Panorama, located 12 km south of Thessaloniki, offers a panoramic view of the city and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. While Kalamaria is bustling with seaside activities, Panorama provides a more tranquil environment with natural attractions like Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café.

SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).']

65 SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS 2.4 Aretsou – Krini. These two most popular areas of Kalamaria stretch along the seafront. The facilities of the local marine sports club are here, next to Aretsou-Krini beach; there is also an open air cinema and a marina (the only one in town) with a 242-berth capacity (there are power, water and telephone services). PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. response:
Kalamaria is a popular suburb in Thessaloniki with several attractions and facilities. The most notable are the beaches, particularly Aretsou beach, which is a favorite among locals and tourists alike. The area also has a marina, a cinema, and a variety of shops, cafes, and restaurants. The Aretsou-Krini beachfront is lined with cafes, bars, and fish taverns, making it a lively and vibrant spot.

In comparison, Panorama is a smaller suburb located on Mount Chortiatis, about 10 km northeast of Panorama. While it has a more rural atmosphere, Panorama offers stunning views of the city and the surrounding mountains. Visitors can hike, bike, or off-road on the mountain trails, and there are also scenic views of the Vlatadon Monastery and the Byzantine aqueduct. The suburb has a mountain refuge, Kissos, which is a great spot for nature lovers.

While both suburbs have their unique charm, Kalamaria is more geared towards tourists and offers a wider range of amenities, including restaurants, cafes, and a cinema. Panorama, on the other hand, is a more tranquil and peaceful destination that offers a chance to experience nature and the great outdoors.

If you're looking for a lively and vibrant atmosphere, Kalamaria is the better choice. However, if you prefer a more relaxed and peaceful experience, Panorama is the way to go. Both suburbs offer a unique and authentic Greek experience, and they're definitely worth visiting.

Overall, Kalamaria and Panorama are two distinct suburbs in Thessaloniki that cater to different tastes and preferences. While Kalamaria is more tourist-friendly, Panorama is a hidden gem that offers a more secluded and natural experience. Visitors can choose the one that best suits their interests and preferences.
reference: Kalamaria features popular areas such as Aretsou and Krini, which stretch along the seafront and include a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, while Komninon Street, the town's main pedestrian street, hosts shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located. In contrast, Panorama, located 12 km south of Thessaloniki's city center, offers a panoramic view from the slope of Mt Chortiatis and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. It is known for its natural attractions like Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café, and a path leading to an artificial lake with scenic spots along the way.

areas of Kalamaria stretch

The longest part of the

65 SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS 2.4 Aretsou – Krini. These two most popular areas of Kalamaria stretch along the seafront. The facilities of the local marine sports club are here, next to Aretsou-Krini beach; there is also an open air cinema and a marina (the only one in town) with a 242-berth capacity (there are power, water and telephone services). The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas which get filled to capacity all year round. 2.5 Komninon Street. The longest part of the town’s main street is for pedestrian use only and you will find shops, cafés, small bars and restaurants along the way. This is also where you will find the area’s central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are. From the direction of the seafront, you can reach the area via I. Passalidis Street. How to get there. Bus lines 5 and 5A leave from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. 3', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Kalamaria is a vibrant and popular suburb in Thessaloniki, offering a range of attractions and facilities that can enhance a traveler's experience. 

Some must-visit attractions in Kalamaria include the Thessaloniki Marina, which is a hub for water sports and activities. The Aretsou-Krini beach is another popular spot, offering stunning views of the sea and surrounding landscape. 

For a dose of culture, visitors can explore the Little Palace (Kyverneio), a historic building that was once the country residence of the Greek royal family. The building now serves as the residence of the minister of Macedonia-Thrace and the President of the Hellenic Republic.

Additionally, Kalamaria is home to the Forest Theatre, the Theatre of the Earth, and the Kalamaria Municipal Theatre, which offer a range of performances and events throughout the year. 

For shopping and dining, visitors can head to the Kapani (Vlali Marketplace), Modiano Marketplace, and Bezesteni, which offer a range of local products and cuisine. 

Kalamaria is also a great spot for outdoor activities, with several beaches and parks in the area, including the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada.

In terms of facilities, Kalamaria has a range of sports and leisure options, including the Poseidonio Sports Centre, the National Swimming Pool, and the Kalamaria Football ground. The Thessaloniki Concert Hall is also located in the area, offering a range of cultural events and performances.

Overall, Kalamaria is a great destination for travelers looking for a mix of culture, entertainment, and outdoor activities, with plenty of facilities and attractions to enhance their experience.
reference: In Kalamaria, travelers can enjoy the seafront areas of Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and the only marina in town with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a vibrant spot year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, the longest part of the town’s main street, is pedestrian-friendly and offers shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located.

The longest part of the town’s main street is for pedestrian use only and you will find shops, cafés, small bars and restaurants along the way. This is also where you will find the area’s central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are. From the direction of the seafront, you can reach the area via I. Passalidis Street. How to get there. Bus lines 5 and 5A leave from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. 3', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Kalamaria is a popular suburb in Thessaloniki that offers a mix of urban and seaside experiences. Its main attractions include the waterfront N. Plastira Street, lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, as well as the Aretsou-Krini beach and the local marine sports club. The suburb is also home to the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ. Kalamaria is known for its lively atmosphere and has a range of accommodation options, including hotels. Visitors can enjoy shopping, dining, and entertainment options, including the Mediterranean Cosmos Mall and the Apollonia Politeia Mall.

In comparison, Panorama is a suburb located about 10 km northeast of Thessaloniki's city center, known for its natural beauty and outdoor recreational opportunities. The suburb offers a range of activities, including hiking, mountain biking, and off-roading, as well as a mountain refuge and scenic views of the city and its environs. Panorama is also home to the Vlatadon Monastery, which played a significant role in the city's water supply system.

While both suburbs offer unique experiences, Kalamaria is generally more lively and urban, with a greater range of amenities and attractions. Panorama, on the other hand, is more suited to those seeking a natural and peaceful retreat, with opportunities for outdoor activities and scenic views. However, both suburbs are easily accessible from the city center, with buses and taxis available.

For a solo traveler, Kalamaria's lively atmosphere and range of amenities make it a more suitable choice, while Panorama's natural beauty and outdoor recreational opportunities may appeal to those seeking a more peaceful and secluded experience. Ultimately, the choice between Kalamaria and Panorama will depend on individual preferences and priorities.
reference: Kalamaria is known for its popular areas along the seafront, such as Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and the only marina in town with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a vibrant area year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, which is pedestrian-only, hosts shops, cafés, and the central square with the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ. Public transport is accessible via bus lines 5 and 5A. In contrast, Panorama, located 12 km south of Thessaloniki, offers a panoramic view of the city and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. It has historical significance, being settled by refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus in the early 20th century. A notable attraction in Panorama is Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café, along with a 6 km path leading to an artificial lake, showcasing natural beauty and historical remnants like Byzantine watermills.

response:
Kalamaria is a popular destination in Thessaloniki, known for its vibrant atmosphere, rich history, and exciting attractions. Here are some notable features and attractions that make Kalamaria appealing:

*   **Beaches and Waterfront**: Kalamaria boasts stunning beaches, such as Aretsou-Krini beach, and a picturesque waterfront, lined with café-bars, fish tavernas, and restaurants. Visitors can enjoy the scenic views, relax, and indulge in local cuisine.
*   **Shopping and Dining**: The area offers a variety of shopping centers, including the Mediterranean Cosmos Mall and the Apollonia Politeia Mall, which feature over 200 shops, cafes, and restaurants. Visitors can find unique souvenirs, try local specialties, and enjoy the city's vibrant nightlife.
*   **Cultural Experiences**: Kalamaria is home to several cultural attractions, such as the Little Palace, also known as the Kyverneio, which offers stunning views of the city and the surrounding mountains. The area is also known for its traditional festivals and events, which showcase the local culture and history.
*   **Sports and Leisure**: Visitors can enjoy various sports and leisure activities, including the Poseidonio Sports Centre, which offers indoor and outdoor facilities for sports and recreation. The area is also home to several stadiums, including the Kaftanzogleio stadium, which hosts various events and concerts.
*   **Accessibility and Amenities**: Kalamaria offers easy accessibility, with several bus stations and a main port, making it easy for visitors to get around the city. The area also features a range of amenities, including restaurants, cafes, and shops, catering to various tastes and preferences.

Overall, Kalamaria's unique blend of history, culture, and entertainment makes it an attractive destination for solo travelers and visitors looking for a leisurely getaway. Its vibrant atmosphere, stunning beaches, and range of attractions ensure that visitors will have a memorable experience in this popular Thessaloniki neighborhood.
reference: Kalamaria is known for its vibrant seafront areas, particularly Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and the only marina in town with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a lively spot year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, the longest part of the town’s main street, is pedestrian-friendly and hosts shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located. Public transport is accessible via bus lines from Eleftherias square, making it easy for travelers to explore these attractions.

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. response:
Kalamaria is a popular area for leisure and entertainment in Thessaloniki. There are several ways to get there, depending on your starting location. 

From the city center, you can take bus lines 5 and 5A from Eleftherias Square, which will take you directly to Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or to Chamodrakas stop in the Aretsou area. Alternatively, you can take a taxi or ride-hailing service from your location.

Another popular area is Komninon Street, which is pedestrian-friendly and lined with shops, cafes, restaurants, and bars. You can reach it by taking the bus from the city center or by walking from nearby areas.

If you're looking for more shopping and entertainment options, Pylaia is a great area to explore. You can take the bus from the city center or from nearby areas like Kalamaria. The Mediterranean Cosmos Mall is a popular destination, with over 200 shops, cafes, and restaurants.

If you're looking for a more traditional experience, you can try visiting the Plateia Mall in Tsimiski Street. It's a great place to find affordable shopping options and a variety of local products.

Lastly, if you're looking for a more vibrant nightlife, Kalamaria is a great area to explore. You can visit the Aretsou-Krini beach and enjoy the local nightlife, or try visiting the Forest Theatre or the Theatre of the Earth.

Overall, Kalamaria is a great area to explore for leisure and entertainment, with plenty of options for shopping, dining, and nightlife. Whether you're looking for a more traditional experience or a vibrant nightlife, Kalamaria has something for everyone.

Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas. To get to these areas, you can take bus lines 5 and 5A from Eleftherias square and get off at the Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in the Aretsou area.

['65
SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
2.4  Aretsou – Krini.
These two most popular 
areas of Kalamaria stretch 
along the seafront. The 
facilities of the local marine 
sports club are here, next to 
Aretsou-Krini beach; there is 
also an open air cinema and a 
marina (the only one in town) 
with a 242-berth capacity 
(there are power, water and 
telephone services). The 
waterfront N. Plastira Street  
is lined with café-bars and 
fish tavernas which get filled 
to capacity all year round.
2.5  Komninon Street.
The longest part of the 
town’s main street is for 
pedestrian use only and you 
will find shops, cafés, small 
bars and restaurants along 
the way. This is also where 
you will find the area’s central 
square where the Town 
Hall and the church of the 
Transfiguration of Christ are. 
From the direction of the 
seafront, you can reach the 
area via I. Passalidis Street. 
How to get there. Bus 
lines 5 and 5A leave from

Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] 
stop or at Chamodrakas stop 
in Aretsou area.', 'MUST SEΕ: 
2.1  Sofouli Street
(see p. 53).
2.2  Kyverneio [Government 
House] (Little Palace).
Situated on cape Mikro 
Emvolo or Karampournaki, 
Little Palace was built in the 
1950’s and used to be the 
country residence of the greek 
royal family; today the minister 
of Macedonia-Thrace and 
the President of the Hellenic 
Republic stay here when 
visiting the city. The ground 
floor includes the lounges,  
a dance hall and an atrium;  
the first floor includes two 
suites and secondary rooms. 
It is surrounded by a garden 
and it affords an amazing 
view of the city as well as Mts 
Chortiatis and Olympus.
2.3  Kodra former military 
camp.
Building works are under way 
to change it into a park. The 
Municipality of Kalamaria often 
hosts cultural events and visual 
art exhibitions there. On-site 
excavations brought to light a 
settlement dating to the archaic 
and classical times (9th – 5th 
c. BC), which some scientists 
believe it is identified as the 
location of Ancient Thermi.

SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS
3.1  Chortiatis.
Named after the mountain, 
this small suburb on Mt 
Chortiatis (elev.: 1,201 m.), 
stretches approx. 10 km NE  
of Panorama. Since the Roman 
times, Thessaloniki’s water 
supply came from this place 
via Vlatadon Monastery (see 
p. 44); this is why you will 
see fragments of a Byzantine 
aqueduct at the suburb’s 
border. The mountain is covered 
with chestnut, oak, beech and 
fir trees, there is a mountain 
refuge (Kissos location, elev. 
1,201 m.) and it is the ideal 
place for hiking (there are 32 
charted paths), for mountain 
biking and off-roading.
How to get there. Board 
the 58 bus on Egnatia Street 
and get off at Dimarchio 
[Town Hall], Astynomia [Police 
Station] or at Platanakia stop.
4 	THERMI
This suburb is located a bit 
further away from town (15 km 
SE of the city centre) and more 
or less still keeps a countryside 
air about it. On-site excavations 
have shown that this was the 
location of the harbour of 
ancient Thermi, a major one  
in antiquity. The place was also 
known for its hot springs – 
thermae – hence the name  
of the gulf (Thermaikos).', '105

['<1-hop>

65 SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS 2.4 Aretsou – Krini. These two most popular areas of Kalamaria stretch along the seafront. The facilities of the local marine sports club are here, next to Aretsou-Krini beach; there is also an open air cinema and a marina (the only one in town) with a 242-berth capacity (there are power, water and telephone services). Passalidis Street. How to get there. Bus lines 5 and 5A leave from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. 3', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Kalamaria is a popular suburb in Thessaloniki, known for its vibrant atmosphere, beautiful beaches, and rich history. The suburb is home to the Thessaloniki Marina, a bustling hub for sailors and tourists alike. Aretsou beach is a must-visit spot, with its picturesque views and lively atmosphere. The nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada offer a range of experiences for beachgoers. Kalamaria is also a great destination for foodies, with a variety of traditional Greek restaurants and tavernas serving delicious local cuisine.

In comparison, Panorama is a quieter and more residential suburb, offering stunning views of the city and the surrounding mountains. While it's not as bustling as Kalamaria, Panorama is perfect for those seeking a more relaxed atmosphere and a chance to explore the natural beauty of the area. The suburb is home to the Vlatadon Monastery, a historic site that offers a glimpse into the region's rich history and culture. Panorama is also a great spot for outdoor enthusiasts, with its proximity to the mountainous area and the many hiking trails that crisscross the region.

While both suburbs offer unique experiences, Kalamaria is generally more lively and vibrant, with a wider range of amenities and activities to suit different tastes. However, Panorama is ideal for those seeking a more peaceful and natural environment, with plenty of opportunities for relaxation and exploration.

Ultimately, the choice between Kalamaria and Panorama depends on individual preferences. If you're looking for a bustling hub with plenty of amenities and activities, Kalamaria is the way to go. But if you prefer a more relaxed and natural environment, Panorama is the perfect choice.

Instagram-worthy spots abound in both suburbs, with Kalamaria's beaches and Panorama's mountain views offering endless opportunities for photography. Visitors can also interact with locals in both areas, with Kalamaria's markets and Panorama's historic sites providing a chance to learn about the region's culture and history. With its rich history, stunning natural beauty, and vibrant atmosphere, Kalamaria is an unmissable destination for any traveler.
reference:
Kalamaria is known for its vibrant seafront areas, particularly Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and a marina with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a popular destination year-round. The main street, Komninon, is pedestrian-friendly and hosts shops, cafés, and the central square with the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ. Public transport is accessible via bus lines from Eleftherias square.

In contrast, Panorama, located 12 km south of Thessaloniki, offers a panoramic view of the city and is characterized by luxury villas and a small shopping area. It was uninhabited until the early 20th century, with its first inhabitants being refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Panorama is also known for its natural attractions, such as Platanakia, a wooded ravine with a small zoo and a café, and a 6 km path leading to an artificial lake with scenic spots along the way. Both areas provide unique experiences, with Kalamaria focusing on coastal activities and nightlife, while Panorama emphasizes residential luxury and natural beauty.

Karampournaki 
(Kalamaria).
72.  
Panorama 
area offers a 
fine view of 
the city and its 
environs.
71']

['<1-hop>

65 SUBURBS AND CITY OUTSKIRTS 2.4 Aretsou – Krini. These two most popular areas of Kalamaria stretch along the seafront. The facilities of the local marine sports club are here, next to Aretsou-Krini beach; there is also an open air cinema and a marina (the only one in town) with a 242-berth capacity (there are power, water and telephone services). The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas which get filled to capacity all year round. 2.5 Komninon Street. The longest part of the town’s main street is for pedestrian use only and you will find shops, cafés, small bars and restaurants along the way. This is also where you will find the area’s central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are. From the direction of the seafront, you can reach the area via I. Passalidis Street. How to get there. Bus lines 5 and 5A leave from Eleftherias square. Get off at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] stop or at Chamodrakas stop in Aretsou area. 3', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Kalamaria is a popular suburb of Thessaloniki that offers a range of attractions and facilities. 

For those interested in leisure activities, the Aretsou beach and the Thessaloniki Marina are accessible via I. Passalidis Street and are a great place to spend the day. 

Visitors can also explore the waterfront N. Plastira Street, lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, which get filled to capacity all year round.

For a taste of local culture, the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located in the central square of Komninon Street, which is pedestrian-friendly and lined with shops, cafés, small bars, and restaurants.

The area is also close to the Thessaloniki Concert Hall, the Vasiliko [Royal] Theatre, and the Theatre of the Earth, which offer a range of artistic events throughout the year.

In terms of accessibility, visitors can use the long distance bus station or the new railway station to get to Kalamaria. The area is also close to the main port, making it easy to get around.

For those interested in traditional experiences, the Kapani (Vlali Marketplace) and Modiano Marketplace are nearby, offering a glimpse into local culture.

Additionally, the Thessaloniki Marina has a marina with a 242-berth capacity, offering power, water, and telephone services.

Overall, Kalamaria is a great place to visit for those interested in leisure activities, local culture, and traditional experiences, with plenty of options for accommodation and transportation.

To access these attractions, visitors can use the following transportation options:

* Long distance bus station
* New railway station
* Main port
* Taxi or ride-sharing services

It's also worth noting that the Thessaloniki Marina has a 24-hour service, making it easily accessible at any time. 

I hope this information helps you plan your trip to Kalamaria!
reference: In Kalamaria, the main attractions include the seafront areas of Aretsou and Krini, which feature a local marine sports club, an open-air cinema, and the only marina in town with a 242-berth capacity. The waterfront N. Plastira Street is lined with café-bars and fish tavernas, making it a lively spot year-round. Additionally, Komninon Street, which is pedestrian-only, hosts shops, cafés, and restaurants, along with the central square where the Town Hall and the church of the Transfiguration of Christ are located. To access these areas, bus lines 5 and 5A depart from Eleftherias square, with stops at Naftikos Omilos [Marine Club] or Chamodrakas in the Aretsou area.

user_input: What are some popular beaches to visit in Chalkidiki, and how far are they from Thessaloniki?
retrieved_contexts:
['Another option for you 
is to go swimming in the 
beautiful beaches by the 
seaside suburbs and city 
outskirts (see p. 63-69), in 
places within the regional 
unit of Thessaloniki (see p. 
91-95), and in Halkidiki (see 
p. 92). You can also visit the 
Magic Park (12th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Airport Road), 
the biggest amusement park 
in Greece, which attracts 
children, teenagers, grown-
ups and families alike  
(www.magicpark.gr); the 
WaterLand is another 
fun option as there are 
waterpools, waterslides  
of various sizes, with different 
levels of difficulty, restaurants 
and mini markets. It is 
located in Tagarades,  
Thermi area, (see p. 66).
TOURING THESSALONIKI WITH CHILDREN
123', 'Such evidence 
makes this cave one of the 
oldest archaeological sites in 
Europe. Findings from the cave 
(tools, animal bones etc) are  
on display at the Museum  
and so are a cast of the skull  
(the original is kept at the 
Geology-Palaeontology Museum  
of the Aristotle University  
of Thessaloniki, see p. 38) and  
a reconstruction of the place  
it was found.
4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for 
110.  
One of 
Halkidiki’s 
numerous 
lovely beaches.
111.  
Mount 
Athos: Agios 
Panteleimonas 
Monastery.
110', '105
Hellenic Professional Yacht 
Owners Association:  
Marina Zeas  
(Administration Building), 
185 36 – Piraeus
tel.: 210 45.26.335
fax: 210 42.80.465
website: www.hpyoa.gr
MARINA
The Thessaloniki Marina is 
located in Aretsou Kalamaria, 
tel.: \x072310 444.598,  
2310 444.541  
(Port Authority)
fax: 2310 444.585 
VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) 
website:  
www.thessaloniki-marina.gr
BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach 
(Kalamaria, see p. 64) and 
the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see 
p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, 
Angelochori (see p. 68) and the 
beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). 
A bit farther away, you can try the 
beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea 
Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). 
At a 60 – 90 min. distance from 
the city you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).
MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS
Lagkadas Spa: 
Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.', '7
«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.', '102
GENERAL FACTS
Greece is on Europe’s southeast 
end with a population of 
10,788,000. It is a parliamentary 
republic and a member of the 
European Union since 1981. 
Thessaloniki is located 510 
km N of Athens. It is the second 
biggest city in the country and the 
biggest in Northern Greece; it is 
also the capital of the Thessaloniki 
Regional Unit as well as of the 
Region of Central Macedonia. 
It is situated within the inlet of 
the Thermaic Gulf and the city 
population is over 1 million.
Currency. Since January 1st 2001 
the euro is the Greek national 
currency. You can change money 
at the airport, in private exchange 
offices, or in banks.  
Calling code. The international 
calling code for Greece is +30. 
Time. Greece is seven hours 
ahead of the Eastern Standard 
Time, two hours ahead of 
Greenwich Mean Time and 
one hour ahead of the Central 
European Time. 
Climate. Thessaloniki has 
a temperate mediterranean 
climate with continental features 
and quite a few sunshiny days 
throughout the year.']

A bit farther away, you can try the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). At a 60 – 90 min. distance from the city you will reach the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92). MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

response:
Chalkidiki is a must-visit destination for any beach lover. Two of the most popular beaches in the region are Kassandra and Sithonia, which are known for their crystal-clear waters and picturesque scenery. Kassandra is located about 120 km northeast of Thessaloniki, making it a perfect weekend getaway. Sithonia is about 90 km northeast of Thessaloniki, making it easily accessible by car or public transportation.

Both beaches offer a range of activities, including swimming, sunbathing, and water sports. Kassandra is particularly popular with families and offers a variety of amenities, including restaurants, bars, and water parks. Sithonia, on the other hand, is more laid-back and offers a more relaxed atmosphere.

If you're looking for a more secluded beach experience, you might want to consider the beaches in the Asprovalta area, which are located about 60-90 km northeast of Thessaloniki. These beaches offer a more peaceful and natural environment, with crystal-clear waters and stunning scenery.

Overall, Chalkidiki is a must-visit destination for any beach lover, with its stunning beaches, picturesque scenery, and range of activities. Whether you're looking for a relaxing beach vacation or an action-packed weekend getaway, Chalkidiki has something for everyone.

Some popular beaches to visit in Chalkidiki include:

* Kassandra Beach: Known for its crystal-clear waters and picturesque scenery, Kassandra Beach is a popular destination for families and beach lovers alike.
* Sithonia Beach: Located about 90 km northeast of Thessaloniki, Sithonia Beach offers a range of activities, including swimming, sunbathing, and water sports.
* Asprovalta Beach: Located about 60-90 km northeast of Thessaloniki, Asprovalta Beach offers a more secluded beach experience, with crystal-clear waters and stunning scenery.

All three beaches are easily accessible by car or public transportation, making them a great weekend getaway from Thessaloniki.
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beaches are known for their stunning scenery and are a great destination for swimming and relaxation.

['7
«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.', 'Another option for you 
is to go swimming in the 
beautiful beaches by the 
seaside suburbs and city 
outskirts (see p. 63-69), in 
places within the regional 
unit of Thessaloniki (see p. 
91-95), and in Halkidiki (see 
p. 92). You can also visit the 
Magic Park (12th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Airport Road), 
the biggest amusement park 
in Greece, which attracts 
children, teenagers, grown-
ups and families alike  
(www.magicpark.gr); the 
WaterLand is another 
fun option as there are 
waterpools, waterslides  
of various sizes, with different 
levels of difficulty, restaurants 
and mini markets. It is 
located in Tagarades,  
Thermi area, (see p. 66).
TOURING THESSALONIKI WITH CHILDREN

gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', '105
