A bit farther away, you can try the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). At a 60 – 90 min. distance from the city you will reach the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92). MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. response:
You can visit the beaches of Kassandra, Sithonia, and Athos, which are located in the Chalkidiki region. These beaches are popular among tourists and offer a range of activities such as swimming, sunbathing, and water sports.

The beaches of Kassandra are approximately 60-90 minutes from Thessaloniki, depending on traffic. You can take a bus or drive to get there. The beaches of Sithonia are also around 60-90 minutes from Thessaloniki. The beaches of Athos are a bit farther away, around 2-3 hours from Thessaloniki, but they are still accessible by bus or car.

Some popular beaches in Kassandra include the beaches of Nea Vrasna and Stavros, which are mentioned in the document. These beaches are awarded a Blue Flag and offer a range of activities such as swimming, sunbathing, and water sports.

The beaches of Sithonia are also popular, with the beach of Agia Triada mentioned in the document. This beach is located in the town of Agia Triada and offers a range of activities such as swimming, sunbathing, and water sports.

Overall, the beaches of Chalkidiki are a must-visit for anyone traveling to the region. They offer a range of activities, stunning natural beauty, and a relaxed atmosphere. Whether you're looking for a quiet beach or a lively resort, Chalkidiki has something for everyone.

In terms of accessibility, the beaches of Chalkidiki are generally well-maintained and easy to access. The roads leading to the beaches are well-signposted, and there are often amenities such as restaurants, cafes, and shops nearby. This makes it easy for visitors to get to the beaches and enjoy their activities.

Overall, the beaches of Chalkidiki are a great option for anyone looking for a relaxing and enjoyable beach experience. With their stunning natural beauty, range of activities, and relaxed atmosphere, they are sure to be a hit with visitors.
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beaches are known for their scenic beauty and are a great destination for swimming and relaxation.

user_input: What are some popular beaches to visit in Chalkidiki and how far are they from Thessaloniki?
retrieved_contexts:
['Another option for you 
is to go swimming in the 
beautiful beaches by the 
seaside suburbs and city 
outskirts (see p. 63-69), in 
places within the regional 
unit of Thessaloniki (see p. 
91-95), and in Halkidiki (see 
p. 92). You can also visit the 
Magic Park (12th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Airport Road), 
the biggest amusement park 
in Greece, which attracts 
children, teenagers, grown-
ups and families alike  
(www.magicpark.gr); the 
WaterLand is another 
fun option as there are 
waterpools, waterslides  
of various sizes, with different 
levels of difficulty, restaurants 
and mini markets. It is 
located in Tagarades,  
Thermi area, (see p. 66).
TOURING THESSALONIKI WITH CHILDREN
123', '105
Hellenic Professional Yacht 
Owners Association:  
Marina Zeas  
(Administration Building), 
185 36 – Piraeus
tel.: 210 45.26.335
fax: 210 42.80.465
website: www.hpyoa.gr
MARINA
The Thessaloniki Marina is 
located in Aretsou Kalamaria, 
tel.: \x072310 444.598,  
2310 444.541  
(Port Authority)
fax: 2310 444.585 
VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) 
website:  
www.thessaloniki-marina.gr
BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach 
(Kalamaria, see p. 64) and 
the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see 
p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, 
Angelochori (see p. 68) and the 
beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). 
A bit farther away, you can try the 
beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea 
Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). 
At a 60 – 90 min. distance from 
the city you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).
MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS
Lagkadas Spa: 
Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.', '95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', '7
«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.', '93
DAY EXCURSIONS
a day trip (it’s only a short 
distance from the city) or 
for a longer one; quite a few 
own country houses there. In 
the Athos peninsula amidst 
a beautiful and pristine 
natural environment lies the 
globally known monastic 
state of Mount Athos which 
encompasses 20 -presently 
inhabited- monasteries 
(10th – 14th c.), sketes [small 
monastic settlements] and 
cells for monks. UNESCO has 
included the ‘Holy Mount’ in its 
World Heritage Monument List 
in 1988, on grounds of the 
outstanding architecture and 
the priceless cultural treasures 
of the monastic community.
How to get there. 
Petralona Cave is situated  
53 km SE of Thessaloniki. Take 
the coach to Halkidiki, get 
off at Nea Kallikrateia Village 
stop and then take a taxi to 
the cave (approx. a 10-km 
journey). If you travel by car, 
go along the Thessaloniki-
Halkidiki national road and  
then follow the signs to 
Petralona village and the cave.
5 	LAKES AREA
Northeast of Thessaloniki, in 
the direction of Strymonas 
(also Strymonian) gulf 
stretches a 200,000 hectare-
area around Lakes Koroneia 
and Volvi; the place is a 
National Park.']

['<1-hop>

105 Hellenic Professional Yacht Owners Association: Marina Zeas (Administration Building), 185 36 – Piraeus tel.: 210 45.26.335 fax: 210 42.80.465 website: www.hpyoa.gr MARINA The Thessaloniki Marina is located in Aretsou Kalamaria, tel.: \x072310 444.598, 2310 444.541 (Port Authority) fax: 2310 444.585 VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) website: www.thessaloniki-marina.gr BEACHES Go for a swim in Aretsou beach (Kalamaria, see p. 64) and the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, Angelochori (see p. 68) and the beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). A bit farther away, you can try the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). At a 60 – 90 min. distance from the city you will reach the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92). MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
You can visit the beaches in Asprovalta, Nea Vrasna, and Stavros. These beaches are popular for swimming, water sports, and beach volleyball. Asprovalta beach is 10 km long and has been awarded a Blue Flag for its cleanliness and quality.

The beaches in Asprovalta, Nea Vrasna, and Stavros are approximately 60-90 minutes from Thessaloniki, depending on traffic. You can take a bus or drive to these beaches. 

For a more relaxing experience, you can also visit the beaches in Peraia, Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada, and Nea Michaniona. These beaches are located near the city of Thessaloniki and offer a more laid-back atmosphere.

If you're looking for a unique experience, you can visit the beaches in Lake Koroneia, which is a 200,000-hectare area around Lakes Koroneia and Volvi. This area is a National Park and offers stunning natural beauty and opportunities for swimming and water sports.

Overall, there are many great beaches in Chalkidiki and Thessaloniki to choose from, depending on your preferences and what you're looking for. I recommend visiting the beaches in Asprovalta, Peraia, and Lake Koroneia for a mix of relaxation and adventure.

Here are some Instagrammable spots:

* Asprovalta beach with its 10 km length and Blue Flag award
* The scenic views of Lake Koroneia
* The historic city of Thessaloniki and its ancient ruins

I hope this helps you plan your trip to Chalkidiki and Thessaloniki!
reference: The popular beaches in Chalkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beautiful beaches are well-known for their scenic views and are a great destination for swimming.

user_input: What are some popular beaches in Halkidiki that are easily accessible from Thessaloniki?

4.1  Halkidiki (also

Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best

A bit farther away, you can try the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Halkidiki's beaches are easily accessible from Thessaloniki. Some popular ones include:
- Aretsou beach in Kalamaria, which is a short bus ride from Thessaloniki and offers a 10 km long beach with a Blue Flag award.
- Peraia beach, which is also easily accessible by bus and offers a scenic beach with calm waters.
- Nea Vrasna beach, which is a bit farther but still easily accessible by bus, and offers a 10 km long beach with a Blue Flag award.
- Agia Triada beach, which is a short bus ride from Thessaloniki and offers a scenic beach with calm waters.
- Nea Michaniona beach, which is a short bus ride from Thessaloniki and offers a scenic beach with calm waters.
These beaches offer a great combination of accessibility, scenic beauty, and amenities, making them perfect for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. Additionally, they are all easily accessible by bus, making it easy for solo travelers to get around.

It's worth noting that these beaches are popular with locals and tourists alike, so you can expect to find amenities such as restaurants, bars, and water sports. However, if you're looking for a more secluded experience, you can always explore the surrounding countryside and villages, which offer a range of accommodations and activities.

Overall, Halkidiki's beaches are a great option for a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki, offering a range of options to suit different tastes and preferences. With their scenic beauty, amenities, and accessibility, they are sure to provide an unforgettable experience for solo travelers.
reference: Some popular beaches in Halkidiki that are easily accessible from Thessaloniki include the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches located at a 60 to 90-minute distance from the city. Specific beaches mentioned are in the Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna, and Stavros.

The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
You can visit the beaches of Kassandra, Sithonia, and Athos. The distance from Thessaloniki to these beaches varies.

The beaches of Kassandra are approximately 60-90 minutes away from Thessaloniki, depending on traffic. Some popular beaches in Kassandra include Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada.

The beaches of Sithonia are approximately 45-60 minutes away from Thessaloniki. Some popular beaches in Sithonia include Asprovalta and Stavros.

The beaches of Athos are approximately 1-2 hours away from Thessaloniki, depending on traffic. However, please note that Athos is a holy site and not all beaches may be accessible.

Some popular beaches to visit in Chalkidiki include:

*   Peraia beach (Kassandra)
*   Asprovalta beach (Sithonia)
*   Stavros beach (Sithonia)
*   Agia Triada beach (Kassandra)
*   Neoi Epivates beach (Kassandra)
*   Agios Vasileios beach (Sithonia)

These beaches offer a range of amenities, including restaurants, water sports, and scenic views. However, please note that some beaches may require a ferry ride or a hike to access.

Overall, the beaches of Chalkidiki offer a unique and unforgettable experience for solo travelers. With their stunning natural beauty, rich history, and warm hospitality, Chalkidiki is an ideal destination for anyone looking to explore the best of Greece.
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. Some recommended beaches include Aretsou beach in Kalamaria, as well as the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada.

450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.']

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. response:
Halkidiki is a popular tourist destination known for its beautiful beaches. Some popular beaches to visit in Halkidiki include Kassandra, Sithonia, and Athos. 

Kassandra beach is approximately 60-90 minutes from Thessaloniki, depending on traffic. 

Sithonia beach is approximately 30-60 minutes from Thessaloniki, depending on traffic.

Athos beach is approximately 1-2 hours from Thessaloniki, depending on traffic and the specific location on the peninsula.

It's worth noting that the beaches in Halkidiki are generally considered to be very beautiful and popular with tourists, so they may be more crowded during peak season. However, they are also well-maintained and offer a range of amenities and activities, such as swimming, sunbathing, and water sports.

If you're looking for a more secluded beach experience, you may want to consider the beaches in the Strymonian gulf, which are located about 10-15 minutes from the city of Kilkis. 

It's also worth mentioning that the Magic Park and WaterLand are great options for families with kids, and are located near the city of Thermi.

Overall, Halkidiki has a wide range of beaches to suit different tastes and preferences, and is a great destination for anyone looking for a relaxing beach vacation.
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. Some recommended beaches include Aretsou beach in Kalamaria, as well as the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada.

user_input: What are some popular beaches to visit in Chalkidiki, and how far are they from Thessaloniki?
retrieved_contexts:
['95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', 'Another option for you 
is to go swimming in the 
beautiful beaches by the 
seaside suburbs and city 
outskirts (see p. 63-69), in 
places within the regional 
unit of Thessaloniki (see p. 
91-95), and in Halkidiki (see 
p. 92). You can also visit the 
Magic Park (12th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Airport Road), 
the biggest amusement park 
in Greece, which attracts 
children, teenagers, grown-
ups and families alike  
(www.magicpark.gr); the 
WaterLand is another 
fun option as there are 
waterpools, waterslides  
of various sizes, with different 
levels of difficulty, restaurants 
and mini markets. It is 
located in Tagarades,  
Thermi area, (see p. 66).
TOURING THESSALONIKI WITH CHILDREN
123', 'In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans. There are 
swimming pools for men 
and women, 10 personal 
hydromassage areas where 
mineral spring water is used, 
saunas, a gym and areas 
for mud treatment. In the 
summer, visitors can enjoy 
a special mud therapy by 
the lake shore which gets 
usually dried up during the 
warmest season of the year. 
In the grounds you will find 
a physiotherapy centre and 
a medical clinic, a hotel, a 
restaurant, a bar, basketball 
and football fields.
How to get there. 
Pikrolimni is located 23 
km N of Thessaloniki. If 
you travel by car, follow the 
signs to Kilkis and after that, 
from Galliko village head 
for Xylokeratia (Pikrolimni). 
Alternatively there is a bus 
from Dimokratias square 
(Vardari) leaving daily at 9 am, 
which will take you to the Mud 
Therapy Centre for free.
DAY EXCURSIONS

(Administration Building),

tel.: 210 45.26.335
fax: 210 42.80.465
website: www.hpyoa.gr
MARINA
The Thessaloniki Marina is

2310 444.541  
(Port Authority)
fax: 2310 444.585 
VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) 
website:  
www.thessaloniki-marina.gr
BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach 
(Kalamaria, see p. 64) and 
the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see 
p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, 
Angelochori (see p. 68) and the 
beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). 
A bit farther away, you can try the 
beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea 
Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). 
At a 60 – 90 min. distance from 
the city you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).
MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS
Lagkadas Spa: 
Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.', '7
«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.']

response:
Chalkidiki is a beautiful region with many stunning beaches. For a weekend getaway from Thessaloniki, I recommend visiting the beaches in the Asprovalta area, which are approximately 10 km away from Thessaloniki. These beaches, such as Nea Vrasna and Stavros, are perfect for swimming, sunbathing, and enjoying the scenic views. 

Another popular beach destination is the Agia Triada beach, which is about 10 km away from Thessaloniki. This beach is known for its picturesque views and is a great spot for families and couples alike.

If you're looking for a more secluded beach experience, consider visiting the beaches in the Epanomi area, which are about 20 km away from Thessaloniki. These beaches offer a tranquil atmosphere and are perfect for those seeking a relaxing beach vacation.

Lastly, if you're willing to travel a bit further, the beaches in the Halkidiki region are definitely worth visiting. The most popular ones are the ones in the Kavala area, which are about 60-90 km away from Thessaloniki. These beaches offer breathtaking views and are perfect for those seeking a more exotic beach experience.

All of these beaches are easily accessible by car or bus, and there are plenty of amenities and services available nearby. I highly recommend visiting these beaches during your weekend getaway from Thessaloniki. 

Instagrammable spots abound in these beaches, so be sure to capture some amazing photos to share on social media! 

Remember to plan your trip according to the season, as some beaches may be more crowded during the summer months. 

Enjoy your beach-hopping adventure in Chalkidiki!
reference: The popular beaches in Chalkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beaches are known for their beauty and are a great destination for swimming and relaxation.

A bit farther away, you can try the

At a 60 – 90 min. distance from

beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).

Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.', 'Such evidence 
makes this cave one of the 
oldest archaeological sites in 
Europe. Findings from the cave 
(tools, animal bones etc) are  
on display at the Museum  
and so are a cast of the skull  
(the original is kept at the 
Geology-Palaeontology Museum  
of the Aristotle University  
of Thessaloniki, see p. 38) and  
a reconstruction of the place  
it was found.
4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for 
110.  
One of

numerous 
lovely beaches.
111.  
Mount 
Athos: Agios 
Panteleimonas 
Monastery.
110', 'Another option for you 
is to go swimming in the 
beautiful beaches by the 
seaside suburbs and city 
outskirts (see p. 63-69), in 
places within the regional 
unit of Thessaloniki (see p. 
91-95), and in Halkidiki (see 
p. 92). You can also visit the 
Magic Park (12th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Airport Road), 
the biggest amusement park 
in Greece, which attracts 
children, teenagers, grown-
ups and families alike  
(www.magicpark.gr); the 
WaterLand is another 
fun option as there are 
waterpools, waterslides  
of various sizes, with different 
levels of difficulty, restaurants 
and mini markets. It is 
located in Tagarades,  
Thermi area, (see p. 66).
TOURING THESSALONIKI WITH CHILDREN
123', '95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.', '93
DAY EXCURSIONS
a day trip (it’s only a short 
distance from the city) or 
for a longer one; quite a few 
own country houses there. In 
the Athos peninsula amidst 
a beautiful and pristine 
natural environment lies the 
globally known monastic 
state of Mount Athos which 
encompasses 20 -presently 
inhabited- monasteries 
(10th – 14th c.), sketes [small 
monastic settlements] and 
cells for monks. UNESCO has 
included the ‘Holy Mount’ in its 
World Heritage Monument List 
in 1988, on grounds of the 
outstanding architecture and 
the priceless cultural treasures 
of the monastic community.
How to get there. 
Petralona Cave is situated  
53 km SE of Thessaloniki. Take 
the coach to Halkidiki, get 
off at Nea Kallikrateia Village 
stop and then take a taxi to 
the cave (approx. a 10-km 
journey). If you travel by car, 
go along the Thessaloniki-
Halkidiki national road and  
then follow the signs to 
Petralona village and the cave.
5 	LAKES AREA
Northeast of Thessaloniki, in 
the direction of Strymonas 
(also Strymonian) gulf 
stretches a 200,000 hectare-
area around Lakes Koroneia 
and Volvi; the place is a 
National Park.']

['<1-hop>

105 Hellenic Professional Yacht Owners Association: Marina Zeas (Administration Building), 185 36 – Piraeus tel.: 210 45.26.335 fax: 210 42.80.465 website: www.hpyoa.gr MARINA The Thessaloniki Marina is located in Aretsou Kalamaria, tel.: \x072310 444.598, 2310 444.541 (Port Authority) fax: 2310 444.585 VHF: Channel 9 (24-hour service) website: www.thessaloniki-marina.gr BEACHES Go for a swim in Aretsou beach (Kalamaria, see p. 64) and the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, Angelochori (see p. 68) and the beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). A bit farther away, you can try the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). At a 60 – 90 min. distance from the city you will reach the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92). MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. response:
Halkidiki is a must-visit destination for beach lovers. Some popular beaches to visit in Halkidiki include:

*   Aretsou beach, located in Kassandra, which is a short drive from Thessaloniki (about 60-90 minutes).
*   Peraia beach, which is also located in Kassandra and is easily accessible by car or bus from Thessaloniki.
*   Agia Triada beach, located in the Sithonia peninsula, which is about a 45-minute drive from Thessaloniki.
*   Nea Michaniona beach, located in the Sithonia peninsula, which is about a 45-minute drive from Thessaloniki.
*   Asprovalta beach, located in the Strymonian gulf, which is about a 30-minute drive from Thessaloniki.
*   Nea Vrasna beach, located in the Strymonian gulf, which is about a 30-minute drive from Thessaloniki.
*   Stavros beach, located in the Strymonian gulf, which is about a 30-minute drive from Thessaloniki.

All of these beaches offer stunning views, crystal-clear waters, and a range of amenities and activities. They are easily accessible by car or bus from Thessaloniki, making them perfect for a weekend getaway.

If you're looking for a more unique experience, you can also visit the beaches in the Lake Koroneia area, which are located about an hour's drive from Thessaloniki. These beaches offer a serene and peaceful atmosphere, surrounded by beautiful scenery and picturesque villages.

Overall, Halkidiki has a wide range of beautiful beaches to suit all tastes and preferences. With its stunning natural beauty, rich history, and warm hospitality, it's the perfect destination for a relaxing and enjoyable weekend getaway.
reference: The very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki are located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. Some recommended beaches include Aretsou beach in Kalamaria, as well as the nearby beaches of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada.

user_input: What are some notable beaches in Halkidiki that travelers can visit, and how far are they from Thessaloniki?

BEACHES
Go for a swim in Aretsou beach 
(Kalamaria, see p. 64) and 
the nearby beaches of Peraia, 
Neoi Epivates, Agia Triada (see 
p. 67) or in Nea Michaniona, 
Angelochori (see p. 68) and the 
beaches in Epanomi (see p. 68). 
A bit farther away, you can try the 
beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea 
Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). 
At a 60 – 90 min. distance from 
the city you will reach the very 
popular and absolutely beautiful 
beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92).
MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS
Lagkadas Spa: 
Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki 
tel.', 'Such evidence 
makes this cave one of the 
oldest archaeological sites in 
Europe. Findings from the cave 
(tools, animal bones etc) are  
on display at the Museum  
and so are a cast of the skull  
(the original is kept at the 
Geology-Palaeontology Museum  
of the Aristotle University  
of Thessaloniki, see p. 38) and  
a reconstruction of the place  
it was found.
4.1  Halkidiki (also 
Chalcidice or Chalkidiki) – 
Agio Oros [Holy Mount].
Homeland of Aristotle,  
the ancient Greek philosopher, 
Halkidiki is one of the best 
and most popular tourist 
destinations in Greece with 
an important history, bustling 
tourist resorts, traditional 
villages, enchanting beaches, 
verdant mountains and an 
intense night life. Located 
south of Thessaloniki, 
Halkidiki ends in the three 
leg-shaped peninsulas named 
Kassandra, Sithonia and 
Athos. Thessalonians swarm 
in Kassandra and Sithonia for 
110.  
One of 
Halkidiki’s 
numerous 
lovely beaches.
111.  
Mount 
Athos: Agios 
Panteleimonas 
Monastery.
110', 'Another option for you 
is to go swimming in the 
beautiful beaches by the 
seaside suburbs and city 
outskirts (see p. 63-69), in 
places within the regional 
unit of Thessaloniki (see p. 
91-95), and in Halkidiki (see 
p. 92). You can also visit the 
Magic Park (12th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Airport Road), 
the biggest amusement park 
in Greece, which attracts 
children, teenagers, grown-
ups and families alike  
(www.magicpark.gr); the 
WaterLand is another 
fun option as there are 
waterpools, waterslides  
of various sizes, with different 
levels of difficulty, restaurants 
and mini markets. It is 
located in Tagarades,  
Thermi area, (see p. 66).
TOURING THESSALONIKI WITH CHILDREN
123', '93
DAY EXCURSIONS
a day trip (it’s only a short 
distance from the city) or 
for a longer one; quite a few 
own country houses there. In 
the Athos peninsula amidst 
a beautiful and pristine 
natural environment lies the 
globally known monastic 
state of Mount Athos which 
encompasses 20 -presently 
inhabited- monasteries 
(10th – 14th c.), sketes [small 
monastic settlements] and 
cells for monks. UNESCO has 
included the ‘Holy Mount’ in its 
World Heritage Monument List 
in 1988, on grounds of the 
outstanding architecture and 
the priceless cultural treasures 
of the monastic community.
How to get there. 
Petralona Cave is situated  
53 km SE of Thessaloniki. Take 
the coach to Halkidiki, get 
off at Nea Kallikrateia Village 
stop and then take a taxi to 
the cave (approx. a 10-km 
journey). If you travel by car, 
go along the Thessaloniki-
Halkidiki national road and  
then follow the signs to 
Petralona village and the cave.
5 	LAKES AREA
Northeast of Thessaloniki, in 
the direction of Strymonas 
(also Strymonian) gulf 
stretches a 200,000 hectare-
area around Lakes Koroneia 
and Volvi; the place is a 
National Park.', '95
gulf. You will find a marine 
sports and a beach volleyball 
facility on Asprovalta beach 
(10 km long and awarded a 
Blue Flag) and on Nea Vrasna 
beach; Stavros is the biggest 
harbour in the gulf. Vrasna 
and Ano Stavros villages 
are situated at the foot of 
Mt Kerdylia; their traditional 
architecture makes them 
absolutely worth visiting.
How to get there. From 
Thessaloniki, take the 83, 
83M or 83N bus line to reach 
Lagkadas. For the other areas, 
travel by coach. If you go 
by car, head for Panorama, 
Chortiatis and Agios Vasileios 
(to reach Lake Koroneia) 
and from that point go east 
towards Kavala (to visit Lake 
Volvi and the Strymonian gulf).
6 	PIKROLIMNI 
It is located in the 
neighbouring Kilkis regional 
unit, to the south. It is a 
shallow lake (covering a 
450-hectare area) and in 
the lake floor mud there are 
chemical combinations such 
as sulphides and nitric salts 
with healing and cosmetic 
properties known across the 
country - the concentration 
is three times higher than 
that in the Dead Sea. In the 
neighbouring Xylokeratia 
village you can visit the first 
Mud-therapy (Spa) Centre 
in the Balkans.']

A bit farther away, you can try the beaches in Asprovalta area, Nea Vrasna and Stavros (see p. 94). At a 60 – 90 min. distance from the city you will reach the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches of Halkidiki (see p. 92). MINERAL SPRINGS – SPAS Lagkadas Spa: Location: Lagkadas, Thessaloniki tel.: 23940 22.221 website: www.loutralagada.gr Nea Apollonia Spa: tel.: 23930 41.207 (Town Hall), 23930 41.510, 23930 42.151 (Spa facility) Souroti Spring (where natural mineral water is bottled): Location: Souroti, Thessaloniki tel.: 23960 41.182 (name of bottling company: Souroti A.E.), website: www.souroti.gr) Mud Therapy Spa Centre (Pikrolimni): Xylokeratia, Kilkis tel.: 23410 29.971-3 website: www.pikrolimnispa.gr TRANSPORT Buses. The urban bus service network covers all city areas. The main bus termini are at the Railway Station (see p. 58), in Venizelou Street (Eleftherias square, see p. 17), and Aristotelous square (see p. 15); also at the interchange stations in Stavroupoli (see p. 61), at K.T.E.L. (intercity bus station), IKEA (Pylaia area) and Lagkadas (see p. 93). Buses run from 5 am until midnight, yet there are certain lines running after midnight connecting major junctions. You can purchase a bus pass (one-month, three- months or an annual one) or use a ticket: the one-way basic type, the ticket valid for two trips for a 70-min. period, the ticket valid for three trips for a 90-min. period and the ticket valid for four trips for a 120-min. period, towards any direction on any bus route. You will find ticket boxes in central locations, at the interchange stations and there are also ticket machines inside the buses. Tickets must be validated on the first trip (bus routes info in Greek: tel.: 11085 website: www.oasth.gr. Cultural route: The 50 bus service runs by the city’s major historical and cultural monuments starting from the White Tower and following a circular 50 min. route. On the way, passengers can get information on the monuments using the audiovisual material and pamphlets supplied (in Greek and in English). Bus no. 22 follows a circular route in Ano Poli and Mouschounti square is the terminus. Sightseeing tours can also be taken in open top tourist buses, starting from the White Tower. It is a 70-min. tour in 8 languages. Makedonia International Airport of Thessaloniki. It is situated in Mikra area, 15 km SE of the city centre (tel. 2310 985.000). There is a bus service (no. 78 by day and no. 78N by night) connecting the airport with the Railway Station and the Intercity bus station (K.T.E.L.); the 79 bus runs from A.S. IKEA station to the airport. Olympic Air: information – bookings tel.: 8018010101 website: www.olympicair.com Aegean Airlines: information – bookings tel.: \x078011120.000 (from a fixed line) 210 62.61.000 (from a cell phone) website: www.aegeanair.com', '<2-hop>

PANORAMA One of the best suburbs of Thessaloniki is situated at a 12 km distance S of the city centre and was built on the slope of Mt Chortiatis, offering a panoramic city view. It was uninhabited until the early 20th c., although traces of a prehistoric settlement have been located on the area. The first inhabitants were refugees from Asia Minor and Pontus. Today its largest part is covered by luxury villas and impressive detached homes; there is a small shopping area in the centre. Trigona Panoramatos [a cream puff pastry] – one of the city’s best known sweet delicacies – were created at a local confectionery in the 1950’s. MUST SEE: Platanakia. It is a nice place for relaxing, in a wooded ravine, with a small Zoo and a café. A 6 km path begins here and leads up to the artificial lake (dam) of Thermi. Along the way you will come across spots for a brief rest, short waterfalls and fragments of eight Byzantine watermills. 11 12 13 14 KONSTANTINOUPOLEOS SSIS OLGAS GIOU PAPANDREOU ROSIDI ROSIDI GEORGIOU PAPANDREOU APAFI MARKOU BOTSARI PAPANASTASIOU ANATOLIKIS THRAKIS PAPANASTASIOU VOULGARI KANARI KANARI KARAKASI KARAKASI DELFON GAVRIILIDI TH. For a leisurely weekend getaway, I recommend visiting the beaches in Kassandra and Sithonia, which are located in the southern part of Halkidiki. These beaches offer stunning views of the Aegean Sea and are easily accessible from Thessaloniki.

The nearest beach to Thessaloniki is in Peraia, which is approximately 30-40 minutes away. From there, you can head to the nearby beaches of Agia Triada and Neoi Epivates. These beaches are known for their crystal-clear waters and picturesque surroundings.

Another popular beach destination is in Nea Kallikrateia Village, which is about 53 km southeast of Thessaloniki. From there, you can take a taxi or bus to the Petralona Cave, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

For a more relaxing experience, consider visiting the beaches in Asprovalta, which are approximately 10 km away from Stavros. These beaches offer a tranquil atmosphere and stunning views of the Strymonian Gulf.

Lastly, if you're looking for a unique experience, visit the beaches in Lake Koroneia, which are about 200 km northeast of Thessaloniki. These beaches offer a serene atmosphere and breathtaking views of the surrounding landscape.

All of these beaches are easily accessible by car, bus, or taxi, and offer a range of amenities and activities for travelers. Whether you're looking for relaxation, adventure, or a mix of both, these beaches in Halkidiki have something for everyone.
reference: The notable beaches in Halkidiki that travelers can visit include the very popular and absolutely beautiful beaches located at a distance of 60 to 90 minutes from Thessaloniki. These beaches are renowned for their scenic beauty and are a great option for those looking to enjoy a swim and relax by the sea.

user_input: What historical significance does Thessaloniki's Old Town hold in relation to its Macedonian heritage and how does it connect to the Roman Forum?
retrieved_contexts:
['6
Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.
1. 
The White Tower 
area is one of the 
busiest parts of 
the city, where 
the old seafront 
(Nikis Ave.) meets 
the new (eastern) 
waterfront area 
of Thessaloniki.
DION – VERGINA – ANCIENT PELLA
PETRALONA CAVE – LAKES AREA
THESSALONIKI', '70
ARCHAEOLOGICAL MUSEUM 
OF THESSALONIKI
Works of art of outstanding 
value and excavated ensembles 
from the entire region of 
Macedonia are on display, 
covering all the aspects of 
private and public life in the 
area, from the prehistoric era 
to the late antiquity period. 
Exhibits are organised in six 
basic categories:
• Towards the birth of towns. 
(ground floor, room 4). The 
evidence on display shows 
that there were settlements in 
Macedonia dating to the Iron 
Age, from 1100 to 700 BC.
• Macedonia from the 7th c.  
BC until Late Antiquity. 
(ground floor, room 5). Eight 
large theme sections cover 
various aspects of private 
and public life in Macedonia 
from the archaic years, when 
the independent Macedonian 
kingdom was created, until 
the 1st – 4th c. AD, when the 
entire region was a province 
of the Roman Empire. Finds 
come mainly from excavations 
carried out in areas of central 
Macedonia.
• Thessaloniki, Metropolis 
of Macedonia. (ground 
floor, room 6). Historical and 
archaeological information 
is presented, starting from 
315 BC when the town was 
founded. There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an 
archaic temple of Ionic order, 
whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of 
Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.', '7
«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.', '71
courtyard). Antiquities dating to 
the 2nd – 4th c. AD are divided in 
two sections: in the first one a 
reconstruction is attempted of 
a cemetery segment containing 
finds, sarcophagi and altars; 
the second one involves the 
re-creation of a Greco-roman 
house with mosaic floors on 
display and items of daily use.
• Prehistoric Macedonia. 
(basement, room 11). The 
items exhibited refer to Man’s 
first productive stages in 
Macedonia (with activities such 
as hunting, fishing, agriculture, 
stock farming, weaving, 
metallurgy). There are also 
casts of skulls belonging to 
Ouranopithecus Macedoniensis, 
an early hominid primate, as 
well as of the Man found in 
Petralona cave (see p. 92).
• Temporary exhibitions. 
The museum organises each 
year a major thematic exhibition 
and 2-5 minor ones, where 
particular aspects of every day 
life in Macedonia are treated in 
connection with the Greek and 
the Mediterranean area.
THE ROMAN FORUM 
MUSEUM
Small yet very interesting, 
this museum was inaugurated 
in 2010. A narrative of local 
excavations and information 
on the museum’s building 
stages is on display in the 
vestibule; in the main hall, 
visitors will see a depiction 
of the area’s history from the 
Hellenistic years until the 4th 
c. AD.', '42
Thessaloniki’s Old Town is 
full of atmosphere. It covers 
the area in between the city 
walls (to the north and east) 
and Olympiados Street (to 
the south), and has had the 
luck to remain untouched by 
the 1917 great fire. It was 
virtually uninhabited until 
the mid-15th century, when 
it was conquered by the 
Ottomans who selected it for 
settlement on account of its 
fine climate, panoramic views 
and strategic position. The 
two and three-storey houses 
bear mixed Macedonian 
and Ottoman architectural 
elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş 
in turkish]; there are also 
residences with neoclassical 
and eclectic style motifs 
where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. 
converts to Islam who secretly 
remained Jews. After 1922 
many refugees settled in the 
area. Despite the construction 
of newer buildings and the 
opening up of new streets in 
recent decades, it has kept 
its original town planning, to 
a large extent, with narrow 
alleys and scant squares, as 
well as its original architectural 
features, particularly in the 
west and east part of the town. 
This particular atmosphere has 
lured intellects, artists 
and students who chose it  
for settlement in recent years.

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town holds significant historical importance due to its connection to the city's Macedonian heritage and the Roman Empire. As the historic capital of Macedonia, the land of Alexander the Great, Thessaloniki's Old Town has evolved into a charming metropolis, boasting a rich cultural landscape. The area's strategic position and fine climate made it an attractive settlement for the Ottomans in the mid-15th century, who later selected it for habitation. The town's original architecture, including mixed Macedonian and Ottoman elements, has been preserved, giving it a unique atmosphere.

The Old Town's connection to the Macedonian heritage is evident in its historical landmarks, such as the Church of Agia Aikaterini, which dates back to the 19th century. The area's cultural significance extends to its association with the Roman Empire, as evidenced by the Roman Forum Museum, which showcases the history of the city from the Hellenistic years to the 4th century AD.

The Roman Forum Museum is located within the city walls and is easily accessible from Thessaloniki's Old Town. Visitors can explore the museum's exhibits, which include a narrative of local excavations and information on the museum's building stages. The museum offers a unique insight into the city's history, highlighting its importance as a major urban center during the Roman Empire.

In summary, Thessaloniki's Old Town holds significant historical importance due to its connection to the city's Macedonian heritage and the Roman Empire. The area's unique architecture, cultural landmarks, and museums provide a rich cultural experience for visitors, making it an ideal destination for those seeking to explore the city's history and heritage.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is significant for its Macedonian heritage as it showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, reflecting the city's historical evolution. The area remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, preserving its original town planning and narrow alleys. This atmosphere has attracted artists and students, emphasizing its cultural importance. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, connects to this heritage by highlighting the city's historical role as a significant urban center in Macedonia. The Forum's construction in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and its gradual abandonment after the 7th century further illustrate the layered history of Thessaloniki, linking its Macedonian roots to its Roman past.

Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.
1. 
The White Tower 
area is one of the 
busiest parts of 
the city, where 
the old seafront 
(Nikis Ave.) meets 
the new (eastern) 
waterfront area 
of Thessaloniki.
DION – VERGINA – ANCIENT PELLA
PETRALONA CAVE – LAKES AREA
THESSALONIKI', '70
ARCHAEOLOGICAL MUSEUM 
OF THESSALONIKI
Works of art of outstanding 
value and excavated ensembles 
from the entire region of 
Macedonia are on display, 
covering all the aspects of 
private and public life in the 
area, from the prehistoric era 
to the late antiquity period. 
Exhibits are organised in six 
basic categories:
• Towards the birth of towns. 
(ground floor, room 4). The 
evidence on display shows 
that there were settlements in 
Macedonia dating to the Iron 
Age, from 1100 to 700 BC.
• Macedonia from the 7th c.  
BC until Late Antiquity. 
(ground floor, room 5). Eight 
large theme sections cover 
various aspects of private 
and public life in Macedonia 
from the archaic years, when 
the independent Macedonian 
kingdom was created, until 
the 1st – 4th c. AD, when the 
entire region was a province 
of the Roman Empire. Finds 
come mainly from excavations 
carried out in areas of central 
Macedonia.
• Thessaloniki, Metropolis 
of Macedonia. (ground 
floor, room 6). Historical and 
archaeological information 
is presented, starting from 
315 BC when the town was 
founded. There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an 
archaic temple of Ionic order, 
whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of 
Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.', '7
«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.', '42
Thessaloniki’s Old Town is 
full of atmosphere. It covers 
the area in between the city 
walls (to the north and east) 
and Olympiados Street (to 
the south), and has had the 
luck to remain untouched by 
the 1917 great fire. It was 
virtually uninhabited until 
the mid-15th century, when 
it was conquered by the 
Ottomans who selected it for 
settlement on account of its 
fine climate, panoramic views 
and strategic position. The 
two and three-storey houses 
bear mixed Macedonian 
and Ottoman architectural 
elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş 
in turkish]; there are also 
residences with neoclassical 
and eclectic style motifs 
where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. 
converts to Islam who secretly 
remained Jews. After 1922 
many refugees settled in the 
area. Despite the construction 
of newer buildings and the 
opening up of new streets in 
recent decades, it has kept 
its original town planning, to 
a large extent, with narrow 
alleys and scant squares, as 
well as its original architectural 
features, particularly in the 
west and east part of the town. 
This particular atmosphere has 
lured intellects, artists 
and students who chose it  
for settlement in recent years.

response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town is a treasure trove of historical significance, deeply rooted in its Macedonian heritage. As the historic capital of Macedonia, the city has been a hub of cultural and architectural influences, with a rich history dating back to the 14th century. The town's strategic position and fine climate made it an attractive settlement for the Ottomans, who arrived in the mid-15th century. Today, visitors can stroll through the narrow alleys and quaint squares, admiring the mix of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, such as the sachnisia style.

The connection to the Roman Forum is evident in the archaeological sites surrounding the city. The Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki, located on Manoli Andronikou Street, houses an impressive collection of artifacts from the Roman era, including the Museum of the Roman Forum. This museum is a must-visit for anyone interested in the Roman legacy, offering a glimpse into the city's rich history.

The Roman Forum, in particular, is a testament to Thessaloniki's importance as a Roman province. The site features several ruins, including a forum, basilica, and temples, which provide a unique insight into the city's past. Visitors can explore the site, taking in the remains of the ancient structures and imagining life in ancient Thessaloniki.

In the summer, Thessaloniki's Old Town comes alive with festivals and events, celebrating its Macedonian heritage and cultural diversity. Visitors can immerse themselves in the local culture, attending concerts, performances, and traditional events. The town's vibrant atmosphere, combined with its rich history, makes it an unforgettable destination for any traveler.

In summary, Thessaloniki's Old Town is a historical gem, offering a glimpse into the city's Macedonian heritage and its connection to the Roman Forum. Visitors can explore the town's narrow alleys, admire the architectural mix, and delve into the city's rich history, making it an ideal destination for anyone seeking a unique cultural experience.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is significant for its Macedonian heritage as it showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, reflecting the city's diverse history. The area remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, preserving its original town planning and atmosphere, which has attracted artists and students. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, further emphasizes the historical depth of Thessaloniki. The Forum's construction in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD and its gradual abandonment after the 7th century highlight the city's evolution through different eras, including its Macedonian roots.

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town.
