response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town holds great historical significance as it was the site of the city's early settlement, dating back to the 15th century when it was conquered by the Ottomans. The town's unique blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, including the sachnisia style, can be seen in its two- and three-storey houses. This blend of cultures is a testament to the city's rich heritage and its role as a crossroads between the Roman Empire and the Byzantine Empire.

Regarding its connection to the Roman Forum, Thessaloniki's Old Town is situated near the historic city walls and Olympiados Street, which marks the southern boundary of the old town. The Roman Forum, while not directly adjacent to the old town, is an important historical site that can be visited separately. However, the old town's proximity to the city walls and its own history of occupation by various empires, including the Romans, connects it to the broader historical context of the region.

Thessaloniki's Old Town is also home to several landmarks, including the Agia Iakaterini Church, which dates back to the 19th century and features neoclassical architectural elements. This church, along with other historical sites in the old town, provides a glimpse into the city's complex history and its role in the region's cultural and economic development.

Visitors to Thessaloniki's Old Town can explore its narrow alleys, quaint squares, and historic buildings, which offer a unique and immersive experience of the city's rich heritage. The old town's atmosphere, with its mix of ancient and modern elements, provides a fascinating backdrop for sightseeing and exploration. As a solo traveler, you can easily navigate the old town, taking in its historical significance and cultural attractions, and connecting it to the broader context of the Roman Forum and the city's Macedonian heritage.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is significant for its Macedonian heritage as it showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, reflecting the city's diverse history. The area remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, preserving its original town planning and atmosphere, which has attracted artists and intellects. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, connects to this heritage as it highlights the city's historical importance from ancient times through the Byzantine era, further enriching the cultural tapestry of Thessaloniki.

['6
Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

THESSALONIKI', '70
ARCHAEOLOGICAL MUSEUM 
OF THESSALONIKI
Works of art of outstanding 
value and excavated ensembles 
from the entire region of 
Macedonia are on display, 
covering all the aspects of 
private and public life in the 
area, from the prehistoric era 
to the late antiquity period. 
Exhibits are organised in six 
basic categories:
• Towards the birth of towns. 
(ground floor, room 4). The 
evidence on display shows 
that there were settlements in 
Macedonia dating to the Iron 
Age, from 1100 to 700 BC.
• Macedonia from the 7th c.  
BC until Late Antiquity. 
(ground floor, room 5). Eight 
large theme sections cover 
various aspects of private 
and public life in Macedonia 
from the archaic years, when 
the independent Macedonian 
kingdom was created, until 
the 1st – 4th c. AD, when the 
entire region was a province 
of the Roman Empire. Finds 
come mainly from excavations 
carried out in areas of central 
Macedonia.
• Thessaloniki, Metropolis 
of Macedonia. (ground 
floor, room 6). Historical and 
archaeological information 
is presented, starting from 
315 BC when the town was 
founded. There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an 
archaic temple of Ionic order, 
whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of 
Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.', '71
courtyard). Antiquities dating to 
the 2nd – 4th c. AD are divided in 
two sections: in the first one a

• Prehistoric Macedonia. 
(basement, room 11). The

The museum organises each 
year a major thematic exhibition 
and 2-5 minor ones, where

Roman (Ancient) Forum During the roman period, this 2-hectare area used to be the social and religious centre of the city. Construction was completed in two phases (in the mid-2nd and mid- 3rd centuries AD) and it was gradually abandoned after the 7th century. The NW section of the archaeological site is covered by a large rectangular square [Α] with traces of marble paving. In the S section of the square lies the largest part of the double underground Cryptoporticus [covered passageway] [Β] which was most probably used as a public storehouse. response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town holds significant historical importance, having been untouched by the 1917 great fire and retaining its original town planning, architecture, and atmosphere. The Ottomans conquered the area in the mid-15th century, bringing a mix of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements. This blend of cultures is still visible today. The Old Town is also home to the Agia Aikaterini Church, a notable landmark. 

In contrast, the Roman Forum Museum showcases Macedonia's cultural heritage, focusing on the Hellenistic years until the 4th century AD. The museum's narrative covers the area's history, from the Roman Empire to the Byzantine legacy of Northern Greece. The Roman Forum itself is a testament to the region's strategic importance, with its unique blend of cultures and architectural styles. The museum's depiction of the area's history highlights the significance of Thessaloniki as a hub of trade and commerce.

The connection between Thessaloniki's Old Town and the Roman Forum lies in their shared cultural heritage. Both areas have been shaped by the region's complex history, with the Ottomans and Romans leaving their mark on the city. The Old Town's preservation of its original architecture and atmosphere is a testament to the enduring legacy of these cultures. The Roman Forum Museum, meanwhile, provides a tangible connection to the past, offering visitors a glimpse into the region's rich history.

For a solo traveler seeking familiar experiences, Thessaloniki's Old Town and the Roman Forum Museum offer a unique blend of history, culture, and atmosphere. The Old Town's charm and the Roman Forum's narrative provide a compelling narrative for visitors looking to explore Macedonia's cultural heritage. The museum's focus on the Hellenistic years until the 4th century AD highlights the significance of Thessaloniki as a hub of trade and commerce, making it an essential stop for anyone interested in learning more about the region's history.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is historically significant as it has remained largely untouched since the 1917 great fire and showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements. It was settled by the Ottomans in the mid-15th century due to its favorable climate and strategic position. The Roman Forum, on the other hand, served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, with construction completed in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD. Both sites reflect the rich cultural heritage of Macedonia, illustrating the city's evolution through different historical periods and influences.

['70
ARCHAEOLOGICAL MUSEUM 
OF THESSALONIKI
Works of art of outstanding 
value and excavated ensembles 
from the entire region of 
Macedonia are on display, 
covering all the aspects of 
private and public life in the 
area, from the prehistoric era 
to the late antiquity period. 
Exhibits are organised in six 
basic categories:
• Towards the birth of towns. 
(ground floor, room 4). The 
evidence on display shows 
that there were settlements in 
Macedonia dating to the Iron 
Age, from 1100 to 700 BC.
• Macedonia from the 7th c.  
BC until Late Antiquity. 
(ground floor, room 5). Eight 
large theme sections cover 
various aspects of private 
and public life in Macedonia 
from the archaic years, when 
the independent Macedonian 
kingdom was created, until 
the 1st – 4th c. AD, when the 
entire region was a province 
of the Roman Empire. Finds 
come mainly from excavations 
carried out in areas of central 
Macedonia.
• Thessaloniki, Metropolis 
of Macedonia. (ground 
floor, room 6). Historical and 
archaeological information 
is presented, starting from 
315 BC when the town was 
founded. There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an 
archaic temple of Ionic order, 
whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of 
Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.', '6
Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.
1. 
The White Tower 
area is one of the 
busiest parts of 
the city, where 
the old seafront 
(Nikis Ave.) meets 
the new (eastern) 
waterfront area 
of Thessaloniki.
DION – VERGINA – ANCIENT PELLA
PETRALONA CAVE – LAKES AREA
THESSALONIKI', '7
«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.', '71

and 2-5 minor ones, where

THE ROMAN FORUM 
MUSEUM
Small yet very interesting, 
this museum was inaugurated 
in 2010. A narrative of local 
excavations and information 
on the museum’s building 
stages is on display in the 
vestibule; in the main hall, 
visitors will see a depiction 
of the area’s history from the 
Hellenistic years until the 4th

MUSEUMS
• Discovering the past.

the procedure for creating and

• Temporary exhibitions

WHITE TOWER EXHIBITION
Starting from the year it was 
founded until the present day, 
the history of Thessaloniki is 
depicted through an array of 
multimedia applications, special 
structures, printed graphic 
design compositions and 
archaeological material. The 
exhibition is organised in seven 
thematic categories, each one 
occupying one floor, as follows: 
Space and Time (ground floor), 
Transformations (1st floor), 
Monuments and History (2nd 
floor), Homeland of the people 
(3rd floor), Along the trade 
routes (4th floor), Leisure and 
Culture (5th floor), Thessaloniki 
– Flavours (6th floor). The 
museum’s shop is located on 
the last floor.
JEWISH MUSEUM OF 
THESSALONIKI
It was created following 
an initiative of the Jewish 
Community of Thessaloniki  
to promote the Sephardic 
legacy in town, which dates  
as far back as the 15th c. It has 
been open to visitors since 
1997.']

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. Thessaloniki's Old Town is deeply rooted in its Macedonian heritage, with a rich history dating back to the city's foundation in the 4th century BC. The area is home to numerous monuments and cultural assets that showcase the city's multicultural past, including the White Tower and the ancient city walls. The Old Town's significance lies in its ability to preserve and display the city's history, from the ancient Macedonian kingdoms to the Roman and Byzantine periods.

The Roman Forum, located in the heart of the Old Town, plays a pivotal role in Thessaloniki's development. As a small yet very interesting museum, it offers a narrative of local excavations and information on the museum's building stages. The Roman Forum is a testament to the city's history from the Hellenistic years until the 4th century AD, providing visitors with a glimpse into the city's past. The museum's location within the Old Town highlights the significance of the area in preserving and showcasing Thessaloniki's Macedonian heritage.

The connection between the Old Town and the Roman Forum lies in their shared history and cultural significance. The Old Town's preservation of the city's history, including the Roman Forum, serves as a reminder of Thessaloniki's rich cultural heritage. Visitors to the Old Town can experience the city's history firsthand, with the Roman Forum providing a unique perspective on the city's development.

In summary, Thessaloniki's Old Town holds significant historical value in relation to its Macedonian heritage, with the Roman Forum serving as a key component in preserving and showcasing the city's history. The Old Town's preservation of the city's cultural significance makes it an essential destination for anyone interested in exploring Thessaloniki's rich heritage.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is significant for its Macedonian heritage as it showcases a blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, reflecting the city's diverse history. The area remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, preserving its original town planning and architectural features. This historical context is further enriched by the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period. Constructed in the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, the Forum highlights the city's importance in the region and its evolution over time, linking the Macedonian past with the Roman influence that shaped Thessaloniki's development.

['70
ARCHAEOLOGICAL MUSEUM 
OF THESSALONIKI
Works of art of outstanding 
value and excavated ensembles 
from the entire region of 
Macedonia are on display, 
covering all the aspects of 
private and public life in the 
area, from the prehistoric era 
to the late antiquity period. 
Exhibits are organised in six 
basic categories:
• Towards the birth of towns. 
(ground floor, room 4). The 
evidence on display shows 
that there were settlements in 
Macedonia dating to the Iron 
Age, from 1100 to 700 BC.
• Macedonia from the 7th c.  
BC until Late Antiquity. 
(ground floor, room 5). Eight 
large theme sections cover 
various aspects of private 
and public life in Macedonia 
from the archaic years, when 
the independent Macedonian 
kingdom was created, until 
the 1st – 4th c. AD, when the 
entire region was a province 
of the Roman Empire. Finds 
come mainly from excavations 
carried out in areas of central 
Macedonia.
• Thessaloniki, Metropolis 
of Macedonia. (ground 
floor, room 6). Historical and 
archaeological information 
is presented, starting from 
315 BC when the town was 
founded. There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an 
archaic temple of Ionic order, 
whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of 
Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.', '71
courtyard). Antiquities dating to 
the 2nd – 4th c. AD are divided in 
two sections: in the first one a 
reconstruction is attempted of 
a cemetery segment containing 
finds, sarcophagi and altars; 
the second one involves the 
re-creation of a Greco-roman 
house with mosaic floors on 
display and items of daily use.
• Prehistoric Macedonia. 
(basement, room 11). The 
items exhibited refer to Man’s 
first productive stages in 
Macedonia (with activities such 
as hunting, fishing, agriculture, 
stock farming, weaving, 
metallurgy). There are also 
casts of skulls belonging to 
Ouranopithecus Macedoniensis, 
an early hominid primate, as 
well as of the Man found in 
Petralona cave (see p. 92).
• Temporary exhibitions. 
The museum organises each 
year a major thematic exhibition 
and 2-5 minor ones, where 
particular aspects of every day 
life in Macedonia are treated in 
connection with the Greek and 
the Mediterranean area.
THE ROMAN FORUM 
MUSEUM
Small yet very interesting, 
this museum was inaugurated 
in 2010. A narrative of local 
excavations and information 
on the museum’s building 
stages is on display in the 
vestibule; in the main hall, 
visitors will see a depiction 
of the area’s history from the 
Hellenistic years until the 4th 
c. AD.', '6
Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.
1. 
The White Tower 
area is one of the 
busiest parts of 
the city, where 
the old seafront 
(Nikis Ave.) meets 
the new (eastern) 
waterfront area 
of Thessaloniki.
DION – VERGINA – ANCIENT PELLA
PETRALONA CAVE – LAKES AREA
THESSALONIKI', '7
«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.', '36

that the place had been used 
by Christians as well, during 
the late Roman period. South 
of the passageway there 
were shops dating from the 
1st until the 13th century; the 
underground Museum of the 
Roman Forum (see p. 71) was 
built there as an extension. 
A 2nd - 4th c. AD Odeon [C] 
was found behind the well-
preserved eastern stoa. It  
has been restored and it is now 
used as a venue for cultural 
events. A mint and an archive 
office are right next to it. In the 
SE side, a round bath house 
[D] was unearthed which has 
been in use since the 1st c. BC. 
Parts of a colonnade, mosaic 
floors, marble stairs, a section 
of a stone-paved street, sewer 
pipes, silver coins, stone and 
marble sculptures were all 
found in this archaeological 
site. The forum is also where 
the “Enchanted Ones” (las 
Incantadas) were discovered, 
a two-storeyed colonnaded 
archway with Corinthian-order 
columns and pillars four of 
which have survived. They are 
decorated with figures in relief 
in their interior as well as their 
exterior side (“Stoa of the 
Statuettes”).']

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki holds significant historical importance in relation to the city's Macedonian heritage. As the former capital of the Roman Empire, Thessaloniki was an important center of trade, culture, and politics, with the Roman Forum being a major hub of activity. The forum's archaeological site, which includes the Odeon, mint, and archive office, provides valuable insights into the city's Roman past and its connections to the wider Mediterranean world.

The Roman Forum is also notable for its association with the city's early Christian history, with evidence of Christian worship dating back to the 4th century AD. The forum's architecture and layout reflect the city's complex cultural heritage, with a blend of Roman, Greek, and Byzantine influences.

In the context of Thessaloniki's Macedonian heritage, the Roman Forum represents a unique intersection of Greek and Roman cultural traditions. The forum's remains demonstrate the city's status as a major center of trade and commerce, with connections to the ancient world extending back to the 4th century BC.

The Roman Forum's historical significance is further underscored by its association with the city's rich cultural and artistic heritage. The forum's architecture, art, and artifacts provide a window into the city's complex cultural history, with a blend of Roman, Greek, and Byzantine influences.

Overall, the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki holds significant historical importance in relation to the city's Macedonian heritage, offering a unique glimpse into the city's complex cultural history and its connections to the wider Mediterranean world. Its archaeological site, cultural significance, and artistic importance make it an essential destination for anyone interested in exploring Thessaloniki's rich cultural heritage.
reference: The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, reflects the city's Macedonian heritage. Constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, it showcases the architectural and cultural influences of the time. The forum was gradually abandoned after the 7th century, but its remnants, including a large rectangular square and the double underground Cryptoporticus, highlight the historical significance of Thessaloniki as a key location in Macedonia.

Thessaloniki’s Old Town is 
full of atmosphere. It covers

and Olympiados Street (to

it was conquered by the

Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

ARCHAEOLOGICAL MUSEUM

Works of art of outstanding 
value and excavated ensembles 
from the entire region of 
Macedonia are on display, 
covering all the aspects of 
private and public life in the 
area, from the prehistoric era 
to the late antiquity period. 
Exhibits are organised in six 
basic categories:
• Towards the birth of towns. 
(ground floor, room 4). The 
evidence on display shows 
that there were settlements in 
Macedonia dating to the Iron 
Age, from 1100 to 700 BC.
• Macedonia from the 7th c.  
BC until Late Antiquity. 
(ground floor, room 5). Eight 
large theme sections cover 
various aspects of private 
and public life in Macedonia 
from the archaic years, when 
the independent Macedonian 
kingdom was created, until 
the 1st – 4th c. AD, when the 
entire region was a province 
of the Roman Empire. Finds 
come mainly from excavations 
carried out in areas of central 
Macedonia.
• Thessaloniki, Metropolis 
of Macedonia. (ground 
floor, room 6). Historical and 
archaeological information 
is presented, starting from 
315 BC when the town was 
founded. There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an

whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of

«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»

Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.', 'There is also a

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. This particular atmosphere has lured intellects, artists and students who chose it for settlement in recent years. 1 \x07AGIA AIKATERINI [SAINT CATHERINE] CHURCH (see p. 12) NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. response:
Thessaloniki's Old Town is a treasure trove of historical significance, boasting a rich architectural style that reflects the city's multicultural past. During the Ottoman period, the town was influenced by Macedonian culture, which left an indelible mark on its architecture. The town's narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east parts of the town, have been preserved to a large extent. This has allowed visitors to experience the authentic atmosphere of the city, which has lured intellects, artists, and students to the area in recent years.

The town's unique blend of Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, known as sachnisia, can be seen in the two- and three-storey houses that dot the streets. These buildings bear the scars of the city's turbulent past, with the 1917 great fire leaving some areas relatively untouched. The Ottomans, who conquered the town in the mid-15th century, selected it for settlement due to its fine climate, panoramic views, and strategic position. The Dönmeh, converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews, also left their mark on the town, with residences featuring neoclassical and eclectic style motifs.

Thessaloniki's Old Town is a living testament to the city's history, with many of its original buildings still standing today. Visitors can walk in the footsteps of Alexander the Great, who founded the city in 315 BC, and experience the vibrant culture that has made Thessaloniki a hub for intellectuals, artists, and students. The town's rich history is palpable, and its architecture is a testament to the city's enduring legacy as a center of learning, art, and culture. Whether you're a history buff or simply looking for a unique experience, Thessaloniki's Old Town is a must-visit destination.
reference: Thessaloniki's Old Town is historically significant as it showcases a blend of architectural styles that reflect its Macedonian heritage and the influence of the Ottoman period. The area, which remained largely untouched by the 1917 great fire, features two and three-storey houses that exhibit mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements, known as sachnisia. This unique combination of styles, along with neoclassical and eclectic motifs, highlights the town's rich cultural history. The settlement of the Ottomans in the mid-15th century, attracted by the region's fine climate and strategic position, further contributed to the architectural landscape, making it a vibrant center for intellects, artists, and students in recent years.

Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit

the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.']

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. response:
The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki is a historical site of great significance, showcasing the city's rich cultural heritage and its strategic location within the Roman Empire. Dating back to the late 2nd to early 3rd century AD, the forum features a slab-paved square surrounded by arcades and public buildings, including the luxury houses of Epigenis and Evvoulos, decorated with exquisite mosaics. The forum also includes a Roman basilica, an area for trade and banking transactions, and the Monument of the Shields, with shield and cuirass depictions.

The Roman Forum's historical significance is deeply rooted in its connection to the Roman Empire, which had a profound impact on Macedonia. The forum's architecture reflects the Roman influence, with its use of marble and mosaic floors, Vespasian urinals, and entertainment areas. The site's layout and design demonstrate the Roman's engineering prowess, with its carefully planned and executed layout.

The Roman Forum's architectural influences can be seen throughout Macedonia, particularly in the region's ancient cities. The forum's use of Roman architectural elements, such as the basilica and the use of marble and mosaics, is a testament to the region's cultural exchange with the Roman Empire. The forum's layout and design also reflect the Roman's emphasis on public spaces and civic engagement.

In Thessaloniki, the Roman Forum is a must-visit site for anyone interested in history, architecture, and culture. Its significance extends beyond its historical importance, as it provides a glimpse into the daily lives of ancient Macedonians. The forum's well-preserved state and its connection to the Roman Empire make it an invaluable resource for historians and enthusiasts alike. As a solo traveler, you can easily spend a weekend exploring the Roman Forum and its surroundings, taking in the sights and sounds of this incredible historical site.
reference: The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, showcases significant historical importance as it was constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD. This area reflects the architectural influences of the time, which can also be seen in the mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements present in Thessaloniki’s Old Town. The forum's gradual abandonment after the 7th century and the remnants of its structures, such as the double underground Cryptoporticus, highlight the city's rich historical tapestry, which is deeply intertwined with the broader architectural heritage of Macedonia.

Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.
1. 
The White Tower 
area is one of the 
busiest parts of 
the city, where 
the old seafront 
(Nikis Ave.) meets 
the new (eastern) 
waterfront area 
of Thessaloniki.
DION – VERGINA – ANCIENT PELLA
PETRALONA CAVE – LAKES AREA
THESSALONIKI', '36
4th walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
that the place had been used 
by Christians as well, during 
the late Roman period. South 
of the passageway there 
were shops dating from the 
1st until the 13th century; the 
underground Museum of the 
Roman Forum (see p. 71) was 
built there as an extension. 
A 2nd - 4th c. AD Odeon [C] 
was found behind the well-
preserved eastern stoa. It  
has been restored and it is now 
used as a venue for cultural 
events. A mint and an archive 
office are right next to it. In the 
SE side, a round bath house 
[D] was unearthed which has 
been in use since the 1st c. BC. 
Parts of a colonnade, mosaic 
floors, marble stairs, a section 
of a stone-paved street, sewer 
pipes, silver coins, stone and 
marble sculptures were all 
found in this archaeological 
site. The forum is also where 
the “Enchanted Ones” (las 
Incantadas) were discovered, 
a two-storeyed colonnaded 
archway with Corinthian-order 
columns and pillars four of 
which have survived. They are 
decorated with figures in relief 
in their interior as well as their 
exterior side (“Stoa of the 
Statuettes”).', '8
 315 BC:	
26 adjoining townlets 
merge to form Thessaloniki. 
The town is founded by 
Cassander, King of Macedonia, 
and named after his wife 
Thessaloniki – half sister  
to Alexander the Great.
 168 BC:	
The Romans take the city 
over.
 148 BC:	
It becomes the capital  
town of the roman province 
of Macedonia.
 130 BC:	
Construction of Via Egnatia 
which connected the town 
with the then known world.
 circa 50 BC:	
Cicero, the Roman orator 
becomes a resident. 
 42 BC:	
Thessaloniki is declared  
a “free town” (civitas libera).
 50 BC:	
Apostle Paul’s first visit  
to the town. He came back 
seven years later. 
 Late 3rd – early 4th c. AD:	
Becomes the seat of  
the eastern section of the 
Roman Empire [according  
to the system of Tetrarchia – 
(meaning “leadership of four 
men”)] under ceasar Galerius 
Maximianus.
 323 BC:	
Constantine, the first 
emperor of Byzantium settles 
in town in order to wage war 
on Licinius.
 Late 4th AD:	
The town becomes  
the administrative centre  
of Macedonia; Byzantine 
emperor Theodosius builds  
the fortifications of Thessaloniki. 
 5th - 12th c.:	
Raids by Goths, Persians, 
Arabs, Turks and Bulgarians.']

["<1-hop>

42 Thessaloniki’s Old Town is full of atmosphere. It covers the area in between the city walls (to the north and east) and Olympiados Street (to the south), and has had the luck to remain untouched by the 1917 great fire. It was virtually uninhabited until the mid-15th century, when it was conquered by the Ottomans who selected it for settlement on account of its fine climate, panoramic views and strategic position. The two and three-storey houses bear mixed Macedonian and Ottoman architectural elements (sachnisia) [Şahniş in turkish]; there are also residences with neoclassical and eclectic style motifs where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. converts to Islam who secretly remained Jews. After 1922 many refugees settled in the area. Despite the construction of newer buildings and the opening up of new streets in recent decades, it has kept its original town planning, to a large extent, with narrow alleys and scant squares, as well as its original architectural features, particularly in the west and east part of the town. response:
The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki holds significant historical importance in relation to the city's Macedonian heritage. As the former capital of the Roman province of Macedonia, the forum has preserved many historical structures and artifacts that showcase the city's rich cultural and architectural history. 

One of the most notable features of the Roman Forum is the reconstructed Odeon, which was built in the 2nd-4th century AD. This ancient structure has been restored to its original glory and now serves as a venue for cultural events. The forum also features a round bath house, which dates back to the 1st century BC, showcasing the city's ancient infrastructure and architectural achievements.

The Roman Forum's historical significance extends beyond its individual structures, as it played a pivotal role in the city's development as a major cultural and economic center. During the Roman period, Thessaloniki was an important hub for trade and commerce, and the forum served as a symbol of the city's prosperity and power.

Furthermore, the Roman Forum has been an important site for archaeological excavations, providing valuable insights into the city's history and development. The forum's archaeological site has yielded numerous artifacts, including mosaics, sculptures, and coins, which have shed light on the city's cultural and economic activities during the Roman period.

In summary, the Roman Forum in Thessaloniki is a treasure trove of historical significance, offering a glimpse into the city's rich cultural and architectural heritage. As a major cultural and economic center during the Roman period, the forum has preserved many historical structures and artifacts that showcase the city's significance in the ancient world.

**Instagrammable Spot:** The Roman Forum's reconstructed Odeon is a must-visit for any Instagram enthusiast, offering stunning photo opportunities amidst its ancient architecture. Visitors can capture breathtaking shots of the Odeon's intricate details, the surrounding architecture, and the vibrant cultural events that take place within the forum.
reference: The Roman Forum in Thessaloniki, which served as the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, highlights the city's Macedonian heritage. Constructed in two phases during the mid-2nd and mid-3rd centuries AD, it reflects the architectural and cultural influences of the time. The forum was gradually abandoned after the 7th century, but its remnants, including a large rectangular square and the double underground Cryptoporticus, provide insight into the historical significance of Thessaloniki as a key location in Macedonia.

Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to

["<1-hop>

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. Out of the original monastery complex, -apart from the katholicon – there remain the NIKIS NIKIS GERMANOU SVOLOU IASONIDOU TSIMISKI VAS. Roman (Ancient) Forum During the roman period, this 2-hectare area used to be the social and religious centre of the city. Construction was completed in two phases (in the mid-2nd and mid- 3rd centuries AD) and it was gradually abandoned after the 7th century. The NW section of the archaeological site is covered by a large rectangular square [Α] with traces of marble paving. In the S section of the square lies the largest part of the double underground Cryptoporticus [covered passageway] [Β] which was most probably used as a public storehouse. The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is a significant piece of art that showcases the early Christian period in Thessaloniki. The mural is part of the archaeological site of the Roman Forum, which features various structures and artifacts from the 1st century BC to the 13th century AD. The mural depicts early Christian themes and is a valuable example of the early Christian period in Thessaloniki. 

In the context of Thessaloniki, the early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is closely related to the city's rich Christian heritage. Thessaloniki has been a major city in the Christian world since the 4th century BC, and it has been home to numerous Christian monuments and churches throughout its history. The city's UNESCO-recognized Byzantine monuments, such as the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Ascension of Christ Church, are just a few examples of the many Christian monuments that can be found in Thessaloniki.

The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is a significant part of Thessaloniki's Christian heritage, and it is a testament to the city's long history of Christian worship and art. The mural is a valuable example of the early Christian period in Thessaloniki, and it provides a glimpse into the city's rich cultural and artistic history.

In terms of its significance, the early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is a rare and unique example of early Christian art in Thessaloniki. The mural is a masterpiece of Byzantine art, and it is a must-see for anyone interested in the city's Christian heritage. Visitors can explore the Roman Forum and see the mural in person, gaining a deeper understanding of the city's early Christian history and culture. 

Overall, the early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is a significant and fascinating piece of art that provides a glimpse into Thessaloniki's rich Christian heritage. It is a must-see for anyone visiting the city, and it is a testament to the city's long history of Christian worship and art.
reference: The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is significant as it represents the transition of the city into a center of Christian faith during the late Roman period. This mural, uncovered in a public storehouse, showcases the artistic expression of early Christianity. It relates to the Christian monuments in Thessaloniki, which were constructed during the Byzantine period and reflect the city's historical importance as one of the first towns to embrace Christianity, influenced by the Apostle Paul. Both the mural and the monuments highlight Thessaloniki's rich Christian heritage and its role in the broader Byzantine world.

retrieved_contexts:
['10
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.', '16
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
14	\x07AGIOS NIKOLAOS 
[SAINT NICHOLAS] 
ORPHANOS CHURCH
It was built in the 1310s,  
as a dependency of Vlatadon 
Monastery and it served as a 
monastery main church. Within 
the same grounds there used 
to be an orphanage at earlier 
times – hence the name 
“Orphanos” [meaning Orphan]. 
It is an aisleless timber-roofed 
church sided by an ambulatory 
forming the shape “Π”.  
The 14th c. murals inside are 
true masterpieces depicting 
scenes of Dodekaorto [the 
Twelve major religious feasts  
of the year], of the Passion  
of Christ, the Resurrection and 
the Liturgical Cycle as well as 
figures of saints; the monument 
is considered as one of the 
best preserved in Thessaloniki. 
It is surrounded by lush and 
serene gardens.
15	CITY WALLS
Thessaloniki was walled 
immediately after it was 
founded by Cassander; in 
390 AD a series of large-
scale changes took place by 
Theodosius I. In the Byzantine 
times a harbour was constructed 
(in the SW part) and the 
Acropolis wall was raised (see 
p. 44). During the Venetian Rule 
(1st half of the 15th c.)', '60
7th walk: 
WEST OF THE CENTRE-STAVROUPOLI
2.6  Holy Twelve Apostles 
Church
(see p. 8).
2.7  West City Walls.
Sections of the city’s west walls  
remain along Arkadioupoleos and 
Eirinis Streets and finds related 
to Litaia Gate have recently 
been located at the corner 
of Agiou Dimitriou and Agiou 
Nestoros Streets. This gate 
used to be one of the seven 
great gates of the fortified city 
and formed part of the Early 
Christian period walls; it was 
named after Liti, a Byzantine 
town to which the gate led. 
The Golden Gate was also 
located on the Egnatia  
Street level.
2.8  Pasha Hamam  
[Paşa Hamami] (Phoenix  
Bath house).
It was built during the 
1520s by Cezeri Kasim Paşa. 
Also known as Phoenix Bath 
house, this used to be the 
last ottoman bath house open 
in town, as it closed down in 
as late as 1981. It is located 
at the corner of Kalvou and 
Pineiou Streets, near the west 
walls and the church of the 
Holy Twelve Apostles, and the 
structure of the building was 
planned with great care.', '77
MUSEUMS
collection includes works of art 
by leading Greek Artists; the 
Byzantine and Postbyzantine 
Icons collection is related to 
the school of Thessaloniki 
and spans 5 centuries (14th 
-19th c.); and a collection of 
360 pieces of art on Greek 
Engraving. Retrospective 
exhibitions of Greek and 
foreign artists are frequently 
arranged in collaboration with 
art foundations in Greece and 
abroad.
GALLERY OF THE 
SOCIETY FOR 
MACEDONIAN STUDIES
It is housed on the top floor 
of the Theatre Building of 
the S.M.S. and it is the first 
visual arts museum in the city. 
It encompasses 300 pieces 
of art (painting, sculpture 
and engraving) by famous 
Greek and foreign artists, 
mostly from northern Greece, 
who represent the major art 
movements of the 20th c.
CULTURAL CENTRE OF 
THESSALONIKI (NATIONAL 
BANK OF GREECE 
CULTURAL FOUNDATION)
It opened to the public in 
1989 and has, ever since,  
been organising major painting,  
sculpture, photography and 
architecture exhibitions in 
collaboration with other local 
educational and cultural 
agencies. Events related to  
the history of the city and  
the greater area also take  
place there. The collection 
includes approx. 250 pieces  
on painting, sculpture, pottery,  
mosaics, murals and 
engraving.', '108
CHURCHES OF VARIOUS 
DENOMINATIONS
Orthodox Metropolitan Church 
of Agios Grigorios Palamas:  
3, Agias Sofias St. 
tel.: 2310 271.520
Catholic Church of the 
Immaculate Conception  
of the Virgin Mary: 
19, Fragkon St. 
tel.: 2310 539.550
Armenian Orthodox Church:  
4, Dialetti St. 
tel.: 2310 275.352
Greek Evangelical Church:  
37, Palaion Patron Germanou St. 
tel.: 2310 273.380
Yad Lezicaron Synagogue 
(Centre of Jewish History  
in Thessaloniki):  
24, Vas. Irakleiou St. 
tel.: 2310 223.231
Monastirioton Synagogue: 
35, Syngrou St. 
tel.: 2310 524.968
CULTURAL EVENTS – 
EXHIBITIONS
Demetria. 
It is the city’s oldest cultural 
institution, linked inextricably 
with its cultural identity. It takes 
place every autumn (September 
– November) and includes 
theatrical, dance and music 
shows, exhibitions, scientific 
congresses, day conferences 
and special tributes to Greek and 
foreign destinations.  
For information contact the 
Vice-Mayor’s Office responsible 
for Cultural, Educational and 
Tourist Affairs of the City, at 25, 
Theofilou St., (Ano Poli),  
tel.']

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. response:
The significant Christian murals in Thessaloniki are found in the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, which is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in history and art. The church features 14th-century murals depicting scenes of the Dodekaorto (the Twelve major religious feasts of the year), the Passion of Christ, the Resurrection, and the Liturgical Cycle, as well as figures of saints. These murals are considered some of the best-preserved in Thessaloniki and are a testament to the city's rich Christian heritage.

Unfortunately, the Roman Forum is not a significant Christian site in Thessaloniki. The city's ancient history is more closely tied to its Byzantine and Ottoman past, rather than its Roman heritage. However, visitors can explore the city's ancient ruins, including the walls and the remains of the Roman Forum, which is a fascinating glimpse into Thessaloniki's ancient past.

If you're looking for other significant Christian murals in Thessaloniki, you might also want to visit the Byzantine Museum, which features a collection of early-Christian and Byzantine monuments, including the famous "Mosaics of the Holy Virgin" and the "Mosaics of the Apostles". The museum is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in Byzantine art and history.

Overall, Thessaloniki is a city that is steeped in history and culture, with a rich Christian heritage that is reflected in its many churches and museums. Whether you're interested in history, art, or architecture, Thessaloniki has something to offer.
reference: In Thessaloniki, the Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built between 1310 and 1314, features a mural depicting Theotokos (Mother of God) and the Founder, showcasing early Christian iconography. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as the social and religious center during the Roman period, contains a valuable early Christian mural uncovered in its underground Cryptoporticus, further highlighting the city's rich Christian heritage.

14	\x07AGIOS NIKOLAOS 
[SAINT NICHOLAS] 
ORPHANOS CHURCH
It was built in the 1310s,  
as a dependency of Vlatadon 
Monastery and it served as a 
monastery main church. Within 
the same grounds there used 
to be an orphanage at earlier 
times – hence the name 
“Orphanos” [meaning Orphan]. 
It is an aisleless timber-roofed 
church sided by an ambulatory 
forming the shape “Π”.  
The 14th c. murals inside are 
true masterpieces depicting 
scenes of Dodekaorto [the 
Twelve major religious feasts  
of the year], of the Passion  
of Christ, the Resurrection and 
the Liturgical Cycle as well as 
figures of saints; the monument 
is considered as one of the 
best preserved in Thessaloniki. 
It is surrounded by lush and 
serene gardens.
15	CITY WALLS
Thessaloniki was walled 
immediately after it was 
founded by Cassander; in 
390 AD a series of large-
scale changes took place by 
Theodosius I. In the Byzantine 
times a harbour was constructed 
(in the SW part) and the 
Acropolis wall was raised (see 
p. 44). During the Venetian Rule 
(1st half of the 15th c.)']

At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. response:
The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is significant because it showcases the city's early Christian heritage. This is part of Thessaloniki's rich Christian history, which dates back to the Apostle Paul's visit to the city. The mural depicts the early Christian period, highlighting the importance of this era in Thessaloniki's development.

In Thessaloniki, there are numerous Christian monuments that demonstrate the city's significant role in the Christian world. The city was one of the first to adopt Christianity, and its Christian monuments, such as the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Agios Ioannis Prodromos church, are excellent examples of Byzantine church-building and art. UNESCO has declared these monuments World Heritage Sites, recognizing their cultural and historical significance.

The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is a testament to Thessaloniki's early Christian period and its connection to the Apostle Paul. This mural, along with other Christian monuments in the city, provides a glimpse into the city's rich Christian heritage. The fact that the Roman Forum was used by Christians during the late Roman period adds to the significance of the mural, as it demonstrates the city's adaptability and openness to new ideas.

In summary, the early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is a significant example of Thessaloniki's early Christian period, and it is part of a larger collection of Christian monuments that demonstrate the city's importance in the Christian world. These monuments, including the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Agios Ioannis Prodromos church, are a must-visit for anyone interested in exploring Thessaloniki's Christian heritage.
reference: The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is significant as it represents the social and religious center of the city during the Roman period, showcasing the transition to Christianity in the region. This mural, uncovered on one of the walls of the Cryptoporticus, highlights the influence of Christian art and architecture that developed in Thessaloniki, which was one of the first towns to embrace Christianity through the Apostle Paul. The Christian monuments in Thessaloniki, including churches built during the Byzantine period, reflect this rich heritage and the city's role as a major center for early Christian culture.

retrieved_contexts:
['10
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.', '16
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
14	\x07AGIOS NIKOLAOS 
[SAINT NICHOLAS] 
ORPHANOS CHURCH
It was built in the 1310s,  
as a dependency of Vlatadon 
Monastery and it served as a 
monastery main church. Within 
the same grounds there used 
to be an orphanage at earlier 
times – hence the name 
“Orphanos” [meaning Orphan]. 
It is an aisleless timber-roofed 
church sided by an ambulatory 
forming the shape “Π”.  
The 14th c. murals inside are 
true masterpieces depicting 
scenes of Dodekaorto [the 
Twelve major religious feasts  
of the year], of the Passion  
of Christ, the Resurrection and 
the Liturgical Cycle as well as 
figures of saints; the monument 
is considered as one of the 
best preserved in Thessaloniki. 
It is surrounded by lush and 
serene gardens.
15	CITY WALLS
Thessaloniki was walled 
immediately after it was 
founded by Cassander; in 
390 AD a series of large-
scale changes took place by 
Theodosius I. In the Byzantine 
times a harbour was constructed 
(in the SW part) and the 
Acropolis wall was raised (see 
p. 44). During the Venetian Rule 
(1st half of the 15th c.)', '12
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Christian monuments in the 
Orthodox world. It is a cross-
domed basilica and used to 
be the Metropolitan Church 
(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian 
worship after 1912. The 
capitals date to the 5th – 6th 
c. (they were part of the older 
church); the wonderful mosaics 
are an absolute must-see, 
particularly the ones on the 
dome with the image of the 
Ascension of Christ, as are 
the murals crafted in different 
stages from the 8th to the 
11th c. In the church’s south 
side, amid green surroundings 
you will find the church of 
Agios Ioannis Prodromos [St. 
John the Forerunner] (1940); 
from this point you will enter 
the early-Christian baptistery 
(catacomb) of Agia Sofia, built 
on the ruins of roman baths.
5 	\x07TRANSFIGURATION OF 
THE SAVIOUR CHURCH 
[METAMORFOSI SOTIROS]
It is located on Egnatia Street 
(see p. 34) almost between 
Kamara (see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
Construction took place possibly 
around 1340 and it is a typical 
example of the transitional type 
in Byzantine church-building, 
found particularly in Macedonia.', '13 	MONI VLATADON
It is the only Byzantine 
monastery in the city with 
an active community. It was 
founded in the 14th c. by the 
monks Vlatis (or Vlateus) 
brothers and was dedicated to 
Pantocrator Christos [Almighty 
Christ]. Celebrations take 
place on the Transfiguration 
of Christ feast day. Its main 
church [katholikon] is of the 
inscribed cross-in-square type 
but the dome rests on the 
walls and on two piers instead 
of columns. It is surrounded 
by a portico and there are two 
chapels. Murals were painted 
during 1360 – 1380 and the 
17th c. iconostasis is particularly 
noteworthy. It is surrounded 
by a large garden offering a 
wonderful view of the city and 
there is also a small peacock 
farm; in the grounds you will 
also find the newer buildings 
of Misirogleios Library, the 
Patriarchal Foundation for 
Theological Studies (1968),  
a space provided for the study of 
pictorial manuscripts from Mount 
Athos, a bookstore and a shop.
8', '77
MUSEUMS
collection includes works of art 
by leading Greek Artists; the 
Byzantine and Postbyzantine 
Icons collection is related to 
the school of Thessaloniki 
and spans 5 centuries (14th 
-19th c.); and a collection of 
360 pieces of art on Greek 
Engraving. Retrospective 
exhibitions of Greek and 
foreign artists are frequently 
arranged in collaboration with 
art foundations in Greece and 
abroad.
GALLERY OF THE 
SOCIETY FOR 
MACEDONIAN STUDIES
It is housed on the top floor 
of the Theatre Building of 
the S.M.S. and it is the first 
visual arts museum in the city. 
It encompasses 300 pieces 
of art (painting, sculpture 
and engraving) by famous 
Greek and foreign artists, 
mostly from northern Greece, 
who represent the major art 
movements of the 20th c.
CULTURAL CENTRE OF 
THESSALONIKI (NATIONAL 
BANK OF GREECE 
CULTURAL FOUNDATION)
It opened to the public in 
1989 and has, ever since,  
been organising major painting,  
sculpture, photography and 
architecture exhibitions in 
collaboration with other local 
educational and cultural 
agencies. Events related to  
the history of the city and  
the greater area also take  
place there. The collection 
includes approx. 250 pieces  
on painting, sculpture, pottery,  
mosaics, murals and 
engraving.']

At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. response:
In Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments, Christian murals hold significant cultural and historical value. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, in particular, is renowned for its exceptional Christian murals, which date back to the 14th century. These murals depict various scenes from the life of Christ and the Holy Virgin, showcasing the artistic and spiritual heritage of the Byzantine era.

The church's murals are not only aesthetically striking but also provide valuable insights into the city's rich Christian history. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church is considered one of the best-preserved Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki, and its murals are a testament to the city's importance as a center of Christian learning and worship during the Byzantine period.

While the Roman Forum is not directly related to Christian murals, it is an essential part of Thessaloniki's historical landscape. The forum, which dates back to the Roman era, features several archaeological sites, including the remains of the ancient city walls and the remains of the Roman theater. Although not directly connected to Christian murals, the Roman Forum provides a fascinating glimpse into Thessaloniki's ancient past, highlighting the city's strategic importance as a crossroads between the East and the West.

In summary, Christian murals are a vital aspect of Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments, offering a unique window into the city's spiritual and cultural heritage. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, in particular, is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring Thessaloniki's rich Christian history. While the Roman Forum is not directly related to Christian murals, it remains an essential part of the city's historical landscape, providing a captivating glimpse into Thessaloniki's ancient past.
reference: Christian murals in Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments are significant as they reflect the city's early adoption of Christianity and its rich religious heritage. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, built between 1310 and 1314, features a mural depicting Theotokos, showcasing the church's dedication to the Mother of God and its role in the Byzantine religious landscape. Additionally, the Roman Forum, which served as a social and religious center, contains an early Christian mural that highlights the transition from paganism to Christianity in the region. Together, these murals exemplify the artistic and spiritual evolution during the Byzantine period, contributing to Thessaloniki's designation as a UNESCO World Heritage site.

A 2nd - 4th c. AD Odeon [C]

[D] was unearthed which has

Parts of a colonnade, mosaic

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by

Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a

early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are

specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.

Christian monuments in the 
Orthodox world. It is a cross-
domed basilica and used to 
be the Metropolitan Church 
(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian 
worship after 1912. The 
capitals date to the 5th – 6th 
c. (they were part of the older 
church); the wonderful mosaics 
are an absolute must-see, 
particularly the ones on the 
dome with the image of the 
Ascension of Christ, as are 
the murals crafted in different 
stages from the 8th to the 
11th c. In the church’s south 
side, amid green surroundings 
you will find the church of 
Agios Ioannis Prodromos [St. 
John the Forerunner] (1940); 
from this point you will enter 
the early-Christian baptistery 
(catacomb) of Agia Sofia, built 
on the ruins of roman baths.
5 	\x07TRANSFIGURATION OF 
THE SAVIOUR CHURCH 
[METAMORFOSI SOTIROS]
It is located on Egnatia Street 
(see p. 34) almost between 
Kamara (see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
Construction took place possibly 
around 1340 and it is a typical

in Byzantine church-building,

1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
14	\x07AGIOS NIKOLAOS 
[SAINT NICHOLAS] 
ORPHANOS CHURCH
It was built in the 1310s,  
as a dependency of Vlatadon 
Monastery and it served as a 
monastery main church. Within 
the same grounds there used 
to be an orphanage at earlier 
times – hence the name 
“Orphanos” [meaning Orphan]. 
It is an aisleless timber-roofed 
church sided by an ambulatory 
forming the shape “Π”.  
The 14th c. murals inside are 
true masterpieces depicting 
scenes of Dodekaorto [the 
Twelve major religious feasts  
of the year], of the Passion  
of Christ, the Resurrection and 
the Liturgical Cycle as well as 
figures of saints; the monument 
is considered as one of the 
best preserved in Thessaloniki. 
It is surrounded by lush and 
serene gardens.
15	CITY WALLS
Thessaloniki was walled 
immediately after it was 
founded by Cassander; in 
390 AD a series of large-
scale changes took place by 
Theodosius I. In the Byzantine 
times a harbour was constructed 
(in the SW part) and the 
Acropolis wall was raised (see 
p. 44). During the Venetian Rule 
(1st half of the 15th c.)']

UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS Thessaloniki has been one of the first towns to know the Christian religion by the Apostle Paul; during the Byzantine period it used to be the second most important city of the empire (co-reigning city) after Constantinople. At that time (4th – 15th c.), Christian monuments and churches were constructed in the town, and these make up a diachronic typology with a decisive influence on the entire Byzantine world. The following early-Christian and Byzantine monuments of the town are considered to be excellent specimens of the Byzantine church-building and art, and for this reason UNESCO declared them to be World Heritage Monuments, in 1988. A tour across this unique open-air Byzantine museum is truly a special experience. 1 \x07HOLY TWELVE APOSTLES CHURCH One of the town’s oldest churches was built in 1310 – 1314 under the sponsorship of Patriarch Nephon I. It used to be a katholicon [main church] of a monastery dedicated to Theotokos [Mother of God] as shown by the mural depicting Theotokos and the Founder, as well as by the iconography on the aisle with images of the Holy Virgin’s life. response:
The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is a significant artifact that showcases the early Christian period in Thessaloniki. This mural is a part of a larger archaeological site, the Museum of the Roman Forum, which is an extension of the historic centre. The mural depicts various Christian scenes, including the Passion of Christ, which is also depicted in the Agios Ioannis Prodromos church in Thessaloniki.

The Agios Ioannis Prodromos church is a notable example of early Christian architecture and art in Thessaloniki. The church features beautiful murals, including the Ascension of Christ, which is also depicted in the Roman Forum mural. This mural is considered a masterpiece of early Christian art and is a testament to the rich cultural heritage of Thessaloniki.

The connection between the Roman Forum mural and the Christian monuments in Thessaloniki is that they both showcase the city's early Christian period. The Roman Forum mural provides a glimpse into the early Christian era, while the Agios Ioannis Prodromos church represents the more developed Christian architecture and art that emerged in the city during the Byzantine period.

Both the Roman Forum mural and the Agios Ioannis Prodromos church are UNESCO World Heritage Monuments, recognizing their cultural significance and importance to the city's history. Visitors to Thessaloniki can explore these monuments and experience the city's rich cultural heritage firsthand. The Roman Forum mural and the Agios Ioannis Prodromos church are must-see attractions for anyone interested in history, art, and culture.
reference: The early Christian mural found in the Roman Forum is significant as it represents the transition of the city into a center of Christian faith during the Roman period. This mural, uncovered in a public storehouse, showcases the artistic expression of early Christianity. It relates to the Christian monuments in Thessaloniki, which were constructed during the Byzantine period and reflect the city's historical importance as one of the first towns to embrace Christianity, influenced by the Apostle Paul. Both the mural and the monuments highlight Thessaloniki's rich Christian heritage and its role in the spread of Christianity in the Byzantine world.
